question:
So I just sent masters to a label - digital and vinyl. 

How involved have you been in test presses and selecting which one gets pressed? Has the band ever had opinions? Are you trying to find the one that is most faithful to the original files sent?

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: The point of the test pressing isn't to pick one, it's more of a sanity check on the vinyl master.  I would always recommend an acetate to avoid the pain in the ass of discovering a problem with your master at test pressing. The acetate precedes the sign off on the master and allows you to hear what your music MIGHT sound like on a record. It is definitely lesser quality than a test pressing and a full vinyl run, but the $80 or $100 it costs will be money well spent to avoid a wasted cycle and cost of a bunk test-pressing.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content:
test pressings don’t work that way, the test pressing is to determine if the cut and plating has any problems, if it does all 5 of the pressings will have the same problems in the same spots.

What you need to do is sit and listen with a notepad noting the times of the “problems” you hear, on each pressing, then if all of them have the same issue, then you have a problem with the pressing.

If you know the cutting engineer that’s the best.

My cutting engineer said, “watch sibilance and take all loudness processing off, driver at -18 and you know then you’ll have a decent vinyl master.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: also, removing any additional distortion/clipping on the master will help translate better, as the cutting will impart a character to it, and the cutting engineer will do EQ before it hits the heads to control the level going onto the acetate.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: So, to more specifically answer your questions....the band should usually hear the test pressing but to find the kinds of problems @Eric Martin is talking about.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content:
it’s not a fun process, I’ve done it for two LP’s, I’d rather trust the cutting engineer.

Any other questions could probably be answered by this FAQ page. (Scroll to vinyl specific questions)

https://www.rareformmastering.com/faq

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: I've been running a primarily vinyl label since 2000 or so and vinyl's an absolute fucking pain in the ass. Something ALWAYS goes wrong. (I stopped pressing a few years ago...can't deal anymore...it's gotten too expensive to do right and the wait times are insane for little guys like me)...all that said, I love vinyl lol, but not pressing it.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: it’s hard for smaller artists too, everyone wants to offer it, but it’s mostly a pain, I have 100’s of copies of a 10” EP, in storage because fans don’t see much value in a 4 song 45 that cost $20 😆

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: even less so for 2 song 12"s! 🤣

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: oof, I have one full closet. 😆

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Wow, this is amazing info. I’m glad I asked. Thank you all a ton!! First thing I’ve worked on that actually made it to vinyl so we will see.

question: when mixing live drums, what makes you wanna use gates?

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: the main thing is that in order to get that modern high-end attack from individual drums, you need to do a lot of eq boosting. this causes the cymbals that are picked up by the close mics to be super loud. if you gate those close mics (or even better: just mute the audio around each hit by hand) you have a lot more control with how much you can process and control those individual drums

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: there are other tricks too like triggering room mic gates with the snare drum to get the snare to explode. but that isolation of close mics for attack is the main thing i do

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: All of what Matt said, yep

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Anything like toms that aren't playing throughout should be stripped, not just gated

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Unless you're intentionally using them as bleed mics for the snare or whatever (which I don't, drums are phase soup as it stands and I'd rather not complicate it as-is

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: To play devils advocate, there's benefits to using gates instead of stripping audio. If you automate the threshold on the gate, then you have the benefit of manipulating the attack, release, and ratio of the gate while mixing. Sometimes i'll find when getting deep into the mix that opening the gates a little bit starts to make things sound a little bit more natural, while keeping the general effect of the gate.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: That's also a valid approach; for me, though, it just ends up being too hard to isolate tom hits from snare hits and I just don't consider it worth the effort. Metal drummers are a special breed, and not usually in a good way.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: But to answer your question, @hendrick, gates just help you keep things focused across multiple drum mics.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: They tend to go really fast but their dynamic control is often total dicks

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Only thing I can add is sometimes Tom mics will have snare bleed that is undesirable and interferes with the snare sound. Also gating toms can help mask sympathetic tom resonance from kick drum hits. But Sometimes the bleed is helpful for the kick and snare too. Same with hihat bleed Into snare. With a gate, You can turn up the snare without also turning up the hihat (but it’s a lot more complicated than that if it’s a really loud hihat In the snare)

question: Saw the great discussion on the biz talk channel. As an artist who wants to learn more about proper rates, what is the typical price range one should expect from a mixing engineer? My previous audio engineer cost 300 per song for a mix + master. How far off is that from the typical range? Since I used him for the entire EP, I don't really have another baseline for price differentials. I hesitate to reach out on soundbetter sometimes because the assumption is that I wouldn't be able to afford it by default. Nonetheless, I figured asking here could be a good start for the comparison. Completely open to budgeting more and waiting until I can afford the new cost.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Outside of big music hubs, for people who don’t have lots of famous credits, that’s not crazy. 

I think a lot of us are sitting in the 200-400 range per song except for those working in bigger markets or with a bit more high level credits under their belt (Correct me if I’m wrong).

It really can vary from $200-$3000. I mean truly.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
I know guys who sit firmly at $750, $1500, $2500. Grammys and charting songs put you at a level, major label work puts you at a level, playlisted releases also. 
I mostly mix my own productions (indie and label,) but I build that into my rates (which are flexible depending on alll the things.)

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: It does really depend on the market and credits, buuuuut

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: $300 for mixing and "mastering" is quite cheap

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Look at fancy pants over here charging appropriately

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
I’m transitioning out of my $200/song mixing phase. Trying to move to 250-300, and NOT “mastering” ever again.

(I’m in Kansas City Missouri for reference.)

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
$250-$300 is a reasonable rate for an newer mixer, and it’s what I ask for a demo mix. $500 for indie, $1000 for label (cause label deliverables are insane.) 

You can release my hot mix, but ill push you hard to call @Rollmottle. I’ve even offered to pay for him myself.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: But all those rates are flexible.

expert_answers.author: ehutton21
expert_answers.content: This is where I sit, but if it’s someone Ive known for years, I’m not gonna accost them if they can’t pay me upfront before working. I usually just don’t deliver till I get $$

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: label deliverables are nuts

question: I guess I'm asking as a workflow question -- if you have a working session and need to downsample it, but maintain the PT session – I'm guessing RX will break all of the PT linking embedded into the audio files?

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: It’s been a minute but yeah, save session copy and then replace the audio files with the ones you’ve batch converted in RX

expert_answers.author: Will Melones
expert_answers.content: I feel like relinking the files with a different sample rate would really piss off pro tools

expert_answers.author: Will Melones
expert_answers.content: But have only done this with a big folder of WAVs

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: yeah, makes sense. not sure how PT works. on my end, Reaper will replace the underlying file if you change the one in the session (post an RX spectral repair for example), so it's pretty seamless over here.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I wouldn’t reopen the session until the RX’d WAVs were in place. Then it will kick up a message about file IDs and you just replace with match by name

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: But it’s been a long time so ..

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: but highly recommend the RX Batch tool for mass SRC operations like these. very fast and you can make presets to have it do the same thing every time, append the right file naming, etc.

expert_answers.author: Will Melones
expert_answers.content: If they don’t play back at double speed I’ll do a rain dance

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: RX for SRC is definitely more of a  “I’ve got 12 stems” rather than a 200 track mix with 1000 regions per track

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: latter use case would be very fraught

question: This is interesting - i remember seeing a steve albini video (and i think some other folks) talking about how analog tape is the most reliable archival format (specifically over digital) because the equipment and playback will "always" exist and be able to happen, etc. but I mean fuck what are you supposed to do, every so often archive your entire tape catalog to brand new tape? (not literally asking because everyone does digital archival, but just thinking out loud)

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: even just messing with it for a day or two and realizing that the tape eventually completely degerades and you can't really use it after a certain point is just interesting

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Yes… you bake it and move it to new tape to live on in a cold dark cave for 20 years. The idea is that you could still retrieve the audio, unlike some old install of pro tools from 25 years ago, or something.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: It was a flimsy argument and technology has since lapped it

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: totally. I get what he was saying, and yeah, old software completely disappearing is a very real thing

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: like certain plugins we all use now will absolutely just not be able to be used in 20 years

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: But to be fair, tape is pretty robust. I’ve smashed it on the ground, uncrumpled from the trash, spools up fine

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
That is cool. I was nervous messing with it early on (literally have touched tape less than 10 times) and it really is robust. it's not overly fragile by any means. I think it's lovely.
makes me appreciate both sides, digital and analog. 
thanks again for all the info guys.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: i do REALLY like how this machine sounds just from some quick playback and record tests

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Even though this is true, if the machine is in good shape you’ll get a lot of mileage off one tape

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: 5050 was my first tape machine, had lots of fun with it.

question: How many people have a goal they believe in?  I think that’s a hard part for many people these days

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I think it’s really hard

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: And whatever little bit of time I have to give here I’d prefer to help people with that question

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Doesn’t have to be a specific goal, can be a general mission like mine, or even just a better relationship with the work

expert_answers.author: chrissorem
expert_answers.content: Most definitely I do believe this is a job that not a lot of people are cut out for it has a lot of ups and downs and I’m sure a lot of us have something in common here which is it’s the passion for the work that keeps us going and if you don’t have that inherently in you I think this work just looks like from the outside is “what a fun job you have”  “I want to do something fun for a living” and yes, there has many fun aspects of the job as well as things that are very difficult and I think anyone that’s been doing this for more than 10 years Likely has what it takes to at least survive. I’m sure it’s the same for many jobs whether your teacher or a lawyer or a doctor if you’re not passionate about the work, you hit the realities of what the work is.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: This is very succinct

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I would guess 90% of people who think they want my job would change their mind if they had real insight into what it’s like

expert_answers.author: chrissorem
expert_answers.content: @Felipe De Mari Scalone  he was my last assistant and he studied to be a lawyer and even practiced Law and realized this can’t be his life. He’s too passionate about making music and creating art and basically started over and I’ll tell you what this dude has what it takes.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: And I think I’d like a wine taster but the reality is also not what I imagine. In some way we must have an unrealistic and idealized version of a goal to keep pushing

expert_answers.author: chrissorem
expert_answers.content: And that energy is contagious. Makes me wanna be better at what I’m doing.

question: Do you hear or feel a difference on rates when you aggregate all of those experiences Peter?

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: Maybe it’s budget gear but I couldn’t get 24 channel sessions on ADAT to work without clicks and pops with only toslink, once I added word clock cables and linked properly it eliminated my issue

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: When i stick a pencil in my eye it hurts. Never ADAT, not even once 🙂

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Hadn’t thought of it, but my initial answer is yes with a massive caveat that I believe negates the whole thing. At the studio I was at, I was really 95% of the time tracking, mostly live ensembles, and a good amount of jazz. We had big soffit mounted ATCs. Amazing mics, beautiful room. So I have lots of memories working there tracking beautiful sounding acoustic things that were really wonderful and open. In recent years, I’ve dug much more into aggressively processing sounds/making more creative engineering decisions that often involve mangling shit. So in my current world, I’m interested in higher rates to push off that aliasing issue, but day to day am perfectly happy at 48.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: So I guess to state more clearly: caveat is in my current world I don’t think it *really* matters, and in that other situation I suppose it was nice but a small small piece of the puzzle.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ it serves a functional purpose for me and ahas let me record larger projects

question: Why would you not pay attention to a null test? Obviously if they don’t null, you need to decide which is better. But if they DO, null… end of conversation, right? Objectively the same.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Even things that null down to -60 or -80 dBFS can sound and feel very different

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: If it’s a 100% -140dB null then that is meaningful, and rare

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: So it’s mostly useless for comparing things

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I would say that most of the conclusions I see people reaching based on null tests are flawed

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: But to go to @itaylerner ‘s question. SRC is not voodoo, it’s entirely possible that Logic’s SRC is performing really well

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: This site shows you how wildly different SRC's can handle aliasing. https://src.infinitewave.ca/

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: It’s just adding zeros and filtering

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: That all makes sense re: null

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: It does, but it doesn’t show you the trade offs of steeper filtering at all. It’s not just “aliasing bad, remove that and you are good”. The filters have an effect on transients

This is interesting:

“The Lightning to 3.5 mm Audio Cable was designed to allow AirPods Max to connect to analog sources for listening to movies and music. AirPods Max can be connected to devices playing Lossless and Hi-Res Lossless recordings with exceptional audio quality. However, given the analog-to-digital conversion in the cable, the playback will not be completely lossless.”

question: By building around it, are you talking about adding more mics and then tracking that way - or coming in later with another mics and then tracking over that?

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Adding more mics and cabs

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: But like get the tone as best as you can with 1 57

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content:
Also with tracking my mindset is

Always a L and R for rthyms or main guitar. And then quads for emphasis and I’ll go insane with different layers with different octaves. On impactful parts that need some lift (natural automation as I jokingly call it) I’ll stack a distorted l/r octave down on some hits with like a pitch pedal or octave fuzz, but it’s never to stand out or be heard it’s just like when I need the rthyms to feel larger than the previous section.


Quads of the same octave help reinforce the tone than trying to be a whole other part sonically

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Won’t quad the whole song tho. Choruses, main riffs, breakdowns, big chugga parts, whatever needs it

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: I am really big on being a crackhead with summing multiple mics on multiple cabs with multiple heads down to one track so I don’t have like 30 guitar tracks in my daw.

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: But like you can screw that up pretty quick if you can’t understand how to get one massive tone with 1 mic

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: But if I don’t have a plethora of gear and only have plugins or an amp sim, I am still fine cause I’ll track that way mentioned above

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: But also like not everything has to be double tracked. Maybe it’s a chill verse with just drum and bass and the only guitar is like a little chord thing off to the right.  That classic saying if everything is wide then nothing is wide. Contrast makes the guitar huge

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: I am also big on the single guitar down the chorus or big parts + the l/r that can always sound dope

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: I've been in the throes of moving my production rig from an M1 mini to an M4 mini over the past couple of weeks. Definitely do not underestimate the time sink of standing up a new rig that is as tuned and ready to go as your current one. Takes some time to make sure you get the new one cooking as good the old one. It's just work, but a pain in the ass. and a pretty unsolved user experience problem.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Single core is helpful for audio tasks (think snappy and responsive, good low latency performance) and multi core is more helpful as the session gets larger.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: I’d say hold off for now if you’re already on M2 Max

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: Copy that. My shit is generally bitchin

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content:
Just taking the time to figure out the right changeover strategy and timing so that I could actually make the move once I basically had two fully functioning rigs stood up in parallel. My additional complicating factor is having a laptop that is a dupe of the studio rig, so keeping it all straight and everything in sync is a bit of a puzzle. 

I took the transition as the opportunity to phase out some mechanical drives so I had to get some new drives for the M4 instead of re-using the old Time Machine mechanical drive. The M4 mini only has Thunderbolt/USB C ports -- the M1 has USB A's and Thunderbolt/USB C's so I needed a TB hub to get my old USB hub to play on the M4. The move forced me to sort out my iLok strategy between my mastering rig and my production rig because it was quite messy (I ended up getting a 2nd iLok for the M4 to make things way easier between it and the laptop). It was just a lot of little stuff for me. If you're not changing machine form factors and it's mostly a software exercise, then it might be worth it.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: I only have 1 monitor, keyboard and mouse, so I spent a lot of time Parsec'ing from my laptop into either of the minis while the other one was on my keyboard, mouse and monitor. I had to make wallpapers with the computer names on them so I could tell them apart because I was getting confused what machine I was on.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Haha the different wallpapers is a great idea

Maybe folks can chime in on the security risk here, but I started a spreadsheet on my last reinstall with my various plugin logins, serials, and download links to speed things up next time round. I’ve been adding any new plugs to the sheet since then.

Also includes a price column with annual totals to horrify myself out of buying anything non-essential.

question: Hi! New here, thanks a lot for all the really great advice! I have a question. I seem to never be able to take breaks when I mix. I think it is because I mix from anxiety or something like that. It often times ends with me not making great decisions level-wise because I get fatigued. Any pointers? What works for you work-flow wise for mixing a track?

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: force yourself to get up and walk away

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: do something else - make a coffee, eat something, go on a short walk, whatever

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: anything to take your mind off what you're working on and give your ears a break

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: ear fatigue is as much psychological as it is physical

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Use an app to set a disruptive reminder or to start the screensaver on your computer automatically. Something that will hold you accountable without you having to think about.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
If you can go outside and take a walk, do it. 

Blood flow increases brain activity. Thus increasing creativity and problem solving.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
If you follow the typical computer break adage, it’s like 45 minutes in front of computer, then a 15 minute break.

Might be more like 50 min/10 min actually.*

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: But I usually go until I reach a logical stopping point or if I’m really making bad decisions, bail.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Ironically, taking more breaks makes you more productive.

question:
__**TLDR 2 - the return**__ - The final word. If I was asked “What sample rate should people make records at in 2022?” And was forced to choose then the answer would be 48k. Why?

- Film and TV prefer it
- Labels prefer it
- *(I hate Atmos)* Atmos is at 48k *(I hate Atmos)*
- There are small but meaningful technical and sonic advantages
- It doesn’t place demands on CPU or drive space

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: @Slow Hand I'm new to discord and not sure how to make this look good, particularly line spacing etc. Please edit at will or let me know how to improve

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content:
I agree, 48k is probably my default choice. 

I'd argue that it gets the AA filter far enough into ultrasonic territory as to not matter, though, and if a plugin is *designed properly* (big if, there... not many get this totally 100% right) aliasing should not be an issue.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: I don't consider it a good idea to work above 96 though, as you'll start introducing junk from switching power supplies, class D amps, noise shaping from D/A and A/D, etc into the program material. At lower sample rates it's effectively rolled out by extremely steep AA filters

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Thinking once I make the jump to Apple silicon I may go back to 96, but I’m 48 all day these days. At the ol’ staff gig we had virtually endless hd space and so much outboard that we did everything 96 and didn’t think twice.

expert_answers.content: You and I could go hard here on the geek stuff, but I'm gonna hold off in this forum so we can answer more newbie questions

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: I think we're largely in agreement though, higher is better to a point

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Anyway: just work at 48, and stop asking me to change the clock to 44.1 because I know you'll forget to change it back after and the next person will be all confused why their session sounds wrong

question:
Oh yeah, for sure. It’s easy to overdo it, and satisfying enough that sometimes you don’t know in the moment.

Ultimately you can be 100% in the right speaker or 100% in the left speaker, and pushing beyond that is tempting the gods. As far as I can conceive it, any process that attempts to widen a signal that’s already entirely decorrelated must have the potential to reintroduce some correlation. Thinking again of the ping pong delay, is there really anything wider than that?

I was doing a lot of M/S mix buss widening stuff a few years ago, and I realized that it could do some pretty weird shit to panned vocals and the like. While it feels like you can just ‘turn up the sides’, you’re really doing something unnatural to the center, too, and the relationship between channels. Like you’re choosing select bits of a sound to turn up, but only the bits of that sound that don’t have anything in common with the other speaker. This is a lot of rambling just to say that there’s clearly a point of diminishing returns, and maybe the solution is to pan something else less wide to create contrast.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: Ultimately i'll probably just be going on a "widener" hunt, and find some secret sauce that no one else uses just to i can brag about it. No more doubler2, microshift, Juno/boss chorus, metaflanger, H3000, H-delay, HaasEffect, übermod)

question:
Turn off the click, press play, do some pushups. How does it feel? 

You didnt notice when you were playing probably cause it felt just fine. A click consistent to itself (despite not being consistent with another daw) is likely going to feel just fine. 

Kick being on and snare being ahead can feel great, kick being ahead and snare being on can feel great, kick & snr being on and hats being ahead can feel great… deep breath, go find the joy. Music is magic, DAWs are just tools. Dont let it steal the fun; this IS the fun part.

question: Here ya go guys. Hope it worked. Took me forever to zip the damn thing. WHoever wants to see ol' Boozle's drums, even if you're not tagged, have at it. And sorry to tag if you didn't want to be. Just thought I'd ping everyone who kinda got involved. No pressure. Please let me know if you have any questions... @Josh Bowman @cian riordan @Zack Hames @Bryan DiMaio @Edward Rivera https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Ebm6jlSvqagp1feooJ2y03jAJCASp7Xf/view?usp=drive_link

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Awesome. Will try and have a listen over the weekend!

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
So! @BoozleBAM! I took a gander and you’re in pretty good shape! I think you’re going to hit some sonic limitations with the quality of your signal path and the cymbals you are using, but the drums sound pretty good and the space you’re in isn’t terrible. Some notes:
- Your cymbal mic'ing approach might be a little overly comprehensive. Its nice to have spot mics on each cymbal, but might be worth trying a more traditional overhead approach. It’ll help get a more natural image of the kit and will likely free up some microphones for other spot positions on the drum set or in the room.
- Your kick drum sounds like a basketball. Theres a few things you can do with tuning, but I would firsttry having some dampening inside. If you like them sounding wide open, then consider taping some felt or paper towels to the inside of the drum shell, at least half way around the interior circumference of the shell. It’ll help quash that bouncing basketball sound.
- Your snare sounds beefy! Obviously, its going to be song and arrangement dependent, but on its own it sounds like you could voice it a little higher to get it to crack a little more.
- If you free up some mics by simplifying your cymbal setup, consider having a mic at the ‘crotch’ position… picking up the center of the kit. It can be useful for anchoring the mono signal of the drums and gives you something nice to potentially squash or distort down the road.
- Your room mics sound pretty good with the right EQing!

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Some specific EQ notes:

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
Kick EQ:
- Mostly just scooping out the boxy low mids. Adding low end and a hair of high end. That ~800hz move is to pull out the ‘boing’ inherent in the sound.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
Snare EQ:
- Just taming a bothersome resonance and adding in a little snap.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
Cymbals:
- These were honestly the toughest part of the sound. I ended up bussing all your cymbal mics and treating them as a set. I found myself hunting for a place to pull back the high-mid harshness but introduce some of the airy sizzle. The tape machine plugin I used helped a bit with this (Studer A800 with the HF calibration dialed up a bit)
- Also these were the only mics that needed the phase to be flipped! Everything else added up nicely.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
Rooms:
- Just pulling the muck out. There was some cool, usable low end in there once I scooped out the bad stuff.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
Whole kit
- I found afterwards that I might have gone a little too overzealous in pulling out high mids, so put a little bit back in and notched out the harshest elements. The low end moves were just finessing I felt needed after having everything focus.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: And Wetransfer didn't work for me. And, yes... I know it's a "me" thing.

question: @Slow Hand cool, so he wants a separate mix for his live performance where his verse vocals are turned down , i wanted to know if theres anything else i can do to the song?

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Gotcha. If that's all they're asking for, then I wouldn't do much else without letting them know, cause they'll likely be sensitive to any changes.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: One question I would consider, though, is whether or not to bypass any master limiting for the live version of the track. If the mix is such that you're taking off a lot of transients on the master buss, it may sound better to ease off the limiter or bypass it entirely so that the live sound engineer will have plenty of headroom to work with and isn't trying to mix around a track that's massively limited. Having that extra headroom and transient energy could be a benefit, thought you'll have to use your ears to make that judgement, and definitely talk to the artist.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: It could be that the limiter is what's gluing the entire mix together and without it the track loses a certain feel. In such a case, you probably would not want to do that, if the limiter is holding it together.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: If anyone else here wants to chime in on whether or not to ease off the limiter for a live track, I'd love to get someone else's perspective on the matter.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: When I've done it, I've left the limiter on so that everything coming out of the Live set is a known quantity and level can be dealt with on the analog side. Done for level and practical reasons, not tonal.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Yeah. I'm used to having more control as an MD for artists and not handing it off to another party and having it out of my hands. An important aspect of these live performance mixes would be consistency of level between them all. Don't send the artist out with one track that's super loud and another that's considerably quieter. Like @Rollmottle says, you want the live tracks to be predictable and consistent and whoever is handling the tracks should ensure that they're level-matched relative to each other. You want to do your best to ensure that the live tracks are all reaching the live engineer at a consistent and unwavering level, so that they aren't getting any curveballs from the person running the tracks.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: So whatever you and the artist decide, do your best to make the live tracks you print have a consistent level. You can't control the mixes they get from others, so you'll need to talk to the artist and see what they're already using.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: In my case, it's been a club setting and the tracks need to be jamming so I applied a bunch of processing across the 2-bus to achieve a consistent "mastering" level...especially when the source is a mix of mastered tracks and non-mastered tracks, you gotta level match what's going into the 2-bus and then make sure everything coming out is generally at the same level without crushing everything.

community_answers.author: mixedbyKerim
community_answers.content: @Slow Hand  got it bro💪🏻 if it sounds good leave it, obviously first time doing something like this , sheesh last thing i was thinking of was the limiter , good stuff

community_answers.author: mixedbyKerim
community_answers.content: Its a bar/lounge setting , couple artists are going live,

question:
Anyone have tips for recording drums without reso heads? Going for Thuddy, dry, drum machine -ish but then I could throw a reverb on them and make them uber 80s. 

I’m at the studio so sky is somewhat the limit - I’ve got vistalite kit with ambassadors and a PS3 coated kick, few snare drum options.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: yeah mic the toms from inside

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: that's how people did it in the 70s anyway

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: My tips would be that you only have one head to tune, so make it good! Honestly one of my favorite Tom sounds— vistalites with coated heads. I would use either moon gels or paper towels with gaff tape to temper the resonance and really get a good balanced attack and let the decay come from the room. Keep the cymbals as far away as possible and mic with a solid LDC… 414 or 87ish

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I never enjoyed the inside Tom mic sound personally, so 45 degree angle about 3-6 inches off. Again, cymbal bleed management is the game

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: gotta agree, I think it doesn't sound great

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Thanks for the tips! 414s have been kicking ass on toms for me,  about a fist away. For the session we ended up using bottom heads, everything sounded really nice though. I used a rolled up bandana on about 20% of the snare, tuned pretty low, all came together really nicely.

question:
I’m not sure if this is a newbie question or not, but I’ll throw it here anyways and see what happens (I hope it helps newbies too). I’m already somewhat aware of the answers I may get, but who knows. Sorry if this is long, I’m bad at short form.

Context: I have been producing music in sincerity for maybe 3 years now, been a hobby since like 16. I’ve started to engineer out of necessity for my individual artistry, but one thing led to the next and I gained a fair bit of skill at it (or so I’ve been told, I’m still pretty insecure, honestly even being around all the really knowledge people on here makes my panic disorder go 📈). I’ve gotten an internship at a studio as a runner and a session assistant down here (it’s not paid but it’s not exactly unpaid), and I truly have learned a lot (I learn something new on the daily I swear), but I’ve yet to have any true guidance from an established figure yet (which very well may never happen), which I know isn’t necessary, but it absolutely makes me question my own abilities/career decisions despite what happens with my freelance work and I’m curious to know if this is like normal/how other people cope. 

Like, I’ve gotten a somewhat okay share of people who pay for my work as an engineer/producer/writer, but the “do you really know what you’re doing” doubt doesn’t fade easily—even when I’ve been paid by people on like label level budgets, I’m never really registering that success. I’ve had cool moments and landed spotify placements as a mixer for artists, and there’s this part of me that’s still somewhat ashamed that I do a lot more work for free than I care to admit. 

Maybe it’s the comments on the old episodes that has me spooked (Jon on #61 re: “not everyone can be a mixer”), but is this like just me or do even some of the really wicked smart people here still feel that—and if so, how do you guys handle the it?

expert_answers.author: ehutton21
expert_answers.content: sorry for the word wall, would love some input here, especially from anyone less green than me. i’ve listened to most of the episodes a few times and i know a few talked about this, but just wanted to take inventory.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
Let me begin by saying that your feelings and experiences are more common than you may realize. It's alright to feel that way. Though I don't believe it's constructive to dwell on them.

It's not unusual to feel inferior when surrounded by people who are more experienced and talented than you. We've all felt this. The thing is this; you are in exactly the right place and will only benefit from engaging with this environment. Being surrounded by so many professionals and people with experience is absolutely a benefit to your development and someday you'll look back at how far you've come and be amazed by how fluent you are.

Let me drive this point home just a little more: When you were young and learning your native language, nobody put you in a room and expected you to learn the language by conversing with a bunch of inexperienced two year-olds who couldn't speak. Instead, you were surrounded by expert speakers and learned through interactions with people who were leagues ahead of you in their ability to speak the language. Learning to speak is not an easy task, but by immersing yourself in a community of experts you are on the path to mastery and in no time you'll reap the benefits of that exposure.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
If your position as a studio runner is paying dividends and you can sustain the lifestyle and afford to go without compensation then continue down that path. It sounds like you're in a position where people may not be giving you the time of day. At this point what a potential mentor figure will be seeking from you is an assurance that you are committed to the path and that their effort will not be wasted on someone who is not committed. 

Considering your position, right now I would recommend adopting an attitude of A) respectful persistence when asking others for insight and help B) private study and a self-starting attitude to make things happen for yourself without their assistance C) actively seeking opportunities to assist, contribute, and be of help to others and D) building your own network of creative collaborators with whom you can continue to create and experiment together.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
The fact that you're already being paid for your work is a great indicator. Just keep going and developing your existing relationships.

That feeling of "I don't really know what I'm doing" is normal. It happens to most of us. And that's okay. I think you'll be surprised when you someday realize that a tremendous amount of people have no idea what they're doing; even those who seem in control. You do your best in the moment and then build on what you've learned and you do it even better the next time.

Don't be afraid of failure. The most courageous thing that you can do is to put yourself in a situation where you feel vulnerable. You will fail and you will fail again, and finally you will succeed. Then you will find yourself in a situation where you get to fail at bigger, better things. That's the process of self-actualization.

You should repeatedly strive to put yourself in a position that puts you at the edge of your abilities. That very feeling of being uncomfortable is a sign that you're in the right place. Challenge yourself and go for it. Pushing yourself in this way is the path to growth and achievement.

You're doing great.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: A. B. C. D. Incredible insight and advice IME.

expert_answers.author: ehutton21
expert_answers.content: there’s so much to respond too but (1) thank you and (2) truly that meant a lot. I’ve started and been adamant about trying to do C & D, and B was i think how i even got into this place in the beginning. A is the one i probably struggle with most—i tend to be pretty shy about asking for respected people’s feedback or even trying to get people to hear what i’ve done. i feel like that needs to change but i don’t know how to do that without feeling like a bother or being attention seeking. ive been here before so i know the path forward in some ways, i guess i’d thought the mental doubt would get better the more i achieve and it’s weird to feel such a struggle

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: So much good advice here, but I’ll just add: no one gives you a plaque that says “you’re a producer” or “you’re an artist”. You are because you do. Just keep doing, keep trying to find any avenue to push you’re knowledge/experience/discography forward. Every record you make you’ll learn something new AND you’re already getting paid for your work (win). Spoiler alert: You’ll NEVER feel like you REALLY know what you’re doing. If you do, you’ve lost (I know this must sound odd coming from someone who @cian riordan  thinks is so knowledgeable and brilliant) Satisfaction breeds mediocrity. Music is far too vast for anyone to fully understand    everything in their lifetime. Bake that into the equation as you try to figure out how you feel about where you’re at.

expert_answers.author: ehutton21
expert_answers.content:
it means a lot that you chimed in, and honestly i had never thought of it that way. i think it’s easy to perceive a sense of superiority in others in a space  where we all work so hard to convince people that there’s nothing we don’t know. 
again, sorry if i hijacked the intro questions channel (i figured i may not be the only one who has or will be in this position). but genuinely, thanks a bunch to everyone engaging. you’ve got no idea how much it’s helped.

question: i'm running a lightning to jack adapter into inputs 3+4 on my Apollo x6, so people can connect their phones and show whatever music they want. Should i leave it at +4dbu or change it to -10dbV?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: As long as you’re not clipping it’s good either way.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: -10dB tends to be unbalanced, prob best to just leave at +4dbu

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Long story short - leave at +4.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: One sec boys, balanced or not has nothing to do with reference levels and where your inputs will clip

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Spend the time to do this right once

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content:
1) Turn off your speakers
2) Download an app with a signal generator that lets you out output a 1kHz sine wave tone
3) Set the app output volume to 0dB (maxed)
4) Set the phone output to max

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: 5) Now you are outputting the maximum possible analog level from your lightning to 3.5mm converter (it’s a tiny DAC)

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: 6) Check Apollo input for clipping, and choose either +4 or -10 on that basis

question:
Probably hugely in the framing of it though? That’s the skill

Can see the same request making a client insecure, and another wording making it feel like you really care about the record

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Sure! And like any engineer, they might have blind spots in the client relations department (we’ve all been there and learned the compromises)… but like, it’s a technical job… end of the line. Guys either punching up his own ego or he’s just looking out for the best end results, regardless of the clients feelings. Not always the best for business, but I certainly don’t question the intentions. I wish more people would speak up.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: I’m with Cian on this. Be curious, and don’t take it personally. But know your own mind, or choose who you trust and then actually trust them.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I was saying those were generally Noah’s priorities as he approaches music - so he was a good sounding board to help AJ through this before he gets too many opinions

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Not descriptions of mastering guy or our priorities

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I should say that I’m allergic to this approach to mastering, and can super easily get on my high horse about it but it’s the right approach for certain clients. They’re likely not my clients and -6 guy would lose his shit dealing with HEALTH or Dorian or the new Carly record

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: So he/she likely has a client base that appreciates this approach and I have mine. It’s about a match

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: What I perceive as fussiness and fearfulness can be perceived by certain clients as care

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: And its the MEs job to know where those decisions are getting made. And if its a rockstar mixer sending a file very intentionally loud vs. a newer-to-intermediate mixer unsure of their footing... it should elicit a different response.

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack

question:
@cian riordan @Adam Thein @Eric Martin thanks for the fantastic responses. This all makes sense. 

The monitoring the repro-head and recording back to digital all in one step note: This is what I am curious about. There's an Otari MX5050 at the studio that I want to mess around with and we have tons of tapes around the studio i'm sure i could use. 

SO, Can you sort of passively have the tape machine going without having to operate it actively and just use pro tools, all while getting the tape sound? Like a hardware insert or simply bringing it in and monitoring? 

I didn't grow up with Tape, but I want to explore the sounds because so many of my fav sounding records used tape. Many also DIDN'T, but I feel like i've got to figure this out for myself.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Yes - set it to record and you’ve got about 25 minutes to just work before you need to rewind.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: That's awesome! so you're not even actually recording onto the tape, just monitoring the repro head while it runs. It didn't seem like it could be that simple but it clearly is. that's dope!

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Keep in mind there is a pretty significant delay from monitoring repro head so unless you are mixing the whole track through it whatever you run to it will be out of time with whatever is not running to it unless you set your delay compensation up accordingly

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: It’s recording to the tape, then you are listening to the repro head a few ms down stream off the tape

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Ah okay, so you just rewind and it records over what was there for the 25 min or so at 15ips.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: basically every so often you have to rewind and press record+play again

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: If it’s the mk4 you might be able to set up an automatic loop so it’ll rewind for you automatically and restart

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: But my mk3 can only have one memory location and no looping on the transport

expert_answers.author: Gerhard Westphalen
expert_answers.content: REW. Plugin doctor is useful for seeing things "live" but I find it to be very buggy and you don't get the same resolution as REW. REW will give you the frequency response (down to something like 0.001 dB) plus harmonic distortion

expert_answers.author: Gerhard Westphalen

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Nothing particularly relevant for most people’s situation. But I have a number of standard DB25’s feeding an analogue loop and another sending digital signal, all using some gender switching cables or adapters to get them to work where I need them. I wouldn’t let DB25 be the deciding factor of going one way or another, but if you do, plan ahead and get ready to pay.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: Your gonna pay either way when integrating a patch bay or loop switcher, effectively doubles the cables a lot of the time

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: DB25's are an order of magnitude more difficult to DIY than XLR's so in many cases it makes more sense to just buy DB25's and save onseself the time and headache. The same argument can be made for XLR's too but I'd say it's a more worthwhile pursuit for most engineers to know how to wire XLR's up. As always, time is money so one must weigh the trade offs.

expert_answers.author: Jonathan Jetter
expert_answers.content: Yeah. I tried to solder some DB25s once. 7 years later I've still only ever tried that one time.

expert_answers.author: Jonathan Jetter
expert_answers.content: Totally happy to go to my grave never trying again.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Wouldn’t wish it on my worst enemy

question: Do you have izotope eq ? There’s a setting in the preferences that says something like “show all curves “ click on it and it adds a time display into the graphic on the gui

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: You can then go into the little sidebar on the tab for each eq point and you ll see a slider that allows you to move the eq point from linear to minimum phase

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: It will also show you simultaneously on the time graphic what part of the signal is being delayed (or not )

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: It’s an interesting tool to be able to slide between eq types and not have to switch them as in FabFilter .

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content:
I also use SSL’s X phase a lot , as much to investigate how many different ways one can adjust phase on a source and to listen to the interplay between sounds . I’ll usually always employ it on low end elements at the moment , just as much as an educational tool as anything . You can do much much more than flip the phase 

And finally phase rotators . I got really into these . RX has one . And the manufacture who make that teote plug in make one and Maat I believe .

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: I ve used them all to just really investigate

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Another one is to take a sine wave at 100 hz and put in a high pass filter and start moving it around and look at the consequent response post filter on the sine wave

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Re Jons point that you referred to , I can remember watching that one but I don’t remember the wording

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: I recall it as him pointing out that although we look at the Hz number on an eq we should be aware that it may have a pronounced effect on our perception of an area of audio elsewhere . I’ve heard this described as the yin yang effect . So if on the master I feel it’s too bright , I could choose to work in the low end with boosts in a certain place   As much as cuts in the high end , in order to affect that perception of brightness

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: Producing/recording my first rock track & would love any tips on getting the drums right! I know Cian already crushed a LFTWR tutorial in here I should revisit that discusses parallel saturation n such. We tracked today, got 441s on kick and snare top, sm7b’s on snare bottom and hat, LCR overheads with my 251 in center and some flat pencils L/R, M201 on each tom, some random Omni EV mic on crotch and a stereo ribbon in the room (r88 clone). Room is rather dead but it’s 600 sq feet so we still get some life out of it when rocking. Refs are like anything Steve Albini has touched, as well as that latest Bully record. I’m mostly working on soft pop Americana type stuff so this is a very fun new adventure. So far really digging slamming the left right overheads with saturn2 transformer, may sample replace kick and snare but just with samples we took at the end. Any tips on making that shit slap in a crunchy modern way would be appreciated ❤️

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Try:
-compression on drum bus first before individual mics. I find compressing rooms on their own makes them sound small not big

-time delay rooms to make the room seem larger. This is a big albini trick 

-don’t be afraid to EQ the shit out of kick drum mics 

-don’t be afraid to add a lot of low end to the snare 

-transient designers on close mics can make shit punchy

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: -Destroy the crotch mic with decapitator and blend

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: You can Key the kick or snare tracks to a gate on the room mics to get more emphasis on the shells vs the cymbals. Sometimes this can help avoid washy crappy room sound. R88 is one of my favs for rooms tho

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Also…compromise perfect fidelity for energy/emotion/intensity. I’ve been leaning on that a lot lately with success. Maybe there’s a little too much high mid. But when you remove it, it’s lifeless. Try to find that balance of aggressive and rockin’ but easy to listen to

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Also, if the music is supposed to be listened to loud….do some EQ moves with the speakers up a bit. I find EQ moves translate better when I mix with some decent volume. Mixing quiet makes everything so out of balance for me especially low end and high end

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: thank you @Zack Hames !!!

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: i regret to inform you that i'm not in fact a drummer haha but a very big fan of working with drummers FWIW. will be DMing at some point, tysm

community_answers.content: If you have any specific questions don't hesitate to DM me or ask here I don't mind. Always happy to help fellow drummers! question: I can’t remember; is your ultimate goal to be able to fully independently make your own music or are you wanting to record and mix for other clients?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Obviously you can do both.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: @BoozleBAM I bet you’d learn more about mixing by hiring someone pro to do 1 of yours songs than spending a year trying to do it on your own.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Think to Cian’s quick drum mix.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content:
To paraphrase @Nomograph Mastering: When your ambition/expectations outweigh your ability, hire it out until your ability match or exceed tour expectations.

Mixing can take years worth of reps to get good at, it’s better to hire someone and release something you’re proud of while you learn how to do it yourself.

-OR-

release the things so that you can truly understand where your current ability is, hindsight is the best scale for quality

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Last tidbit:

you’ll write more songs. If you’re so nervous about these being the be all end all, you’re gonna have a short creative lifespan.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Not to be a hardass. This all said with love.

question: What is the drummer listening to in his headphones when tracking drums first? just a click? click + demo?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Ideally, the rest of their band playing along with them. Second best is fleshed out pre-production demo with everything in time.

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Scratch vocals, scratch guitar, bass etc

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Or have guitar and bass track with them etc

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: If everyones ready and you have the inputs, record!

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Heavy on the if everyone is ready

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: There is some serious vibe from having the whole band playing together

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
More often than not it seems the main songwriter demos the song. Maybe a drum loop, maybe some programmed drums. Plays guitar and/or keys and sings.

Drummer then plays along to the in time demo. This will be the keeper drums. 

Band instruments then re-played, layered on top of the keeper drums. 

Then vocals. 

Then whatever little extra schmutz you want to add. 

Then you clear some space on the wall for the inevitable awards and plaques.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: This is my experience

community_answers.author: SawyerM
community_answers.content: At very least vocals + click

question: What does single core vs multicore mean in terms of using DAWs?

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: The value of future proofing is also tied to the ticking clock of the  trade in value decreasing with each new line. I mean I bought this thing two years ago and we’re already three versions past it. Never ending lol

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: I've been in the throes of moving my production rig from an M1 mini to an M4 mini over the past couple of weeks. Definitely do not underestimate the time sink of standing up a new rig that is as tuned and ready to go as your current one. Takes some time to make sure you get the new one cooking as good the old one. It's just work, but a pain in the ass. and a pretty unsolved user experience problem.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Single core is helpful for audio tasks (think snappy and responsive, good low latency performance) and multi core is more helpful as the session gets larger.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: I’d say hold off for now if you’re already on M2 Max

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: Copy that. My shit is generally bitchin

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content:
Just taking the time to figure out the right changeover strategy and timing so that I could actually make the move once I basically had two fully functioning rigs stood up in parallel. My additional complicating factor is having a laptop that is a dupe of the studio rig, so keeping it all straight and everything in sync is a bit of a puzzle. 

I took the transition as the opportunity to phase out some mechanical drives so I had to get some new drives for the M4 instead of re-using the old Time Machine mechanical drive. The M4 mini only has Thunderbolt/USB C ports -- the M1 has USB A's and Thunderbolt/USB C's so I needed a TB hub to get my old USB hub to play on the M4. The move forced me to sort out my iLok strategy between my mastering rig and my production rig because it was quite messy (I ended up getting a 2nd iLok for the M4 to make things way easier between it and the laptop). It was just a lot of little stuff for me. If you're not changing machine form factors and it's mostly a software exercise, then it might be worth it.

I had to make wallpapers with the computer names on them so I could tell them apart because I was getting confused what machine I was on.

question:
I send tracks to drummers or string players or vocalists etc allll the time. I want them recording at a healthy level, something that fits with everything I’ve recorded & mixed. If I’ve done my job on the mix end, it’s already sounding great. 
Think of it like this- how would it be if he/she/they were in the room tracking with you? 

Also- it’s not hard at all to just send both. “Here’s what it’ll sound like with the limiter on, here’s one to track to.”

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
Haha just relaying my experience. If you're sending to a mastering engineer it's a whole different conversation.

Always think about what you're trying to accomplish at any given stage. Then go after that goal. 

I used to spend too much time on sonics in writing sessions. I should have been solely focused on finding emotional magic. Now  I am just trying to inspire the artists and writers around me, I'll deal with the sonics later. Much better results.

I also used to fully mix-as-I-go, which painted me into a corner with gain staging and eq. Now when I get to the end of the process, I often pull things back and rebuild my levels so there's headroom and I can make that exciting production translate.

Different approaches for different parts of the process.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
No, definitely don’t. Please. For the love of God. Don’t. 

Master bus processing to this day still suffers from poor delay compensation, across a variety of daws. You’ll be sending him a 2 track that does not line up with your session, and the ensuing vocal you get back will not line up with what you’ve recorded. Pocket will be off. 

This has been THE SINGLE biggest nightmare in my career as a vocal producer. Please. If at all possible, leave the master off. 

(Unless you do the square wave trick at the end that will allow him to precisely align the files)

question:
Are you looking for resources on writing/production, or mixing? Just like with the record side, there's so much noise from bedroom composers and people that have zero real-world experience. And as Ruairi is always saying, even the people with real success often can't teach what they know. Maybe I'm a bit cranky after an 8 hour delay at the airport yesterday, but Spitfire has gotten quite good at creating "tutorial" videos that are thinly veiled advertisements, and many of their libraries are the equivalent of one-knob plugins or CLA vocals. Selling paint-by-numbers solutions to naïve kids who want to get into scoring (They're far from the only ones guilty of this). But to focus on some of the channels I think are actually worth their salt:

8-Bit Music Theory: https://www.youtube.com/@8bitMusicTheory/videos
Can be a bit basic at times, but he talks a lot about structure which, IMO, is becoming a lost art in modern scoring.

Anne-Kathrin Dern: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWJg1w7F3PKPbSpEF2YOejVjWAg-KcM3Z
Not the biggest name out there, but she has a no-bullshit way of explaining things about orchestration and theory that is clear and concise. As far as "teachers," I think she's a good one.

Alan Meyerson Waves Sessions: https://youtu.be/h9jZqn5lnw4
I hesitate to include this. I know for a fact that Alan swapped out a bunch of his go-to plugins to make everything a Waves product. I haven't watched this in awhile, but it's a good insight into how he sets up a big mix session and why he makes some of his decisions. He's also playing to the camera/audience some, so this is a your-mileage-may-vary recommendation.

McGowen Soundworks: https://www.youtube.com/@McGowanSoundworks/featured
Phil knows his shit, and goes pretty deep breaking down a few actual mixes, which is pretty rare to find.

If I think of others, I'll report back. Hope that helps

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content:
That’s super, thank you!

Looking for all of the above - prod, eng, mix stuff I can to a decent extent verify myself, but I’m relatively green in the composition world so it’s great to hear your take on it.

expert_answers.content: Banger. Considering investing in a MWTM membership. I don’t know either of their work (at least I don’t think I do), but sounds like a great series, and two more people to add to my listening list.
