question: How do you approach compression on Electric Bass? How you think about Attack and release for bass, compressor choices, etc. I feel like I’m always trying random things for every mix and haven’t found anything particularly amazing.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: I've never used the hardware, but I love the UA LA-2A on bass. You can really lay into the thing especially fucking with the emphasis to find the right tonal balance vs. limiting

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Annoying answer, but, it depends. (Ha! Stock answer for almost everything.) If the performance is uneven and really needs to be smoothed out, I might go for an 1176 at like 8:1 and catch loud parts. Then I might do a parallel comp (dbx 160, often), for more sustain and maybe snappiness. If certain notes are really poking out against others, as is often the case, I’ll ruthlessly eq them so they are balanced with Pro-Q3, instead of trying to solve that with more compression.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: First I'll think about what the tonal impact will be. There are particular compressors that automatically suck low or high end out of the signal... and for something like bass that can occupy a very crucial part of the low end, that could prove problematic. Usually if I'm compressing bass, it's to bring out the sustain of the low end. So I'll typically set the release & the makeup gain first first to a place where I like how the low end is holding out, then dial in the attack to taste (usually on the medium-to-slow side). Grabby compression on bass can be fun in very specific instances, but I often find it distracting and fatiguing.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Badass. This is wicked helpful. Thanks @peterlabberton and @cian riordan !

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I’ve not used the UAD, I’ll have to check it out. Studio that just became available to me has a hardware one so I may go to town - Thanks!

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Oh, echoing @cian riordan , the release feels especially important to me on bass gtr. I feel like it’s one of the few instances where I would regularly go with a longer release (I’m usually a big fast release dude). This would be if the bass is doing mostly whole notes, to get it to fill more of the measure. If I’m being specific about attack time... I’m usually (like almost always) getting the punch totally from the kick, so a faster attack usually feels pretty good to me, at least for the compressor not in parallel. And yes to the tonal change—I feel like usually I end up wanting to cut low end and add some kind of aggression, so compressors that go in that direction work well for me.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Also I really never have a kick out that far off

community_answers.author: jonmatteson
community_answers.content: I’ve been using the faraday limiter lately on bass and have been really happy with the results! The tone controls on it are very useful for adding as much or as little color as you like.

question:
How can I get better low end from my kick drum? 

My usual setup is a D112 right outside the hole pointing at the batter, then either a tube condenser or rn a Warm Audio 47 fet, a few feet away pointing at the kick, low passed at 50-100hz and delayed maybe 150-300ms to get the low end nice and full and make some sort of phasing miracle happen. 

I am so close to getting the sound I want, it just sounds a little less thick and a little less rock solid than what I am chasing. What am I missing? What can I try?

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Also I really never have a kick out that far off

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: This is my version of a sub kick. Basically the idea is to have the low end happen a little later than the attack, intentionally. I’ve used sub kicks and they’re just okay for me, but maybe I don’t know the best way with them. I’ve played with the distance quite a bit, sometimes it’s a couple feet from the center, sometimes it’s exactly even with the dynamic mic.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: These are good suggestions, especially about the drummer’s playing.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: I’d echo what’s been said but I’d also add that you should play with the tuning of the batter and reso head to get the sound, you might be surprised to hear that tighter might actually deliver more low tone and overtone to the mic than the puff of air that a too loose head will deliver, I’d also mess with the dampening material, start with less dampening and only dampen what it needs to tame the basketball ping if you get that tone. And let the beater rebound don’t bury the beater, imagine the kick drum is a guitar string and burying the beater is like playing with a piece of foam killing the resonance. play with all these things and you’ll get more low end

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: @Zack Hames I’d also add to the above to not be afraid to just go for it with an eq. Bus all the kick tracks together, and use a high pass with a high q and boost until it hits right. Depending on the drum/recording and how you want it to hit in the mix, I often find a good spot between about 60 and 80 hz that has good weight and punch, and just boost by adjusting the q to taste.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Also... I think I’d try your FET closer to the head, and then if you want to try delaying it a touch, trying it from there, OR throwing another mic up a few feet away for that option

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Great advice. I know I’ll need some mixing to get there I’ll try the FET closer to maybe make it “punchier” low end. Thanks man!

community_answers.author: jonmatteson
community_answers.content: Try moving the kick out 4-6 inches from the kick and get them in phase on the way in. This can help the low end “bloom” nicely and give you a really full sound. As always though, the source/drummer has a lot to do with the sound. Make sure the drummer isn’t burying the beater as you will get a lot less low end if they are!

question: Mixing is another story if you’re on a console… but who doesn’t that anymore?!

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I just downloaded the “snapshot” plugin today to do recalls for the MPEQ-1, otherwise I just use the comments section in PT to document what gear was used if I want to remember. Usually what guitar, amp, mic, or other important particulars, or what drum/mic or something.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: for tracking guitar this last year, I literally only ever used my HXStomp, and I saved each preset every time, which was convenient when I was asked to re-track something

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: i think those apps for recalls are a lot of solution for a minor problem. my method is pretty guerilla. i master, so it's a bit different, but i like how simple this is and how little mental overhead there is. i have a white board slate i write the artist, track name and version on. then i snap a pic of it followed by all my gear.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: etc..etc. then i take those pix off my phone and drop them in the project folder. they're in order by date/time so when i drop em in a folder, they're all in the right order.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: i've tried google docs, google sheets, graphical recall sheets, etc. it's just too much for my brain. i do this while i'm cutting the master and once the capture is done, i can move on to the next one with zero fuss.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: at the end of the day, i would say try not to be too precious about it. get something for "safety" that will get you back in the ballpark, make it easy to manage, but don't sweat too much over it.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Agree with @Rollmottle even for mix recall. I’ve made custom recall documents and then meticulously filled them out for racks of gear and 64 channels of an analog console as a staff engineer. But taking a photo (or panorama on iPhone) is so so much better. 😵

question:
Question:

I frequently find that in writing sessions artists want to start tracking their vocal/piano/guitar ideas as soon as they start having them, often before drum grooves are figured out. In my experience laying down drums last in a production usually turns out to be a total mess with various grooves often not quite locking. 

How do y’all handle the quick flow of the early stages of these productions? Am I in the wrong state of mind by trying to get things right early on? Do you end up retracking a lot later? Do y’all not have this problem because y’all just have impeccable rhythm?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: If there’s going to be drums in the final, I always put a scratch drum track. No exceptions. Either with my korg drum machine or midi in daw with Steven slate drums or Battery. Luckily almost no one complains  because it’s 100x better than playing to a fucking click!

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: This is a huge part of my workflow. If people record themselves at home with a collab, I’ll insist they send me a demo that I can make a rhythm track for real quick that I’ll build just for them to record themselves to

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: To answer the flow question: it just needs to be made quickly. 5 minutes or so. Doesn’t need to be crazy, just needs to fit the song and be easy to play to.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
I usually get a backbeat or 4 on the floor going, even if it's subtle. But I've had a lot of great songs written to just that, then drums are built around it later. tbh if you have that and you're having trouble getting drums to work later, it's usually not because you didn't get proper drums in there. If the song is great and there's a basic beat, you're pretty much set. a simple backbeat goes a long way.

As I've said before, I think the two essential parts of a song are not actually piano/vocal or guitar/vocal but instead beat/vocal. chords are obviously important, usually. But melody against rhythm is primarily what people move to and remember. if you can sing and clap it, you've probably got something.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: the melody implies rhythm, if it doesn’t, that’s the problem IMO.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: the best songs IMO, can be sung, full stop. Then while you’re singing, you feel the pull of the rhythm of the song is really strong.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: yes sung or rapped. but the vast majority of songs from 1950 until now have a backbeat or some other basic 4/4 rhythmic element that completes the polyrhythm. these rhythms act as an anchor for the melody. so to answer the original question, ive found it super valuable to have something like that in there when writing. especially if what the OP is asking is how to find solutions for programming drums later.

community_answers.author: kidcutler

community_answers.author: Rob Domos
community_answers.content:
My general issue isn’t usually with finding the pattern. That’s often pretty easy for me. I think the issue  comes with rhythmic feel. Like I end up with slight flams between the drums and the previously recorded material because of slightly disagreeing swings. It happens because a lot of times I steal the groove from loops and I really struggle with trying to program something with great time feel after the fact without the crutch of a groove pool, and a lot of times the performer will have their own groove that I then have to match in my programming and it’s not as intuitive as lining up grooves against transient heavy drum loops. 

I might just need to drill my rhythm harder

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames

expert_answers.content: Long story short - leave at +4.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: One sec boys, balanced or not has nothing to do with reference levels and where your inputs will clip

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Spend the time to do this right once

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content:
1) Turn off your speakers
2) Download an app with a signal generator that lets you out output a 1kHz sine wave tone
3) Set the app output volume to 0dB (maxed)
4) Set the phone output to max

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: 5) Now you are outputting the maximum possible analog level from your lightning to 3.5mm converter (it’s a tiny DAC)

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: 6) Check Apollo input for clipping, and choose either +4 or -10 on that basis

question: __**TLDR**__ - So what to do practically in the real world? If I had a super fast and stable computer I would record, produce and mix at 96k. It’s subtly better in every way and you can introduce any of the “desirable” problems from lower sample rates at will. BUT BUT BUT….if there was even the tinniest chance that the rig would hiccup, or my drives would not access fast enough, or that I would have a glitch in a real session then I would absolutely start at 48k.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: @Slow Hand I'm new to discord and not sure how to make this look good, particularly line spacing etc. Please edit at will or let me know how to improve

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content:
I agree, 48k is probably my default choice. 

I'd argue that it gets the AA filter far enough into ultrasonic territory as to not matter, though, and if a plugin is *designed properly* (big if, there... not many get this totally 100% right) aliasing should not be an issue.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: I don't consider it a good idea to work above 96 though, as you'll start introducing junk from switching power supplies, class D amps, noise shaping from D/A and A/D, etc into the program material. At lower sample rates it's effectively rolled out by extremely steep AA filters

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Thinking once I make the jump to Apple silicon I may go back to 96, but I’m 48 all day these days. At the ol’ staff gig we had virtually endless hd space and so much outboard that we did everything 96 and didn’t think twice.

expert_answers.content: You and I could go hard here on the geek stuff, but I'm gonna hold off in this forum so we can answer more newbie questions

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: I think we're largely in agreement though, higher is better to a point

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Anyway: just work at 48, and stop asking me to change the clock to 44.1 because I know you'll forget to change it back after and the next person will be all confused why their session sounds wrong

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
A strong second on this. I'm not someone who interacts with many kids on a regular basis, but I've felt a similar openness and lack of inhibition during my experiences doing improv comedy. It has so much in common with what we observe in children. Finding your way back to that state of non-judgement is such a worthy pursuit.

Improv education places such an emphasis on not being precious about things, accepting what's happening in front of you, and not overthinking. Most of all, the biggest lessons were always about *listening*: Listening to your partners, listening to their intent, and listening to the audience. There is no time to plan. You just do.

I did it for two years and it was one of the most rewarding experiences of my life. The improv mindset really enriches everything else in your life once you open yourself up to it.

question: What happens if you null them?

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Side note this riff rocks

expert_answers.author: ehutton21
expert_answers.content: Semi dumb question here that I’ve never fully understood

expert_answers.author: ehutton21
expert_answers.content: What’s the use cases for mono reverb vs stereo

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Honestly, mono reverb down the middle leaves lots of rooms on the sides, and mono reverb to one side leaves lots of room in the middle + other side. Stereo reverb leaves no room.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
I really like mono reverbs for:

1. Vocal verb. It can just give the vocal it's own little space instead of spreading it out into the rest of everything in the sides. Just has a different feel, similar to "Mono drums" iMO.

2. Panning a reverb hard to one side, opposite of a dry signal. I.E. Electric guitar or synth.

Also, I use mono -> stereo reverbs a lot because when I was learning, I used the Lexicon PCM-70 a lot which was mono input. It also just made sense to me...not sure it matters a whole lot though ultimately. That is an aside to your question.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
Great responses above. One other thing to conceptualize is guitar amps. Many guitar amps have built in spring reverb. If you mic that amp with a single mic, that mono signal has the reverb as a part of it. When you pan that complete signal, it carries a kind of depth and character that is very different from a stereo reverb or even a separate send. 

Mono elements with their own reverb can achieve an interesting spatial clarity that you can't get with eq or compression or whatever else you use to give elements their own place in a mix. I use it on all kinds of things from guitars to vocals to drums to whatever.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: i was recently working on some guitar stuff. and it was a 3 guitar parts thing, guitars were panned L-C-R but the L & R reverbs was 25% towards the center in mono, and the main center guitar had a stereo verb. it ended up as a really cool blend. so basically   (Left guitar - 50%panned reverb) - (stereo reverb - Main Guitar - stereo reverb) - (50%panned reverb - Right guitar)

community_answers.author: Jeremy Klein
community_answers.content: definitely dont null but that could be because of a few different things

community_answers.author: Zakhiggins
community_answers.content: I love a clean mono guitar in the left ear and mono reverb aux in the right

expert_answers.content:
There’s also the very real case that this issue only really becomes an issue to a small set of specific users. Like if I a vocal goes a few wonky samples off, no one is going to care or notice.

It’s only a problem with stuff like multi track drums and people that are recording loved shows. Basically anytime audio has to go out and then come back in. (Which again, most people don’t have to worry about)

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
My advice here - I have not seen the issue I mentioned today if I'm batching out groups of stems.  For example - if I print a group of stems on THE SAME RENDER then they tend to sum with each other correctly/sample accurately.  It seems in my case to be if I'm printing stems one at a time, then one print may sometimes be offset 1 sample.  So if you are printing multitrack drums, try and print them together, or at the very least, load them into another DAW or a clean session and make sure they are adding back up like you expected ESPECIALLY for parallel processing.

The main takeaway here should be if you are sending files to another person to work on them you should always check your work so what goes out is what you expected to have go out!

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content:
the dead space issue seems to happen in both logic and ableton. And I found printing click track helpful because I can make sure it’s lining up in the daw after exporting the vocal files. I’m working on a rubato-ish track with more classical time feel and I printed click track to double check the tempo map I imported from a midi file, correcting issues only took me 5 mins. 

Both Ableton and Logic seem to bounce tracks with extra few ms in the beginning of the song and if you print click (separately) you can figure out how far off it is and just match to that.

question: Posting here to stay humble and because this is something I probably should know by now: I hear people talking about “low-end transients” or “low information transients” but by definition, shouldn’t transients only really start existing at a certain wave length ? My question is: can low end actually feel like it has attack or is all attack mid / upper-mid / treble in relation to that low end information ?

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: You nailed it, if you are hearing fast attack/speed/transient then it’s a higher frequency component

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: What it can be used for sometimes is to describe ringing or resonance *after* a note, the way I’ll often describe ATC ports as being sleepy

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: (Kinda like me right now)

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Basically yes, but low pass have a slope so you’re still hearing some higher stuff

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: But a lot of the sense of attack is distortion

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: And that’s not always a bad thing as long as you can depend on it to play that way in the real world

question:
If I wanted to analyze what a hardware EQ was doing, like an EQ curve, what programs do I need? I see plugin doctor being thrown around but I don’t know if that works for hardware. 

I want to know exactly what the SSL EQ on our console is doing, just for science/fun/curiosity.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Q Clone, technically a matching EQ, REW, many ways to skin a cat

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I have an old copy of fuzz measure that works well and is simple to use.

expert_answers.author: Gerhard Westphalen
expert_answers.content: REW. Plugin doctor is useful for seeing things "live" but I find it to be very buggy and you don't get the same resolution as REW. REW will give you the frequency response (down to something like 0.001 dB) plus harmonic distortion

expert_answers.author: Gerhard Westphalen
expert_answers.content: If you feed the EQ something like noise or a sine wave (can do it using the generator in REW) then you can watch it live with the RTA in REW but it's not as nice as plugin doctor which shows you the frequency response changing live

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Yep, Plug in Doctor super buggy

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: REW for the win and it’s a great tool to learn

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Will also help you measure distortion in channels etc

community_answers.author: Matt Huber
community_answers.content: Ozone Match EQ is excellent

So if you had submitted a 48k file it does live conversion which may sound worse than submitting 44.1k that was converted before submission. The option is good to have if needed.

Before we advise @BoozleBAM on hot rodding let’s consider his big picture. Two observations 

1) I’ll bet that there is no Time Machine running, and that backup protocol for audio projects is not yet optimized (same as we all did when we were at that stage of the journey)

question: this section in the Motu UL manual keeps haunting me. I look at it and wonder “ok? how much do i trim or boost to hit one of these standards”

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Ah ok. Learning is good.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: The EEVblog multimeters are the best value for money -  https://eevblog.store/collections/test-equipment

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Any of the ones here will do what you need, you should be able to find on Amazon

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: But zooming out, I’ve been engineering for 30 years and have some very expensive multimeters but never use them in the studio

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Most modern gear connects together easily and you won’t damage anything if you clip an input in testing. Just set up a test in your DAW with a signal generator and a decent peak meter

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: We are trying to find good operating levels between the noise (very low in modern gear) and clipping

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: So if I have a piece of gear that can output +24 dBu (like my Benchmark DAC3) I just turn it down a few dB so it doesn’t clip my AD

question: I’m fascinated with phase and waves . I expect this might all be familiar to you but it seems there’s some handy info about phase and audio here https://mycourses.aalto.fi/pluginfile.php/666520/course/section/128564/Jon%20Fagerstr%C3%B6m_1929997_assignsubmission_file_AAT_Seminar_paper_Phase_Equalization_JF_FINAL.pdf?time=1558421096226#:~:text=Phase%20equalizers%20are%20filters%20that,response%20of%20a%20given%20system.

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: You can then go into the little sidebar on the tab for each eq point and you ll see a slider that allows you to move the eq point from linear to minimum phase

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: It will also show you simultaneously on the time graphic what part of the signal is being delayed (or not )

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: It’s an interesting tool to be able to slide between eq types and not have to switch them as in FabFilter .

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content:
I also use SSL’s X phase a lot , as much to investigate how many different ways one can adjust phase on a source and to listen to the interplay between sounds . I’ll usually always employ it on low end elements at the moment , just as much as an educational tool as anything . You can do much much more than flip the phase 

And finally phase rotators . I got really into these . RX has one . And the manufacture who make that teote plug in make one and Maat I believe .

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: I ve used them all to just really investigate

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Another one is to take a sine wave at 100 hz and put in a high pass filter and start moving it around and look at the consequent response post filter on the sine wave

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Re Jons point that you referred to , I can remember watching that one but I don’t remember the wording

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
More often than not it seems the main songwriter demos the song. Maybe a drum loop, maybe some programmed drums. Plays guitar and/or keys and sings.

Drummer then plays along to the in time demo. This will be the keeper drums. 

Band instruments then re-played, layered on top of the keeper drums. 

Then vocals. 

Then whatever little extra schmutz you want to add. 

Then you clear some space on the wall for the inevitable awards and plaques.

question: @Zack Hames When you're tracking guitar 2, are you having the first guitar (the one you're playing along to) panned up the center or hard panned? - I tried it hard panned and found that confusing/ hard to get the performance. Also, if I had the guitar I was tracking along to too loud up the center, I would end up compensating or adjusting a bit too much with the subsequent take and I would end up with a quieter take on one side. I had to have the take I was tracking along to really quiet (like minus 28db, even -25 was too loud) in order to get a compelling subsequent take. Barely hearing it was helpful, but I also think it accounted for some of my off-ness in intonation in parts.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
I pan the first one hard and then double with the other panned opposite. I may turn up the current one a slight amount.

Also when I do the doubles I always have to turn both down a few dB to be able to hear everything else.

I’m also super used to doing it, so I don’t know how else I would do it. I just make micro adjustments to the levels as needed

expert_answers.content: Play it right and make sure intonation with playing is right

question: Wouldn’t it also even out the transients in a more consistent way than compression? Lop the jagged peaks off to zero, and then regenerate all the transients equally and controllably?

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: depends on the compressor (technically you can use lookahead/super fast attack and a very high ratio to do the same thing) but yea

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: oh yeah sorry I wasn't more clear in my response to will, that's essentially what I meant (doing the transient stuff without the harmonic stuff with a limiter)

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Put slightly differently , You increase perceived loudness without destroying impact.

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Also , dependant on  the actual clipper you’re using they have slightly different characters

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Orange clip is an attempt at simulating FL . Kazrog Kclip in crisp is attempting to simulate clipping lavry gold .

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: I think Jon was using Boz clipper in those JFTRs iirc.

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content:
It’s great for really really in your face attitude , brilliant for a trap 808.
Standard Clips another good un. Ruairi detailed a good use case for that one

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content:
Another way to see this, at least the harmonics that clipping adds, is considering a simple sin wave vs a square wave. Read into the harmonics created (it’s just wave theory). But it’s especially clear in synthesis in that case.

Of course musical applications are much more complex, but that’s why clipping (squaring off the top of a rounded waveform) adds harmonics

That’s what people mean when they say it spreads the energy across the spectrum. In the case of a sin wave, you have a single fundamental. At the far other end, you have a square wave which has harmonics all up the spectrum of frequency

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content:
To illustrate a good example of the difference and why (guessing) Jon would want to clip rather than do this (which would control the transients as you describe)

If you use a long look ahead, call it a limiter with a long look ahead. That will let the processor know about the transient well before it hits the GR circuit, thus avoiding distortion/harmonics (of course there still could be some artifacts). But even though there will be samples at the threshold, it won’t be a straight line waveform as if you clipped it. It is pushing the waveform down. The waveform itself is actually changed still, so it is not exact but it’s different than clipping.

A clipper just squares it off. Hence harmonics.

This is why you can limit/compress an instrument like piano, which has a tendency to hear distortion easily, when clipping it would be a disaster (unless you are going for that)

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: Oh I think it is clear! Was just spelling out why one vs other would be used

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content:
I have a couple distinct phases of my workflow. The “technical” phase let’s call it, is all about letting my brain objectively search for the very specific kinds of things that are distracting within the mix at hand. This is much more of a thinking and corrective process than it is a feeling one, even though feeling and taste is 100% involved. This part of the process is to get the mix on a more solid foundation if needed.

The next phase is where I want to actively NOT be thinking at all. This is why I do the first part separately. I want to be FEELING the music in this phase and not be taken out of it by the vocal resonance at 1.8k at 1:35 in the bridge. I want to turn that part of my brain off so I can focus on the music, the feeling, the lyrics, the intent, the song and try to find where (or if) I can elevate or reveal or better frame the heart of what’s there. This is meant to be the flow state, moving intuitively and viscerally based on what’s coming out of the speakers. This is where efficiency in toolset matters -- where an extremely efficient human-computer interaction matters, where knowing your tools cold matters. I want to reduce latency between feeling and move and I don’t want anything to get in my way. 

So to answer your question: I think about ways to continue to be able to access and preserve that crucial flow state during the time where it matters the most. And it can manifest a million ways that aren’t directly related to mastering at all: taking a walk, working out, doing a J, listening to a new record, checking Discord, unplugging, whatever. And yes, sometimes it also means refining my template or my Streamdeck shortcuts or creating a new preset.

question:
Are the sides in phase? Two ways I’d consider approaching this.

1. Put a multi-mono Trim plugin on the track. Unlink the channels. Tweak the gain on one channel until they match.

OR

2. Create two mono tracks and ctrl-drag the stereo clip onto them. Clip gain, nudge, nip, and tuck as needed. Then ctrl-drag the two mono clips back onto the stereo track.

expert_answers.author: Will Melones
expert_answers.content: But if you null test the channels and they’re the same content with slightly different level, might as well just split ‘em into mono and lose one half

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
Orrrr… just split into mono, take one side, and make that your 808. I just did that on a record. Was better than trying to finangle the whole both sides bit. Track was significantly better too just having the one up the middle.

(Edit: just saw will’s answer. This is the way)

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content:
Nailed it Will. Split mono is a step in my mix prep sequence. Efficient method goes like this:

PT Downmixer stock plugin is the one for this (it collapses stereo channels to mono) - flip the phase of one side in the GUI and save that as your user default. If you insert your Downmixer on a faux stereo track, it’ll immediately silence it, so you can happily split and delete what you don’t need. 

(Check the meters though, sometimes ambience or other subtle stereo info isn’t very audible unless cranked.)

If the stereo track contains slightly panned mono information, pushing/pulling either of the faders in Downmixer will quickly get it to cancel, and you can note how much extra gain you need to add or subtract when level matching in the final step (below). Obviously if it’s deliberately panned info, you can either just leave the track stereo or match the pan position by ear (I prefer to do this because I like mono channels to behave like mono channels, and also half the CPU you’d use on a stereo track).

Finally, use clip gain to add 3dB to the resulting mono channel, and obviously pan it centre. This makes up for the level change according to default pan laws in Tools (-3dB).

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Great answer. My less thoughtful one would be - split to mono, use the louder side. A panned 808 has little to zero value in the stereo field… especially if you’re unsure of what processing is on it.

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content: Ooh that's rad (the existence of Stereomonoizer, not your PanPot woes). Thanks for the tip, that's yuuge!

expert_answers.author: Will Melones
expert_answers.content:
Ahhh, I forgot Downmixer! One of the handiest but simplest utility plugins ever.

I will echo that StereoMonoizer is worth every penny, pays for itself, and has been my one responsible software purchase in recent years

community_answers.author: Barbara
community_answers.content: Dude, just added this as a preset for downmixer because I usually do it with the Trim plugin and this will save me some time!

question:
Noah covered a lot, but a few (also stream of consciousness) thoughts to add:

There is no formula to when to take the leap. It's helpful to have some money in the bank, because it's going to take awhile for things to start happening. The more connections you have, the more in-roads you've made, the easier it will be to drum up work in music and keep the lights on. The less responsibilities and overhead you have, the easier the beginning stages of freelance life will be.

Don't think about your music career in terms of the same metrics as your day job, you're burnt out on it for a reason. So instead of "am I making what I made before," think "can I survive on this for now?" and if not, "what will get me to a place that I can afford to pursue this dream?"

Any music job can be a boon for your career, and chances are you don't know where the opportunities will come from. The Beatles became the Beatles by playing cover songs at shady clubs, honing their sound and learning to play with each other. For someone else, that would've been a mindless, thankless gig with no upside. When they started playing better gigs, they were ready and stood out because of it.

How you do anything is how you do everything - if you're an intern at a studio cleaning up trash, you may be around huge artists and engineers. If they see you as dependable, friendly, going above-and-beyond, there's a tiny chance that a life-changing opportunity could emerge. Likewise, if they see you doing a sloppy job, that's how they're going to assume you'd be in the room, too.

question:
Now that the basics are happening — kick and snare are really standing on their own two feet and in a place to drive the song — I’ll start bringing in other instruments in the mix and getting a sense of how things are adding up. Usually starting with bass, guitars, keys and finally vocals. Some people do vocals first — that’s never worked for me. Once you have a balance of the track, you can start really incorporating some of the overheads and room mics to give the drums more dimension and flavor. If the engineer really fucked the dog with the recording — or the room just sounds bad — I won’t spend too much time making them work… I’ll just get to manufacturing something that sounds cool. This could be leaning into a spring reverb, or a fun delay, or using other creative reverbs to get the drums have the space you want. I’m a big fan of un-natural sounding drums… distorted spring reverb panned hard left with a slap panned hard right? Why not! If someone serves you shit, shovel them ice cream.

Toms will literally be the last thing I work on. It’s just a matter of seeing what’s missing from the overall picture and filling in the blanks with the spot mics. I don’t like to trim the regions because I might find that when I’m gating, some of the bleed sounds good from the track. Sometimes, if the engineer did their job, the multi-mic recording will be really complete and will need the tom mics for the overall sound… so no gating at all. Again, all depends on what you’re working with.

Once I move on with the rest of my mix, I’ll find myself doing EQ moves on the drum buss and treating it more like one instrument to get other things happening in the mix… only doing small tweaks to the individual sounds.

I hope this all makes sense?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
A tangent…

I’m lucky to have spent many years in a great studio with lots of great drums & gear… not to mention being mentored by one of the great engineers of our time. Having this perspective is massively useful in mixing other peoples tracks, because I feel I have a north star of what good drums can sound like if they’re recorded and performed properly. It used to be that my starting point for mixing drums were working with tracks that I had recorded myself… and most of the above problems were solved before the mix stage. These days, with smaller budgets and time constraints, its very rare that this is a possibility.

I’m including this drum tracking session from a few years ago that I recorded at Barefoot. It was for a project that Matt was producing that never saw the light of day. But we went all out with the drum setup in the big room, through the console, and had a great drummer. This might be useful for some people who have never gotten properly recorded drum tracks… to get a sense of how good thigns can sound before the ‘mix’ stage. These are the tracks that were printed into Pro Tools off of the console, and the three busses were prints of the outboard compressor busses we were using while monitoring. It’s unlikely these busses would get used in mixing, but they’re a good reference to what we were listening to in the room while we were tracking. But as you’ll notice, the individual drum blend can stand on it’s own two feet. Hopefully this is useful as well.

Thanks for coming to my Ted talk.

question: so when we talk about 500 series lunch boxes. is the best thing to get one that connects thru usb or something? i just feel like having a high end preamp in there to then get it to the computer thru an apollo ruins it. how’s that different from plugin the mic straight to the apollo then? am i missing something?

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
i don't know about usb 500 series boxes, but having an A+ preamp into the line input on the apollo will likely be an improvement on the apollo preamps (which are actually not bad though). 

ps, this is what i do with my undertone pres into my apollo x16

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Oh, this is an area where I know a bit!

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Other than the Cranborne stuff, all the 500 series stuff I see is purely analog in and out (i.e. balanced XLR or TRS). You'd need some kind of converter to make it into any kind of digital format (ADAT included).

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Line level and mic level are very different signals, and depending on the Apollo, some entirely bypass the mic preamp on the line input, others just pad it down to a lower level.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: I think if it was me, I don't particularly like the "mic preamp  with the level knocked down" thing so I'd see if you can just go right into a line level input without a gain control on it.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: My setup I have a secondary AD/DA hooked into my interface via AES just for my analog stuff, but if I hadn't gone for an interface that's 2 in/2 out in analog then I wouldn't have needed it.

question:
What’s the best pitch shift plugin for vocals for adding that low/octave below effect that’s all over stuff the last 5 or so years? Ie:

https://open.spotify.com/track/0KS2h61pHQ4WmOwruD7uxD?si=BZCjMXQJSsKHv3IZGtOTjw

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: There’s a million examples of this, this is just the one that a client reference today.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: *Little Alter Boy* is solid - if a little artifact-y and with some latency.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: The Infected Mushroom *Manipulator* is good for real-time performance and has some other great tricks.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: However, I find I get the most natural/full-sounding results if I varispeed the audio recording down to the desired pitch/formant and then use a granular algorithm to compress the audio back to it's original, faster, playback speed. It's more labor intensive, but the results usually sound more natural to my ears than doing a granular pitch-shift down.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: manipulator is such a great and weird tool. i use it a ton for filling out bvs/ adding vocoder

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Yeah. Their vocoder is the easiest no-muss-no-fuss one out there. Sounds great *always*. Couldn't be simpler to set up. Also Manipulator's stereo spread module (while heavy handed) holds up extremely well when folded down to mono. Whoever designed that plugin did a great job.

question: Guys I love the stylistic choice gunna and playboicarti do with autotune is it possible to use autotune in a different key from the instrumental is and still sound good

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: it's possible but challenging. there are definitely scales besides major and minor that work in pop songs ("pop" meaning anything that gets popular). but if you don't have good experience and/or a decent grasp of music theory, it's tough to not make it sound weird. it's a bit like doing tempo changes or odd time signatures: mostly it sounds crazy to a mainstream music audience, but if done just right, it can be unique and amazing.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Yeah. There are lots of theoretical explanations for different scales/modes that would work, but you're probably better off just using your ear. If it sounds good, it is good. Go for it!

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: One of my favorite instances of polytonality (multiple keys at the same time) in a pop hit is Beyonce's *Single Ladies*. On the second chorus when those huge, dark synths come in... *Chef's Kiss*.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Serpent With Feet is also someone who is really harmonically interesting. Sometimes he's in a very grey zone harmonically, but it's so confident and assured that your ear adjusts and accepts it as a new texture.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: I'd say he's on the fringes of what passes for popular music, though. He's more in Bjork end of the spectrum.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Fancy by Iggy Azalea hits me the same way as far as polytonality is concerned. Not really answering the autotune question but it’s a similar result.

question:
How do you all approach mixing live drums . which tracks  is your go to to fix or work on first? Currently mixing an indie rock song ( i usually mix pop/rnb/some indie which has a lot of programmed drums) . 
The drums on this mix wasn’t recorded well. The kick mic sounds like it’s only a kick in mic . All of the spot mics has crazy amount of bleed , they all sound like close mic overheads. 
Mixing live drums always been my weakness. 
😌

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Oh oh this is a question I can answer!

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Focus on your overheads and rooms (if present) first.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Strip the bleed out of toms manually.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
If it’s that bad, don’t be afraid to use drum samples. Just do it. Make it sound good at all costs.

I’d carve out any annoying or harsh frequencies in the overheads, cut out low end so it’s just cymbals, then throw in samples to be the focus of the drum sound since it will minimize the bad sounds.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Also beyond “fixing” the best thing i ever learned for drum mixing was drum bus compression, and using saturation on close mics.

My usual chain is this:
All kick and snare mics get some sort of eq if needed. Then I’ll put fab filter Saturn 2 and saturate the high end at around 700hz.

The I’ll bus all the drums to an aux. then I’ll usually do this:
Tape saturation (waves J37)
Parallel drum compression with a mix knob (fast release, slow attack) I use the kush audio AR-1, I used to use the waves abbey road mastering plugin. 

Sometimes I’ll use wavesfactory Spectre to boost highs and lows after all that. Maybe soundtoys Sie-Q to boost midrange.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I’m sure you’re right. If you have the time or capability, maybe just record new drums LOL

community_answers.author: mixedbywong_my
community_answers.content: The overheads sounding really phased out . Almost makes me think that the pair of mics were facing up the ceiling . And the room mic is kinda … shit. I have a feeling even though I’m not a recording engineer , that the engineer didn’t know how to mic the kit properly . 😌

community_answers.author: mixedbywong_my
community_answers.content: Hahaha I’m just mixing the song . My country is in a lockdown since may , so most likely the band almost committed with this recording of the drums 😅 thank you for the tips @David Fuller @Zack Hames  🙌🏼

question: Buying some bulk cables and connectors to practice soldering has me wondering: any benefit to speaker cables / instrument cables over balanced cables for everything? Why would I not just use balanced cables with TRS / XLR for my instruments and monitors?

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: because they aren't balanced circuits

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: tl;dr: cables themselves can't be balanced, they're just wire - what makes a circuit "balanced" has to do with having two sources with equal impedance feeding a load with a differential amplifier on the other end.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
You would get 0 benefit using a TRS cable for guitar because it is an unbalanced signal. It would cost more money and time for 0 benefit. Also with certain connections it may NOT work. 

You probably know this, but active monitors just use balanced cabling with TRS or XLR connectors. Passive use proper speaker cables which are unshielded and TS.

Speaker cables don't have any shielding because they are expecting to see a super hot signal.  So this would result in unwanted noise in your guitar signal / active monitor signal because line level is much lower than speaker level.

So in all cases it's pretty much best to use the correct cable for the correct job. You'll save money and your equipment's longevity and reliability.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content:
To go into more detail... Unbalanced signaling like a guitar or a speaker input from an amplifier just has a signal lead (hot) and a common (ground). Speaker cables in particular do not use the common as shielding where unbalanced line level (like consumer RCA) and instrument level cables do. 
Balanced signaling like mics and pro audio line level equipment requires a "hot" signal, a "cold" signal (either polarity inverted hot or just nothing but with the same source impedance), and a common (ground/shield). At the receiving end of the connection, there is what's called a differential amplifier. Short version, a differential amp polarity inverts cold and combines it with hot, thereby reducing common mode noise by cancellation (and also some distortion, but we'll get back to that later).

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: This is what a basic differential amp looks like. I've labeled it so it's more obvious what everything is. The feedback loop isn't necessary, but is very common because it helps further linearize the circuit (and also in the case of op amps limit their gain, which for something like a common TL071/TL072/TL074 is about 120dB - or a factor of 1,000,000).

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: It's just a return to ground, basically

question: __**What does not matter? (Even though people will say it does)**__

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content:
- **More samples (slices) per second equals a better representation of the analog waveform.** Within half the band of the sample rate (say up to 22.05k for 44.1k) this is demonstrably not true. I know that is confounding, but digital and information theory is basically miraculous
- **We can hear/feel/sense sounds above 20k.** We truly really cannot and if you experiment with significant energy above 20k you’ll actually see problems creep in for electronics and speakers etc. Information above 20k is not our friend (space for harmonic information to live without aliasing back excepted)
- **Working at multiples of 44.1k is better because the sample rate conversion will work better.** This used to be a little bit true a long time ago but hasn’t been for a long time. Use the SRC in iZotope RX on it’s stock preset to 44.1 and you are in pretty good shape
- **Digital EQs work better at higher sample rates because of cramping.** Cramping was an esoteric problem with older digital EQs that looked bad on analyzers but never actually sounded very bad. It’s a solved problem nowadays with most EQs.
- **Video and film is at 48k so we must start there.** Yes film and TV still work at 48k (although YouTube specs 44.1 now) but I have sent a million tracks for sync at 44.1 and it gets dropped in with SRC and away we go

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: @Slow Hand I'm new to discord and not sure how to make this look good, particularly line spacing etc. Please edit at will or let me know how to improve

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content:
I agree, 48k is probably my default choice. 

I'd argue that it gets the AA filter far enough into ultrasonic territory as to not matter, though, and if a plugin is *designed properly* (big if, there... not many get this totally 100% right) aliasing should not be an issue.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: I don't consider it a good idea to work above 96 though, as you'll start introducing junk from switching power supplies, class D amps, noise shaping from D/A and A/D, etc into the program material. At lower sample rates it's effectively rolled out by extremely steep AA filters

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Thinking once I make the jump to Apple silicon I may go back to 96, but I’m 48 all day these days. At the ol’ staff gig we had virtually endless hd space and so much outboard that we did everything 96 and didn’t think twice.

question:
My first option would always be to see if it was possible to sing it differently. If thats not possible, i would try to differentiate the two Lines where they overlap, maybe an eq or pan automation? Could be one disappears into the back with verb while the next one stays dry? If its still fucked, maybe just try and volume automate/shorten one of the lines. 

It really all depends on the song, and the importance of those Lines.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content:
This really only happens when I song is written and recorded line for line at the same time. 

One a great way to really listen to a song is actually to play it with a guitar or a piano before recording it. It will really let you tune in on the core song and be able to judge it without all the production.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: And if it’s part of the energy, just lean into it and make it weird

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: It all depends really

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: You could let the ending of one pan out 10-20% during the word that over laps, while the the new sentence starts 10-20% out and pans inward

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: Also making the end fade into the back with some verb or effect while the new one comes in dryer

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: Subtle eq moves can really make the overlapping help as well. Automate a little high or low end out as the new one comes in. Just on the overlapping part

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: It's very much the way the artist wanted the performance to sound in this case

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: panning might be the best idea now that you suggest it

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: It's a little like "Sic Transit Gloria" by Brand New in delivery

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: That makes sense to me as well

expert_answers.content: Ok so it’s happening somewhere other than the DAW. Hearing that while recording has to be disconcerting. An external phantom supply solved some issues for me. Buy the absolute cheapest one you can find on Amazon and if it solved your issue, use it till it breaks and then buy the most expensive one you can afford.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I’ve seen inductors in power supplies squeal like that

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: It’s physical in the electronic component itself

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering

question: Might be a stupid question, but - I've comped and bounced down a bunch of rough mixes for listening. question: Thank you so much, Zach - What are you aiming at on your master usually?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Not clipping. I don’t care as long as it’s not clipping before processing

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I’ll use a limiter to make it however loud I want/can

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
That’s why I do the faders at 0
Or below. It all lands in the master fader really well. If I start pushing faders up (fader creep) I start to clip the master

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Then it all goes to shit

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: If you find yourself needing to crank something with a fader, that’s when you pull everything down. During the mix phase rather than at the end or something. And if a source was recorded very quietly, bring the level up at the clip level or within a plugin so the fader can react in an expected way.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: keep an eye on average volume also, some instruments might have a very low peak to average where if you record the peaks might not be very high, but the average is, I try to keep faders at zero but perceive the loudness, so drum peaks can be much higher than guitar peaks because drums have a very wide peak to average ratio, distorted guitars peak to average level is generally very low where the peak is not much higher than the average.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: They all come from having made all these mistakes over the years haha

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content:
ExFAT has given me problems so I avoid it. It seems to work for some other folks but these days my go to is a SSD running APFS. I gravitate towards the Samsung T7, they’ve been super reliable. Avoid SanDisk, but I think there are some other folks using things from other brands like Crucial.

Hard drives are super susceptible to damage and weird mechanical failure when moving them around, and they’re much slower. Do yourself a favor and work from a solid state (and keep everything backed up in multiple places)

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: That unsafe ejecting part can really mess up a hard drive because the final writing of some files (even if it seems like any transfers are finished) can get interrupted, leading to corruption. It may not even be apparent immediately

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: And always operate under the presumption that any drive can fail at any time

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Open up disk utility with the new drive connected and erase/format the new drive with whatever name you want and the APFS file format. Look up on Apple’s site how to use disk utility if you get stumped

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: You won’t easily be able to use it on windows though but it’s worth it to use a file system meant for SSDs

question: I"m not quite understanding this - If I play through it live, how can I / what would be the purpose of separating sections down the road? I.e. chorus, verse, bridge, etc.

expert_answers.author: Edward Rivera
expert_answers.content: Id leave it up to the guitarist. If it’s an instance where they’d prefer to run through the tune front to back, we do some work to make sure that there’s no crazy spikes or dips in level with each pedal and that the dynamics of the performance sound as they should

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Let’s say you want the verse to sound thinner or quieter, and you want the chorus to sound thicker and wider… you can do some of this with the performance and your sweet pedal action… but you’ll be able to take it further by separating the sections of the song (verse guitars in one track, pre chorus in another, etc). This way you can effect and mix them accordingly. Just giving you more control and helps the song have more dynamics since it’s just one guitar take throughout.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
There’s no right or wrong in this regard.

If you’re landing the transitions really cleanly between the different levels of overdrive you’re golden. 

You’re getting suggestions from folks who probably got burned on records where it was done poorly or it would have been easier for them to separate and organize like @cian riordan said. He described the benefits of it perfectly. 

I’m impatient as *fuck* and prefer to cut as many things live and in 1 go as possible. I don’t like overly complex sessions, etc. it’s prob more of a shortcoming than benefit unfortunately.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I also hate comping! So I try to just get the take and pretend like I don’t have playlists except as emergencies

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Start with a fresh slate on a format you choose rather than whatever they give you

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: If you’re on Windows use NTFS

expert_answers.content: It’s a solid state drive and the other ones are hard drives. The solid state drives basically can search for files much faster which makes them feel more responsive. You also have noticed the higher speed for copying (known to the nerds as read/write speed)

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: AFAIK nothing as straightforward and painless as Time Machine. I use AOMEI Backupper, previously used something offered from Paragon. There are options.

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: We’ve talked here about what a robust backup strategy looks like, but to start, the important thing is that you have some automated backup in place. Drives fail, files get corrupted, mistakes happen and things get erased. My backups have saved me from some potentially catastrophic situations over the years.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Same thing. Backing up to the cloud is just backing up to a hard drive on a computer somewhere else. The point being, you want to set up a backup routine that doesn’t require your intervention so you can set it up once and be  covered.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Lotta people around here on Backblaze

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM

question: How does one arrange the merry dance between the vocal and the rythm guitar without losing impact and drive

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: 🙅🏼‍♂️🙏🏼 (ps . The mixes are popping I just want it all to speak beautifully together )

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Any thoughts much appreciated 🕊️

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
Looking forward to other answers here, but considering that 700-2k is the so much of the sound of the electric guitar I’m much less inclined to scoop there.  In fact if the guitars only lived 700-2k I bet your vocal would pop easily. (Hard to tell without source material of course.)

But, philosophically, it’s way more about panning. You guitars can be huge if they’re on the sides.

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Thank you Noah . I follow what you’ve said there about the 700-2khz area being so much of the sound …..which is where I’m having this “dilemma “ …thank you also for the reminder re : panning . Cians mixes always educate me with respect to panning . I think it’s time to listen again to some st Vincent and the Jane’s addiction record . Thanks Noah for your ideas

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: ….this is awesome gents thank you

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: @cy (sigh)  . Re “the vocal enunciation being ok to be a little swallowed by the guitars at times “……this is gold . You’re bang on , you ve just drawn to mind that perhaps I’m approaching the way I want to mix the vocal a little inappropriately for the genre

community_answers.author: cy (sigh)
community_answers.content: not as much exp as others  but I've learned that you have to be okay with some lopsided feel more often than in the other genres you're used to.  especially if you're dealing with contrasting /dueling  guitars

community_answers.author: cy (sigh)
community_answers.content: also depending on the type of music, the vocal doesn't always  need to be as clear. sometimes the guitars swallowing up some of the enunciation will give you what you  need . coming from the other genres we tend to want the vocals to be super audible but I've found that can take away from the overall feel and detach the voice too much from the song

community_answers.author: Chad Rodgers
community_answers.content: Agree with the above. I used to be a bit brutal and completely hi pass the low mids for guitars, making my band mixes sound a lot more like my pop mixes, but right now I’ve been enjoying letting those low mids through in guits for the body. Similar to the above it’s hugely about feel and it’s nice to really *feel* those guitars as opposed to just hear them. A bit like if you were sat in the room with an amp, or in a small venue in front of the stage… definitely a case for abandoning mixer brain.

question: Can one of you genial mates help me to understand how cutting the mids became so popular?? In my short, but fairly extensive and obsessive mixing journey of 2-3 years or so, I've basically discovered that: On kick drum anything goes, so you never know what you're going to do there, but aside from that, I've found that 100-400 hz is mainly where all the power/ strength lies, and that cutting it is not good.  Typically, sooome nastiness can be found between 3 and 400hz, but really I don't get the whole "cutting the mids" thing. Has not worked well for me.

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Because if you scoop the mids it feels like there’s more low end

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: So you can scoop mids instead of boosting lows etc

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Yeah cause it’s balance

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Scooping mids also sounds “modern”

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Def a taste/ personal call on balancing the mids

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Not enough and there won’t be enough clarity to much and it’ll sound boxy/thib

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Okay, tight. Thanks, Ryan.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Right. I found it was *quite easy to get things to sound thin - even just -1 or 2 dB can change things drastically. Really suck the life out. I think through my neurosis I managed to select mics that flatter the thing I'm recording in the way that I'm going for, so I find eqing largely unnecessary for the most part. This creates some frustration for me; I think the tendency as a mixer is always to want to do more.

question: Hmm could you speak more to why they’re completely different worlds? From my POV, phase shifts are phase shifts, they don’t vary by what condition they’re in. The xover in a speaker are filters that impart the same high and low pass phase shifts in an EQ (and hence the same phase response and group delay). But I digress, that wasn’t my original question lol. Original question was whether phase shift from EQ on the master is audible?

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Nah, the Harman Curve is a headphone tonality preference curve. Not much to do with why mids get cut a lot

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I very rarely hear or notice phase shift on single source EQ moves. If I do, it's often on low end or sub material... especially kick drums or 808s. I'll find they punch a different way... sometimes good, sometiems bad... so I tend to be a little more judicious with moves down there.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: The reason I see that mids get cut a lot is that it leaves room for more "lead" instruments or voices

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: That and not everything can have a ton of energy in that region

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Okay, first thing to understand is that a lot of very successful people in music have no idea why what they're doing works

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: they just know "it sounds good" and they build a framework of what they *think* is happening to explain it

community_answers.author: tinkerjef
community_answers.content: And I guess if I were to choose a specific example, it’d be Jon saying boosting 16k and low passing 27k creating a pleasing phase bump, where psychoacoustic research tells us phase shifts like that aren’t audible

community_answers.author: tinkerjef
community_answers.content: Usually when I think phase bump, it’s because you change the phase relationship between 2 tracks, and when they sum, they either add or cancel, creating a difference in frequency response

community_answers.author: Dereck Blackburn
community_answers.content: I thought it might have been because of the preference for that sort of EQ curve.

question: those of you who use the hi hat mic - how are you recording it? is snare bleed just inevitable?

question: I’m wondering about general principles of mixing a drum kit , from the perspective of experienced engineers ……when it comes to the particular drums ( kick in and out for example ) which are close mic’d with two different mics, when it comes to the tiny timing differences of when that drum beat arrives at the kick in ….and  the kick out …..are you on principle , leaving that phase relationship captured on the consequent drum multitrack ….or are we on principle aligning those kick in and and out tracks so the transients can align bang on with no (millisecond ) out of phase relationship . My thoughts are I want those kicks hitting spot on together , but then I’m corrupting the phase relationship of the bleed in the kick out to the rest of the kit . So are y’all then chasing this phase shifting around the kit multitracks and trying to build a drum mix that represents the sounds as though they all arrived at the close mics at the same instant …..or are these discrepancies of the sound travelling different distances to the close mics ……to be preserved ? I’ve experimented and will continue to do so , but I wonder if there’s a consensus principle around this time / distance to phase aspect of recording and mixing drums ?

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: I’m thinking about not wanting the speaker to be trying to push and pull at the same time on playback if these time / phase relationships are left “as it happened “ during recording .

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering

question: There can be capacitance issues on long runs, which can on occasion destabilize a headphone amp

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I wouldn’t do a long run like this at headphone level

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Better to get a small cheap good headphone amp like topping or smsl and run a balanced signal to where you need it with a local amp

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: And no problem to split the headphone signal to two headphones, but be aware that if they are not the same they can play at different levels depending on impedance

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Last I checked here we're using brystons as cue amps, but we also have to do a lot of distribution

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: For a single set of headphones I agree about a local headphone amp with a balanced line level signal

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Yeah, not relevant for a home user

question: Make sense… so is it like a premium for a higher likely hood of consistency and longevity?

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content:
There is no one reason that some gear costs more than others than does the same job

It can be everything from component level differences that are beyond a typical engineers understanding to the level of service to where it's manufactured to outright emperor's new clothes scammy stuff (loooking at you Antelope 10M)

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: G-Man and I have had a long running argument about speakers, he believes PMC/ATC costs too much

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I know the inner workings of PMC at a component level, and the business inside out. No one is getting rich at PMC, they cost what they need to cost to make the business viable for a product made in the UK

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: But that does *not* mean that you or anyone else finds them to be good value

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: And if the difference between say a Kali IN8 and a PMC 6 is beyond your skill level to perceive, or beyond your need (say as a hobbiest) then it doesn't matter how justifiable the extra $$$ on the PMC is, it's not worth it for you

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Manufacturing audio equipment is an absolute heartbreaker

community_answers.author: itaylerner
community_answers.content: That all tracks. I usually don’t get too hung up on gear but helping some folks make some vocal chain decisions and it can be a real head scratcher. Without really being able to try a bunch of options it seems takes quite a bit of discernment and hope haha

community_answers.author: wcalebparker
community_answers.content:
Not exactly a direct contribution to this discussion, but it feels relevant.

I know a few producer/player types who are massively talented and could get great results with anything. That said, all their gear is either really expensive or rare/unobtanium. It seems like there’s something about having this top notch stuff that really gives them confidence in their creative decisions. It’s inspiring to them and the people they work with.

It’s helpful to know yourself and know your clients! Having some inspiring stuff around can be very helpful. And if an artist is going to get excited about singing into a BAE and not a Golden Age, that’s at least something to consider.

I’m also not saying that gear sounds the same. It doesn’t. It’s just that (like Ruairi and Cian said so well) that sometimes gear makes a different difference than the manufacturers would have you believe.

community_answers.author: itaylerner
community_answers.content: Real! I’ve gotten come cool results from the inspiration of certain environments / pieces being utilized.

question: I truly only want the song to be how they want.  That's the end goal.  But sometimes I'm like, "eh is that note making the song worse?"  So far I just do whatever they ask but then I wonder if I'm not serving them in the best way.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I often tell people that V1 is for me. It's what I want to hear. I get all my jollies off on that mix and paint the picture the way I see it. After that, it's time to hang the ego up and let them have their say. Ultimately its their song, with their name on it, and they'll have to do the work to release it and actualize it in the world. Best thing you can do is support them along the way.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
This is a constant in record making. Balancing your own thoughts with those of your client or collaborators. 

Cian is right on of course, but I’d encourage you not to think of it as binary. Almost always, there’s a version of their note that makes the song better, and it’s your job to hear it. 

In the end, it’s their record tho, and they’re the ones who will be playing it out, selling it, promoting it however they can… so they’re the ones who *need* to be happy with it in the end. 

My longtime producer & collaborator Jon Kaplan used to say “it’s your record, you can be wrong if you want to.” I give that to artists I work with now. Going in I tell them I’m going to treat you like an equal, until you tell me it’s your record and you can be wrong if you want to. 

Honestly that one idea has eased the tension on so many occasions for me.

Whatever artist you record, go to their shows.  Be cool, in both the "hip" sense of the word and the "nice and easy person to be around" sense of the word.  Even better, have your band play with them and be good.  People start lining up to have you record them.  It's crazy.
