question: You said the "downside is that you lose a bit of the potential width" - I took this to mean that the compromise in this case is that you miss out on that wide spread of having oh hard L and oh hard R?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Yes, if you space them incorrectly.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: If you space them correctly, snare is in the middle, you get full width

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Yep. Just remember that distance doesn’t have to necessarily be left to right. You can space them out on the Y axis as well

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: (Only if you want your snare in the center of the image)

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Easiest way is grab a cable or some string, put it on the center of the snare (or on the right side of the rim, closest to the kick) and measure out each overhead to its capsule. Match that and it’s a great starting place.

question:
I think a few things can factor in... sometimes there are contracts, maybe you need your lawyer to read it or at a minimum spend time to go over it yourself. Negotiation could be more intense, deliverables could be more scrutinized and annoying. Often deadlines are tighter/more strict.  Dealing with them dictating terms of payment IE when/how you get paid, as opposed to indie gigs where you can set your own payment terms and most people will be happy to follow them. And for me personally, the label gigs ive had (not a ton but a few at least), i ask for more because I know the budget generally will be higher than most of my local indie clients. And TBH it feels more like what im worth, than what i normally get paid by local artists without label support.  Thats partially because i probably dont ask for enough for my indie gigs, and partially just my location/client base.

TBH  I also dont have a problem morally with asking a corporation to pay me more for a service than an individual that is paying out of pocket... partially for the reasons listed and partially because if they're playing the capitalism game, why cant i when im working with them? Not to the point where i feel im being greedy, but, just advocating for myself a litlte stronger than i normally do.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: Label delivery requirements are insane. The oversight and hoops to jump through, and the higher stakes. I’m not gonna give a label a deal if I don’t have to, and I’m not gonna charge an indie artist the same as I would a label. It’s not that deep.

question:
For the second question, the "car test" is a staple mostly because both sonically and psychologically, the car is a great counterbalance to the context and precision of the studio. 

The car is also the place most people used to listen to the most music as a fan. It still is for many, but I say "used to" because a lot of people's #1 music listening environment outside of a studio is the phone/ headphones/ AirPods. 

So my "car test" is now AirPod max headphones walking around my neighborhood in LA or taking the tube in London. 

But the car also has its advantages because it's noisy and imperfect and NOT isolated like the studio and headphones. You can't listen as precisely in a car, which often tells you very quickly whether you can hear the important parts of your song (can you hear the vocal? Does the low end feel good?).

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: @Zack Hames I don't think this has been mentioned, but it's worth keeping in mind -- it's much, much easier to up your rate significantly with a new client vs a repeat client. If you've got someone that's used to $200 and suddenly you're charging $750, that's going to be hard for them to understand. A new client will just see this as your rate. Not impossible by any means, but important to tread more carefully with repeat clients.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Good thing to remember / mention. I think Rauri or multiple people have mentioned to do the next project of a repeat client at the previous rate and then let them know “hey I’ve upped my rate, but I got you this time”. Which is a good strategy if you want to do that

I realize it's silly, but I take comfort in staying busy and keeping my 'pirate ship' afloat. I definitely have a bottom line, but I like to work with artists to meet them at what they can afford. It keeps my work portfolio diverse and my toolkit in good working order.

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Oh of course !! Right . Send my music , drums and bass to a bus , glue it there then send it to the 2 bus to meet up with the vocal and just the final  limiter . Brilliant. That’ll give me the little bit of pumping off the low end I want

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Thanks Bryan, funnily enough it’s that action / pump coming off the low end I want , but didn’t want it pulling down the vocal . I think ed s gifted me the answer

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content:
Yay 

This mix can now arrive at perfection

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content:
Niiice , yes my structure is very similar . Added , For programmed music , I have a separate kick bus , and I tend to keep live (eg moog and or p bass ) to their own bus and 808s to their own buses also . Kick and bass might arrive to one shared bus pre 2hus if I want to clip them pre 2 bus . Tend not to clip much anymore tho  . All my drums go into  three parallels (a clean a distortion and a comp ) and those are what arrive to the drum bus . It was cians article that educated me to just how much “eq” I can do this way via distortion . This was a real level up for me . 
I do the same thing for my kick and basses and include a blown out high passed parallel to feather in at the end to tickle the tweeters once I’ve balanced the mix at the end .

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: I like a parallel for all my music elements that goes to a pitch shifted (+12) microshift , little decap and into a verb . I’ll feather that in a breakdown or chorus etc . Lovely for a little unheard icing

community_answers.author: Josh Bowman
community_answers.content: This is a great move when you wanna slam the instrumental a bit but not effect the vocals! Do it on occasion here

community_answers.author: Iwan Morgan
community_answers.content: Compress vocal and instrumental buses separately then feed both into another gentle compressor to coalesce.

community_answers.author: Chad Rodgers
community_answers.content:
Bit of an aside (still bus related) and not sure if this is the best way of doing it, but I tend to route all musical elements (non-drums and percussion) to a bus, all drums and percussion to a second bus, and all vocals to a third bus. 

I then have a further bus where I bring the musical elements together with the drums and perc, so “instrumental”.

And then my final bus which I label “all” that pushes through to the mix bus.

This way I have plenty of options for automation, levelling, compression, and even FX like whacking EchoBoy or the Echorec on it and going nuts for transitions and bridges etc.

It’s possibly not the best way of doing it but it works great for me at the mo. My template for writing / prod and mixing is just set up that way now.

question: wait. wouldn't using a low pass also shift the phase? (assuming it's not in linear  mode)

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I think it would change the phase at the frequency it's filtering at most dramatically...so probably if you filtered just a bit higher (400hz) you could cleanly tell if the low end was doing its thing. question:
Sup everyone. Just wanted to check in here for some morale/mental advice, and possibly some technical advice. 

Basically ive been workig with this artist for almost a year now, and he’s by far my biggest client (both how often he books me and how many listeners). We’ve grown really close personally, but we are currently in the midst of doing a mix for his favorite song hes done yet. He expressed to me that he is frustrated that after all this time, i am still unable to get in the ballpark for his vocal mixes within the first handful of versions. He expressed that he’d rsther a much more formulaic copy and paste approach, but i explained to him that every song is different, etc etc. in the end, we ended up importing the vocal chain from one of his older songs and it definitely sounded better, having me questioning my skills with his stuff and leaving me feeling a bit embarrassed because i worked for 2 hours on the other vocals that sounded worse (he is sending me raw untuned vocals). Lemme preface this by saying that i dont have this issue with any other client ever, and ive gotten amazing feedback from our final mixes that we’ve put out, just not the inital ones. Anybody ever struggle with this before? Not sure how i should take this and how i can be better for the sake of my work with him and others.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
Well I’ll kick things off by saying that two years with an artist is a long time and you’re bound to hit some plateaus & frustration points. These kinda of relationships really grow you over time. I’ve never made a whole record with someone where there wasn’t at least one come to Jesus moment. So you’re not alone there. 

But also- you don’t need to reinvent the wheel every time. If you’ve found something that works, letting that be a starting point shouldn’t feel like a loss, it should feel like a win. Use time served as a leg up.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: No room in this business for fragile egos. I listened to @aemaury’s Master Your Mix interview today and I think it might be a good reality check on a few levels. Mostly just encouragement.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: Be curious, tinker, learn, grow. Dont beat yourself up.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: Appreciate your vulnerability. It’s the absolute best way to be.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Without divulging too much, I know there’s a lot of second guessing and doubt you need to manage because I need to do it too. Try not to let it get you down. You do excellent work!

community_answers.author: h3x
community_answers.content: Thanks man! I think im in a weird stage of my career where Ive done some mixes that im extremely proud of and i know can hold up well in the real world, but also still feel like i dont know anything. I think hearing a client say that the vocals i did from scratch sound bad while the copy and paste ones from an older song sound good took a stab at my ego a bit. I think this is a big learning experience for me for sure

community_answers.author: h3x
community_answers.content: Appreciate u man 🙏🏻🙏🏻

community_answers.author: h3x
community_answers.content: Appreciate u man, and im glad we’re on the same page and im not alone. Gonna just have to let my ego go and do whats best for the client 🤝

question: who knows a little about synths? i have a model D by behringer and i wanna know how to patch a sound that doesn’t glide notes together

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: So you're looking for what Moog calls *multi-trigger* on their newer synths which makes the filter or amp envelopes re-trigger every time you gate a key.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: I'm looking at the Model D panel right now and I don't see a clear cut choice (terminology is always a little different). But if it's on there it's gonna be one of the 6 blue and white switches between the *mixer* and *envelope* sections.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: My money is on the *filter decay* and *loud decay* switches.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: damn when i start doing production sessions again i finna have you on speed dial.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Please do. Synths are my *thing*.

community_answers.author: hendrick

community_answers.author: hendrick
community_answers.content: i switched combinations of off and on between those 2 and i got it to work

question: does that sound right to you?

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Depends on what effect you want, but yeah. Filter decay re-triggers the filter envelope and loud decay triggers the amp envelope. Having either switch off will cause that synth component to respond in a legato way.

question: The internet can be pretty neat sometimes. I was really into New Orleans drumming in high school, which I feel really goes deep on these nuances of swung/straight—I had an instructional DVD from this very drummer talking about this very exercise, which was super helpful at the time: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8PQaU_tCbjg

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: In terms of translating this to programming... I don't do a *ton* of programming, since I'd always rather just play something 🙂 But just manipulating the placement of the upbeats is basically what he's doing here. You keep the eighth note straight, and move every *other* eighth note that's not on a beat by varying amounts... as he says, you're just trying to find the balance of where it feels good/isn't hokey.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: In the video I had in high school, he spends more time on the first exercise, which I feel like he kind of glosses over here. Just setting a metronome and playing eighths, and smoothly going from purely straight to super, over the top swung, and then smoothly transitioning back to perfectly straight is a good one to practice.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Wow. Thank you. Great recommendation and an interesting concept to think about. Drummers are so neat when they have that total control.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: On a side note, since you mentioned New Orleans drumming, I'm obligated to mention the show *Treme* that ran on HBO around 2010. That's probably the best show about music I've ever seen. It's such a celebration of the music life and it oozes with love for the art form (not to mention food and everything else it touches on). *Strong* recommendation.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Yeah! I’ve seen the first one or two episodes but fell off for some reason. I looove The Wire and I’m sure Treme is excellent, too. Will revisit!

question:
If I get through the kick and snare and find things starting to sound too ‘scooped’, I’ll try and fill in some blanks with parallel sansamp or the distortion buss. I like the distortion buss technique because if offers a consistency across all the tracks and you dont just have a distorted snare drum but pristine clean toms. Often its a Decapitator with a low shelf going into it killing some low end. I’ll solo this buss, get it to sound crunchy but not messy, then un-solo, bring the fader to neg-infinity, and blend it into taste. You’d be surprised how much excitement you get without totally fucking up the aesthetic of the drums.

As for samples? Sure! I’ve you’ve gone all-balls on these tracks and you’re still lacking what you think you need, then no shame in supplementing with samples. ‘Supplement’ being the key word here. I use the Massey DRT to extract MIDI from the kick & snare mics and then use Battery to trigger my samples. I have a few samples that just solve various problems for me. Sometimes just giving me the low end sub, or a 100 cycle knock. They can be helpful to punch your way through phasing issues and really get the meat and potatoes of the rhythm track holding its own. I will never ‘replace’ with a sample… there’s always something useful in the recorded track if you try hard enough.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
A tangent…

I’m lucky to have spent many years in a great studio with lots of great drums & gear… not to mention being mentored by one of the great engineers of our time. Having this perspective is massively useful in mixing other peoples tracks, because I feel I have a north star of what good drums can sound like if they’re recorded and performed properly. It used to be that my starting point for mixing drums were working with tracks that I had recorded myself… and most of the above problems were solved before the mix stage. These days, with smaller budgets and time constraints, its very rare that this is a possibility.

I’m including this drum tracking session from a few years ago that I recorded at Barefoot. It was for a project that Matt was producing that never saw the light of day. But we went all out with the drum setup in the big room, through the console, and had a great drummer. This might be useful for some people who have never gotten properly recorded drum tracks… to get a sense of how good thigns can sound before the ‘mix’ stage. These are the tracks that were printed into Pro Tools off of the console, and the three busses were prints of the outboard compressor busses we were using while monitoring. It’s unlikely these busses would get used in mixing, but they’re a good reference to what we were listening to in the room while we were tracking. But as you’ll notice, the individual drum blend can stand on it’s own two feet. Hopefully this is useful as well.

Thanks for coming to my Ted talk.

question: to expand on this: what is the best way of learning piano and music theory? I feel overwhelmed by all the options on youtube. Any specific course that is good?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Just a place to start - learn and practice all of the scale modes (Ionian, mixolydian, aeolian etc) and basic chords. (Major, minor, augmented, diminished, etc) 

Frankly you can start with just basic 3 note chord and expand to bigger chords and inversions. I am by no means an expert but I am a long time guitarist with 0 theory that learned theory via piano playing so hopefully this might give you a very basic direction rather than something overly technical.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: The other obvious place to start to get chops is to learn songs. Analyze them to understand the theory.

question: with learn and practice you mean able to improvise over a song key?

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: I can write you up a quick explanation and exercise of how to derive chords that "fit" with a given key or scale. I'm a little busy at the moment, but if I don't come back to this in the next day or so and you're still searching feel free to DM me.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: One thing I'll say right now is that it's important to have a good fingering technique, so that you can move around quickly and fluidly. It's going to be the foundation of your technique and I wouldn't skimp on this step. I would seek videos of people who will explain strategies for fingering major scales in each key. It's a little tiring, but repeating these fingerings until you're very comfortable with them is a necessary step to building your facility.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I should have been more specific - it’s good to run each scale up 2 octaves and back down with both hands 1 octave from each other.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt

question: what’s the benefit to add one’s initials to the filename when sending mix passes? i feel like everyone that will have access to the file will know who’s it coming from so i haven’t found the need to use it. however i see a lot of mixers doing it

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: I do it out of habit at this point, but a habit built from trying to be thorough/professional and also get credited when my shit gets used—in many situations, you may not know if there are other people submitting mixes, and to me it also just adds some clarity to file names. Also if you’re working with a team of people, initialing mixes/PT sessions/etc. can be a good way to do some forensics months later if needed; at least there’s some hint of who to ask to help you track down that one version of that one thing you need now that you didn’t think you’d need last year when you wrapped that project.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: I duplicate the .ptx file each day I work on a given song/mix, and if it’s not something I’m solely producing, I’ll add my initials as well. Maybe overkill in most situations, but helpful when you need it. 🤷🏻‍♂️

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Really it’s an AES “standard” just to stay organized.  Probably matters more if you’re in a studio facility with multiple engineers. You should look up the AES project naming convention PDF it’s wild.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: AES also recommends doing a save as if you get too stoned to be sure you’re making responsible mix decisions

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: If you’ve got the cash, +1 for the KSM 8 or 9. I tour as MD for Brett Young (country artist) and we’ve gone through the ringer looking for the perfect mics. Of course it’s different for everyone, but we like the KSM 9 on everyone in the band. We’re playing mostly arenas tho, and the drum bleed situation is real in smaller venues. question: I'm not sure if its a newbie question or not but is getting louder mixes is releated to 32 bit ? I know it has more dynamic range than 24bit so can i push it more ? Whether I want it or not there's still a loudness war going on and i just want to be able to give my clients what they want if they ask for -6 lufs.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller

expert_answers.content: More dynamic range in digital means you have more room *down*

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: Getting stuff loud is easy, just distort and limit it until all hell breaks loose. Getting stuff loud while still sounding decent is what we’re all fighting for 🤪. I would spend time learning audio basics if you really want to understand how loudness works. Matt and Jon have a few good episodes on their takes on loudness. 🙂

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: Also there really is no one magic answer or plug-in. Just Do it a lot and you will slowly figure out how to makes things sound how you want.

community_answers.author: emre

community_answers.author: rse
community_answers.content: Loudness is dependent on so many factors, it's affected by all stages of music making, from recording to production choices, to mixing, all the way to the final stages of mastering. It's something that's going to be different for every piece of music and there is indeed no secret formula.

question: Hey all, got a question about sidechaining in Ableton, specifically kicks and bass/808s. I normally just use a generic compressor when sidechaining with a soft ratio, no attack/short release, and pretty low threshold (-18 to -24) and it usually works pretty well. Sometimes however the compressor alone isn't enough to dip the 808 and allow the kick to punch through cleanly. I was going to try using F6 instead, but I can't figure out how to sidechain the kick signal itself into F6 (in Ableton at least). Any tips?

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
Should just be two steps:

On 3rd party plugins in live that allow sidechaining, you should see this little Sidechain menu show up.  So this should look really similar to the sidechain settings in the stock compressor. (1st picture)

Next, inside the plugin there should be an option to change the source of the sidechain to "external" from default internal.  With the stock Ableton plugins this happens automatically when you engage the sidechain but for 3rd party you have to add it manually.  I don't have F6 but looking up an image of the plugin it looks like the option is in the bottom right (2nd picture).

If that doesn't work then I'm not sure what's going wrong.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Gotcha - you should be able to select where the sidechain is coming from in the small plugin window on the chain - check out that first picture I attached

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Wish I had F6 so I could give you specifics on that one, hope this helps!

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Last ditch effort but looks like if you are on an older version of live the setup might be a little different:  here's the article from the manual!  https://help.ableton.com/hc/en-us/articles/209775325-Sidechaining-a-third-party-plug-in

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
Perhaps I can address your issue at the source with how you have your Ableton compressor set up:

You're saying that you cannot get your 808 to duck low enough each time the kick hits. The first thing that stands out to me is that you're using a soft ratio. You need to crank that ratio up to at *least* a 4:1 ratio, but you might be even better off with an 8:1 or higher ratio. You need a high ratio to get the deeper ducking effect that it seems you're seeking.

Using a soft ratio will never get you a big duck unless you have the threshold pulled all of the way down. And even then it's probably going to have issues recovering correctly after each duck.

community_answers.author: benigma
community_answers.content: Ah I see, it's strange because F6 has the option for sidechaining but the bottom right button only activates it and doesn't give an option for which track to route from. It also doesn't have that sidechain tab like the stock compressor or Pro-Q 3 does, so I might have to figure out another way 😩

community_answers.author: benigma
community_answers.content: but either way thank you!!

community_answers.author: benigma
community_answers.content: That's most likely where my issue lies, was definitely trying to compensate for the low ratio with unnecessarily low thresholds. I'll try much higher ratios from now on, thanks for the tip!

question: @Nomograph Mastering can you school us on sample rate once and for all ? That way we can choose one and stick with it

expert_answers.author: ehutton21
expert_answers.content: Sample rate lessons for the youth!

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Ok, worked super late. Gonna coffee up, and do this on the computer. Let’s see if I can’t be somewhat concise

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Fuck concise, go deep!!

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Ok Boyz and Girlz, buckle up. I’m trying some formatting stuff for clarity that may or may not work. I’m not sure this is the best place for this post but @Slow Hand  can advise and move or I can repost

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content:
__**Sample rates in modern record making**__

**What matters
What does not matter
And how to choose what to use**

question: __**What matters? (Even a little bit)**__

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content:
- **Higher sample rates reduce aliasing.** There is effectively no difference between 44.1 and 48k here but a meaningful difference at 96k and above. Aliasing is caused by non linear processes like distortion, and dynamics processing (compressor or limiter). Lots online about what it is and why it happens but you can sum it up by saying it’s an inharmonic, digital sounding hash that can feel bright but in a kind of ugly way (but remember sometimes ugly is good)
- **Higher sample rates reduce the impact of Anti Imaging and Anti Aliasing filters in AD to DA converters.** Filtering is necessary for accurate capture and replay of analog signals, and it in the early days of digital it used to be a real challenge. Now it’s basically a solved problem, but if you are doing acoustic music, with delicate transient information there is still a small but real advantage to higher rates
- **Higher sample rates reduce overshoot and inter sample peaks on limiters.** This really only matters if you are sending your loud mixes directly to release, otherwise your mastering girl or guy should handle that

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content:
- **More samples (slices) per second equals a better representation of the analog waveform.** Within half the band of the sample rate (say up to 22.05k for 44.1k) this is demonstrably not true. I know that is confounding, but digital and information theory is basically miraculous
- **We can hear/feel/sense sounds above 20k.** We truly really cannot and if you experiment with significant energy above 20k you’ll actually see problems creep in for electronics and speakers etc. Information above 20k is not our friend (space for harmonic information to live without aliasing back excepted)
- **Working at multiples of 44.1k is better because the sample rate conversion will work better.** This used to be a little bit true a long time ago but hasn’t been for a long time. Use the SRC in iZotope RX on it’s stock preset to 44.1 and you are in pretty good shape
- **Digital EQs work better at higher sample rates because of cramping.** Cramping was an esoteric problem with older digital EQs that looked bad on analyzers but never actually sounded very bad. It’s a solved problem nowadays with most EQs.
- **Video and film is at 48k so we must start there.** Yes film and TV still work at 48k (although YouTube specs 44.1 now) but I have sent a million tracks for sync at 44.1 and it gets dropped in with SRC and away we go

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: @Slow Hand I'm new to discord and not sure how to make this look good, particularly line spacing etc. Please edit at will or let me know how to improve

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content:
I agree, 48k is probably my default choice. 

I'd argue that it gets the AA filter far enough into ultrasonic territory as to not matter, though, and if a plugin is *designed properly* (big if, there... not many get this totally 100% right) aliasing should not be an issue.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: I don't consider it a good idea to work above 96 though, as you'll start introducing junk from switching power supplies, class D amps, noise shaping from D/A and A/D, etc into the program material. At lower sample rates it's effectively rolled out by extremely steep AA filters

question:
It seems like your square wave trick should be a best practice, since it's definitely not just master bus PDC that can throw things off. The other person's effects, or their sample rate, or working across DAWs could all contribute to misalignment.

What's your method for doing the square waves? Is there a particular plugin you like for generating the tones? Is there a specific 'low frequency' that works best?

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
Im in PT, so I just highlight an eighth note, and use the audio suite signal generator to print a 
150ish square wave, and then duplicate it every quarter note.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: No. Print. Check. If you think PDC latency is wonky you’re going to lose your mind when you find out about midi.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: I’ve got a square wave audio file I have saved in an easy spot to grab for this workflow after @BatMeckley mentioned this first

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: Imagine if they record it through a chandler 500tg pre going into an Apollo

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
I love my dear friend @BatMeckley but I think he's wrong here. Just send the instrumental how it sounds the best, and have them send you a bounced ref along with the vocal. I ask them to send me the session too as I have Pro Tools, Logic, and Ableton and can play with their processing and do a new bounce if need be.

If a vocal bounce comes back with some delay uncompensated or otherwise off the grid, lining up the vocal will NOT take you an hour. You simply line up the ref to your session and the vocal to the ref (the latter is 99% of time already done since they're bouncing from the same session). This takes a few minutes max and I've done it dozens of times. Nudge and flip some phase and you're within a couple samples. You're fine.

community_answers.content:

question: Do you think it would make sense to set up a template with a MIDI instrument set to play eighth-note sine waves at a given frequency in the pre-roll, or is entrusting the job to an instrument asking for trouble? I'm thinking of that as a possible quick way to have a sync track available at all times across LPX, PT and Ableton

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: No. Print. Check. If you think PDC latency is wonky you’re going to lose your mind when you find out about midi.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: I’ve got a square wave audio file I have saved in an easy spot to grab for this workflow after @BatMeckley mentioned this first

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: Imagine if they record it through a chandler 500tg pre going into an Apollo

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
I love my dear friend @BatMeckley but I think he's wrong here. Just send the instrumental how it sounds the best, and have them send you a bounced ref along with the vocal. I ask them to send me the session too as I have Pro Tools, Logic, and Ableton and can play with their processing and do a new bounce if need be.

If a vocal bounce comes back with some delay uncompensated or otherwise off the grid, lining up the vocal will NOT take you an hour. You simply line up the ref to your session and the vocal to the ref (the latter is 99% of time already done since they're bouncing from the same session). This takes a few minutes max and I've done it dozens of times. Nudge and flip some phase and you're within a couple samples. You're fine.

question: piano rollers: does it play any practical role in decision making?

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: I do a lot of ear training translation from pitch back to frequency - helpful when I can hum the ring I'm hearing and then figure out what note it's close to in order to get me to a starting place for where I'm looking

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: or like thinking about masking in arrangements where stuff is built up, my brain is coded for the note values first before frequencies

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Whatever sounds good to you, context is key

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: (As in, don’t necessarily do the same thing every time because you think it’s the only move you are allowed to do)

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: If it sounds good it is good

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: I find the lowest note an instrument is playing and HPF from there up (or a relevant upper harmonic of that lower note if I need more space)

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: Yeah, it’s not like a hard rule that I live by but there are a lot of situations where EQ’ing with a key, note, or harmonic series in mind is helpful

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: Pitched drums are one I use the piano roll for a lot, like toms or if there’s a very distinct snare pitch ring

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content: I didn’t know you could turn off the piano roll

question: Trust your gut but also be open right?

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: Send it and I’ll tell you the truth.

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content:
This is such an important lesson to anyone following along who's either a mixer or especially a mastering engineer. You can send someone spiraling with doubt based off of one comment, perhaps your own limited understanding of the material. 

Even the way you phrase something can make all the difference. "Hey AJ, I hear what you're going for and I love it, but I think there's room for the bass to hit harder if you can back off the levels. Just trying to to get you the vibe that I think you're going for. And if you hate it, no worries and we'll go back to your louder track."

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: I just finished getting an album mastered and had the ME ask me for a few tracks to be printed quieter, because they weren't gelling into the overall mesh of the album with the other songs. And I was fine with that. He made the case, we both listened and agreed it was better. But my tracks definitely weren't hitting -5 LUFS anyway, so it's not the same situation.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Sorry you’re going through this AJ

community_answers.author: AJ

question: So, I'm tracking this album all by myself, and I'm doing everything else, too - playing all the instruments, etc. My question is (relating to drums): If one of my rack toms is a liiiittle of out of tune, is that something I can "scosh" into place in post, or is that something I have to be dead certain about from the get-go??   Things are just getting a little wild at the moment and it's got to the point where I really don't know what I'm hearing anymore. I'm not planning on using any samples.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: You won’t be able to fix it. But also might not matter as much as people think it does.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Get them sounding like toms… and just make sure the intervals between the drums are in the ballpark of what you’re going for. And in this situation, a deader drum will work in your favor.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Tuning drums to the key of the song can sound amazing if you have the time and diligence to manage it — very difficult if it’s a one person operation. Also I’d rather a Tom have its own pitch in drum universe than being slightly sharp or flat to something in the key — that will sound even more distracting.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: The only thing I was going to add you sort of just covered here - might be worth doing a "scratch take" of the drums just to see tonally if you are in the ballpark of where you want to end up before you crank on trying to go for the final takes.

expert_answers.author: chrissorem
expert_answers.content: I agree with what Cian and Adam said. If it’s already tracked and too late to  fix tuning I’ve had success notching the resonate frequency it can help it be less of a note

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Okay, sweet! I understand everything you laid down. Thank you so much. No one has ever noticed anything wrong with my toms, but man - when it's just me going back and forth, and back and forth, and back and forth,  listening and recording. Omg. I've about reached my limit! Lol

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: And yeah - I definitely pay close attention to the pitch of my drums, but I certainly don't tune them to the key of the song. Maybe I should try that.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: This is a home studio situation as well, so I can redo things to my hearts content if need be.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Oh, we've had MAAAANNY a scratch take going on here. Lol!!

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: And if I record the song and say to myself "ya know, those toms just aren't sitting right..." I'll just re-record it. But it's getting to the point where I just need to get moving.

question: What's the simplest way to get rid of flutter echo in a small, square room? Diffusors or absorption, or something else?

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: absorbers pretty much always

expert_answers.author: chrissorem
expert_answers.content:
Remove two of the walls.
Kidding. What David said should solve it

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
You could probably kill it by simply putting even just blankets on the offending wall(s).

Basically put stuff on the walls, clap, and if you no longer hear flutter, you did it

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: You’d need to do put absorption at least two walls, particularly ones next to each other,  as to catch the parallel high frequency of reflections of each pair of walls

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: FWIW, when I end up using m/s eq it's for problem solving

community_answers.author: Rob Domos
community_answers.content:
Just reading through what you and @river were talking about and I’d like to balance this perspective out a little bit.

While I’d agree that things like midside EQ can make things sound strange in a way I don’t like, I’m not shying away from decoupling the mids from the sides in general or saying M/S = Bad. Turning down the M channel on elements that I want to have be more background surrounding elements with a plugin like CenterOne is actually one of my most common mix moves and it sounds great.

A good friend of mine who has made one of my favorite mixes of all time constantly talks about his use of M/S processing. I don’t do much M/S other than levels and stereo imagining, but my boi does regularly and he sounds great. 

All that to say: River,  It’s worth being careful and listening to what could be getting fucked up in your midside processing, I wouldn’t be M/S EQing personally, and you should generally only do M/S moves with speakers and generally not with headphones, but that doesn’t mean that you should shy away from M/S all together if it sounds really good to you. Lots of great engineers are using it all the time.

community_answers.author: river
community_answers.content:
I rarely do M/S EQ moves, but I am always EQing gently so they're usually safe moves.

Thank you for the advice about doing M/S with speakers. This is a thing I had not thought about!! Stereo vs binaural is something I forget about sometimes

question: How I started my career in music? Or how I got a job at a recording studio? Or both?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Hoo boy. Tell you what, here's something I wrote about it 10 years ago... maybe it'll still be useful.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
I started getting serious about recording while I was in college (studying chemistry). I was playing bass in a band at the time and I was the only one that had any sort of decent recording equipment. I found myself being the guy recording all of the band's demos before we went into a 'proper studio'. Eventually, we realized my demos were sounding better than the ones we paid other people to record! Meanwhile, I started assisting (for free) at a local small recording studio and met a really great mentor. The studio was small and its business was mostly weekend warrior type stuff – nobody really notable. That being said, it was a working studio – and booked almost 6-7 days a week. The producer was the big fish in the small pond and had a great repeat clientele. Most of the music was not my cup of tea – but this proved to be a good thing as I was exposed to all sorts of different styles and it allowed me to be comfortable in genres of music which I normally wouldn't gravitate towards. It just made me comfortable around music and musicians in general.

Once I graduated and decided I wasn't going to use my chemistry degree, I ended up helping the producer build a bigger studio complex from the ground up. I learned an insane amount of stuff during this period – whether it was researching which Pro Tools system we would need to helping design the wiring layout to actually implementing it all. Ultimately, after months of hard work (and lots of borrowed money) the studio was complete and it was ready for business. I worked here for 2 years or so until I got introduced to Eric Valentine through former Street To Nowhere guitarist Matt Radosevich in Los Angeles. He needed a new full-time assistant and so I hopped at the opportunity and moved to LA – leaving behind the studio and crew I helped build (they're still going today and they're doing great).

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
Making the jump from working on music for local bands to making music for bigger commercial acts was obviously a big move forward. What I realized very quickly is that the process is fundamentally the same with people of all levels. You get in a room, you make a plan, and you execute it. However, when you've got a major label backing you, there's many more resources available, enabling you to spend more time (and money) making the record... although in my experience this can be both a blessing and a curse!

I assisted Eric for a few years and eventually started networking with more local Los Angeles artists and was able to mix and produce their stuff out of Eric's studio. He was very cool about letting me use the space when we weren't working on bigger projects. He set a very high standard and made it clear that anything that left our studio had to sound really, really great. After assisting and working on my own stuff for several years, Eric then hired me as his full-time main engineer and now I'm on call to work on him for any of his projects. This has been amazing in so many ways as I get to work on high-level commercial music and apply all of my own sensibilities to the process – as well as the stuff I've learned from Eric over the years.

Obviously my tale is one in a million and there's not a day that goes my where I don't realize how lucky I am. Now that I've worked full time recording music for almost 8 years, I've realized there are certain things you need to have to be successful:

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: @M3MIYAGI I say this as someone who received a similar email from Cian a little over a decade ago: this advice is all gold

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Just a small note: when you say you weren’t feeling their system, that reads as a possible red flag. Assuming these studios are not run by total hacks (and therefore worthy of you not wanting to be involved), you’re most likely going to have to work on lots and lots of stuff you don’t like, for a long time. And that might apply to working in ways you wouldn’t personally choose. But—again, assuming these studios are at least semi-decent—you’ll learn a lot by involving yourself in other peoples’ work flows. Then you can take it or leave it as you see fit in your own work.

community_answers.author: shaunobi
community_answers.content: I follow a similar approach when doing blue-sky producing - I'll prep song I like beforehand, splitting them into stems using UVR (which uses the best machine learning algos like Demucs v4 to split tracks). When people get there, I then play just the drums, or whatever, and we start layering other stuff on top of them. I speed it up, slow it down, use various parts, cut and paste - basically just to get something that inspires me during composition. Later, I'll come back with real musicians and actually record it, but this is a pretty powerful demo creation method, for me at least. Kinda fun to un-mute the OG track at the end and be like "yeah, it's been Interpol this whole damn time :)"

question: What does your loudness look like for delivering to mastering? In the past when I spoke with my longtime engineer they told me they preferred that I don't even put a bus compressor on the print but now that I am branching out that seems to be an exception rather than a rule. Should also say that I recognized your name immediately, I had a chance to produce a mini mansions show some years ago and became a big fan of that band.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Oh fuck yea, MM forever! I usually just trim the input of my final limiter (almost always the Ozone maximizer) 5dB and call it a day. All of the compression/limiting/clipping thats happening on various busses beforehand stay the same. I try to not lean on the final limiting stage to heavily in building the 'loudenss' of the mix, but I know that's not the case for everybody. If there was an instance where it was really part of the sound, I'd just leave it and send it off. Any mastering engineer worth their salt should be OK working with whatever you send them. If there are glaring issues, they're likely to bring it up... but most mixers I know don't even peel back the limiter a little... so the loudness is fully baked into the mix.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: We put together a primer for preparing mixes for mastering. Loudness and how to approach it is covered: https://www.livewithmattrad.com/resources/preparing-your-files-for-mastering

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Obviously, I'm much less experienced than all these guys - But a few years ago I went through a NIGHTMARE situation with a producer who wouldn't give me my tracks (I also co-wrote a bunch of songs for him that I'm sure I should be getting some kickback from and whatever else, but whatever...). Once it got to be too much, I started looking for an entertainment lawyer. Ended up with a guy who used to manage Travis Truit or something and he offered to write my ex-producer a letter for free. Really nice and helpful guy - for the little guys. So, yeah. Thank goodness I'm self-produced now and don't need anything from anybody, but the next time I do get involved with anyone in a production capacity or mixing or whatever and I feel like I'm deserving of a certain something, I intend to call Sam up and get things squared away before I start. Also, I'll add that the toll it took on my health - struggling with that producer basically in isolation, wasting time, feeling powerless, etc. etc. - was not negligible. That situation actually made me physically ill, and none of us artist types deserve that. So - take care of yourself.

question: Is there a good channel I can watch to get started?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I'll defer to others on here who might be newer to the game... I'm 20 years in at this point so the learning tools are very different.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: But if you're familiar with other DAWs, you're 3/4 the way there. Its setup very intuitively to resemble the workflow of an analog mixer & recorder.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: You make a track, you set an input, and you set an output. Pan, volume, effects sends, etc... solo, mute on each channel. Give it a spin, you'll know more than you think.

question: Out out curiosity, who here is recording drums last?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: My least ideal situation, but I do it often.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: But if I was a one man shop working on a solo project like yourself, save the headache and do drums first.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Not quite. Drums first, layer up. Build the house from the foundation. Don’t start with the roof.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: Usually when I’m working alone, I’ll sketch rough midi drums, a couple of loops, etc. then lay down a guitar or two and a rough vocal on top of that, if it takes more than two hours, you’re over cooking it. Then I send that to my drummer, who plays actual drums to that rough. I then build all the keeper takes on top of that real drum track.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan

ExFAT has given me problems so I avoid it. It seems to work for some other folks but these days my go to is a SSD running APFS. I gravitate towards the Samsung T7, they’ve been super reliable. Avoid SanDisk, but I think there are some other folks using things from other brands like Crucial.

Hard drives are super susceptible to damage and weird mechanical failure when moving them around, and they’re much slower. Do yourself a favor and work from a solid state (and keep everything backed up in multiple places)

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: That unsafe ejecting part can really mess up a hard drive because the final writing of some files (even if it seems like any transfers are finished) can get interrupted, leading to corruption. It may not even be apparent immediately

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: And always operate under the presumption that any drive can fail at any time

question: This might be a dumb question. If I have a dual channel-tube compressor/limiter. Should one be weary of using only one side for recording purposes? I’m thinking difference in tube lifespan etc.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: I wouldn’t, you could always flop to using the “other side” every other session if you’re worried about it

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Not a dumb question, but no, that's not the thing that causes tubes to wear out (though it's logical to think that would be the case) - rather, having them on causes the cathode to gradually wear out, and turning them off and on again will cause the heater to eventually fail like an incandescent lightbulb.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Not solely but definitely the bigger factor

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: An easier way to think about it, when either channel needs new tubes you will be replacing both channels anyway

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: And today is the day it find those tubes and order so you have on hand!

question: Example of "automated backup": A setup where something is copied to another drive in real time? Or to the Cloud?

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Same thing. Backing up to the cloud is just backing up to a hard drive on a computer somewhere else. The point being, you want to set up a backup routine that doesn’t require your intervention so you can set it up once and be  covered.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Lotta people around here on Backblaze

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Backblaze would be great. Most professionals here will have several stages of failure for backups, but in your situation, I would not reccomend getting sucked into this rabbit hole. Either A) Setup backblaze, have it backup to cloud all the time, and get on with it or B) Setup a secondary drive that you copy files to at the end of every working day. If you use a program, so be it. This can be as simple as dragging the session files over and replacing the previous files.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Don't spend more time or money setting up some crazybrained infrastructure... you're not there yet.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Yeah man. As long as the files are in two different places you're good. Back to drum editing and IR tinkering!

question:
Mixing strategies for guitar band music : 

I’m v familiar with effective gain staging and transient / tone shaping of composite parts of a mix  for rnb and hip hop …..however not so for the relationship between rythm guitars and vocals in guitar bands music . I wondered if the vets had developed any simple guiding principle about this particular relationship when finding a good balance . The guitar as an instrument is presenting me with a lot of questions about masking and level relative to the vocal , it sits so close/ across many of  the vocal Hz . How do ya ll approach this interplay . Are you scooping  700 - 2 kHz for example to make space for the vocal ? Etc etc . And this is for rhythm guitars only . 

I started as a guitar player in a band so I totally see the guitarists view on music , but I left guitar bands in my teens and am only returning to this music now as a mixer moving into new genres from club /rnb / hip hop background . Recurring dilemma : Drums bass and guitar no vocal , the mixes bang . Put the vocal in . Guitar and vocals aren’t speaking together . Drums bass and vocal no guitar , mixes are banging .

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: 🙅🏼‍♂️🙏🏼 (ps . The mixes are popping I just want it all to speak beautifully together )

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Any thoughts much appreciated 🕊️

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
Looking forward to other answers here, but considering that 700-2k is the so much of the sound of the electric guitar I’m much less inclined to scoop there.  In fact if the guitars only lived 700-2k I bet your vocal would pop easily. (Hard to tell without source material of course.)

But, philosophically, it’s way more about panning. You guitars can be huge if they’re on the sides.

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Thank you Noah . I follow what you’ve said there about the 700-2khz area being so much of the sound …..which is where I’m having this “dilemma “ …thank you also for the reminder re : panning . Cians mixes always educate me with respect to panning . I think it’s time to listen again to some st Vincent and the Jane’s addiction record . Thanks Noah for your ideas

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: ….this is awesome gents thank you

community_answers.author: cy (sigh)
community_answers.content: not as much exp as others  but I've learned that you have to be okay with some lopsided feel more often than in the other genres you're used to.  especially if you're dealing with contrasting /dueling  guitars

community_answers.author: cy (sigh)
community_answers.content: also depending on the type of music, the vocal doesn't always  need to be as clear. sometimes the guitars swallowing up some of the enunciation will give you what you  need . coming from the other genres we tend to want the vocals to be super audible but I've found that can take away from the overall feel and detach the voice too much from the song

community_answers.author: Chad Rodgers
community_answers.content: Agree with the above. I used to be a bit brutal and completely hi pass the low mids for guitars, making my band mixes sound a lot more like my pop mixes, but right now I’ve been enjoying letting those low mids through in guits for the body. Similar to the above it’s hugely about feel and it’s nice to really *feel* those guitars as opposed to just hear them. A bit like if you were sat in the room with an amp, or in a small venue in front of the stage… definitely a case for abandoning mixer brain.

community_answers.author: andrew_yv
community_answers.content:
Here’s a simplified experiment you can do to explore what’s going on when it comes to audible phase shifts within  a track.
Create a bunch of tracks with sine test tones, ideally harmonically related so you don’t go crazy and so reinforcement/interference patterns are more noticeable, and just start flipping or rotating phase on some of them. See what if anything you hear.
I’m not deep enough on this to have the answer on a plate, but I think when we talk about hearing phase shifts on a single track, the times when that will be noticeable are when we have a lot of harmonically related content and they can either create constructive or destructive interference patterns depending on their phase. You’re going to see changes in peak amplitude and I think that’s a big factor. But yeah it’s subtle stuff and not always the most significant factor in how things sound

community_answers.author: tinkerjef
community_answers.content: Yeah so the phase relationship between individual tracks is known to create an audible difference, however the phase of a single track is what I’m interested in

question: I think the general consensus I got was highlighted by slow hand, which was multiple sounds together, phase matters, single sounds, not so much.

question: Well you've likely made a quality jump from your cheap sennies and ATHs. You say you don't like them for mixing -- how much time have you spent working on them? Usually it takes a while to acclimate to a listening device/environment so you can get good results mixing on them.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Might be worth hanging onto them and digging in a little bit more.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: No right answer with headphones… everyone responds differently to them. It’s all about results… if you can make things that sound good outside of your studio, then you’re on the right track.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Also better monitoring might just take you from point A to B quicker. IME if I have to mix on closed backs it ends up being a slower process even if the end result may be similar as to open backs

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: But really if you have speakers that’s where the majority of your time should be spent

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
One thing that’s important when getting acclimated is listening to a LOT of music. If the monitoring is truly good, when you listen to your favorite records you’ll be able to hear things in a fresh way, sometimes details you’ve never noticed will jump out.  

And then when you go back to your record you should be able to hear the distance between the two things fairly quickly. Things like low end, transient response, reverb tails, midrange detail (or lack thereof if you make metal) etc. 

Sometimes just the fact that you can *hear* things makes you feel like it sounds good, but the key is to know what “good” is for each case.

question: This has been my first experience managing myself as a producer and I feel a little stuck in the whole deals side of things. I have a great lawyer. It’s a major label artist. But…who is actually supposed to have the conversation negotiating fees and points? Lawyer to lawyer? Me to manager? Me directly to label? I kind of feel like an idiot asking this but it’s not written down anywhere. My old manager was so good at this but he is retired and I’m wanting to respect the boundary.

expert_answers.author: chrissorem
expert_answers.content: You could create a fake manager email for the meantime so that you it isn’t “you” negotiating

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
Deal points generally get approved by the artist, cause it’s the artist side it comes out of. There are sort of standard rates when you work on stuff like this so it shouldn’t be too big of an issue to hammer it out. 

As long as you’re not tryna do something out of the ordinary, my suggestion is that you have the chat with whomever you’re closest too, artist or manager.

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: Yea there are very few cases where I think talking directly to the artist is best and this would not be one of them. Fake manager is not the move in my opinion. Im going to get ahold of lawyer first then connect w the manager who I have a solid relationship with. Thanks guys.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I am in this situation and if it's major label or major artist, I'm having my attorney work out the deal. They will be in touch with artists management & legal and hash it out. All to the tune of 5% of the total fee.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: If its an indie label or indie artist, I'll give the option to send over a boilerplate mix agreement to see if I can keep my lawyer out of it and save the 5%. About 20-30% of the time, their lawyer gets involved anyways and I end up bringing in my legal to make sure things are taken care of.

community_answers.author: Calvin Lauber
community_answers.content: In my experience with major label stuff,  it’s always been a conversation had lawyer to lawyer, usually the artist/management proposes a deal conveyed through their lawyer to mine, and then we have a quick chat about things that might be missing or could be better for me, my lawyer conveys that back. I don’t personally communicate with the artist directly in these kinds of deals, it’s great to be able to keep that separate when possible

question: The thing I wanted to ask about is, how do you deal with notes where you feel that it's making their song worse?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I often tell people that V1 is for me. It's what I want to hear. I get all my jollies off on that mix and paint the picture the way I see it. After that, it's time to hang the ego up and let them have their say. Ultimately its their song, with their name on it, and they'll have to do the work to release it and actualize it in the world. Best thing you can do is support them along the way.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: If you've made your case for how you envision it, and they still disagree, I will always defer to them.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: It sounds like there will be more opportunities down the road given your lovely, organic success story.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
@chrissorem @Nomograph Mastering @NoahNeedleman This essay does a great job at unpacking what it takes to participate and succeed in any kind of venture, and how the people who endure have their own unique madness that makes them the right fit for it.
https://www.experimental-history.com/p/face-it-youre-a-crazy-person

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
This is a constant in record making. Balancing your own thoughts with those of your client or collaborators. 

Cian is right on of course, but I’d encourage you not to think of it as binary. Almost always, there’s a version of their note that makes the song better, and it’s your job to hear it. 

In the end, it’s their record tho, and they’re the ones who will be playing it out, selling it, promoting it however they can… so they’re the ones who *need* to be happy with it in the end. 

My longtime producer & collaborator Jon Kaplan used to say “it’s your record, you can be wrong if you want to.” I give that to artists I work with now. Going in I tell them I’m going to treat you like an equal, until you tell me it’s your record and you can be wrong if you want to. 

Honestly that one idea has eased the tension on so many occasions for me.

community_answers.author: sarawls
community_answers.content: And for any of you lurkers that are trying to get people to pay you to record them, this is obvious, but I can tell you it works SO WELL.  Whatever artist you record, go to their shows.  Be cool, in both the "hip" sense of the word and the "nice and easy person to be around" sense of the word.  Even better, have your band play with them and be good.  People start lining up to have you record them.  It's crazy.

community_answers.author: sarawls
community_answers.content: Playing in bands my whole life and paying other people to record my bands, a lot of the studio people I knew were kind of hermits.  Go to as many shows as you can.  With locals playing.

community_answers.author: Josh Bowman
community_answers.content: Make it sound and feel as finished as you can. Then let the ME  see if/where they can elevate it further. I think in modern record making, except in really specific relationships where it’s been communicated, the best result comes from everyone at every stage doing their absolute best and then passing it onto the next person.

question: Are they loud or run hot like do they need to be in a separate room from the control room?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Easiest way is grab a cable or some string, put it on the center of the snare (or on the right side of the rim, closest to the kick) and measure out each overhead to its capsule. Match that and it’s a great starting place.

expert_answers.content: @hendrick these are awesome!

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: FYI, They're playing a steel string in the Usher video, but it's still a nylon on the recording.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: The other big difference is the neck/fingerboard shapes. Steel string necks are typically akin to electric guitars. If you can play electric guitar you'll pick up a steel string easy, while a nylon guitar takes a little bit of adjustment because the fretboards are much wider and the string spacing is wide to match. It's nothing you can't get used to, but it can lead you to different playing styles on each.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Now all that said, Ovation guitars are somewhat unique. They've got that plasticky back, instead of wood, which can make for a more biting, articulate, tone. They can sometimes be a bit hybrid in their sound and form factor. So again, just put your hands on the guitar, if you can, and see how it feels/sounds to you. If it sounds good and it feels good it is good.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: maybe someone can chime in but i'm not really sure what you mean. there's no difference if the audio on the buss and the audio track is the same

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: No difference sonically, just all workflow, resource management, etc. Sends harken to a time when outboard effects were limited, so it made sense to send things to a plate so you didn't have to have 20 giant EMT plates in your studio to put on each track you wanted reverb on. Nowadays, in the computer, it's less important and just comes down to workflow. Sometimes some mixes call for a more uniform reverb to tie tracks together... in this case putting it on a send makes more sense. But there's no rules anymore, and if you don't like that workflow, then fuck it. Do it your way. There's no right or wrong on this.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: if you have a reverb or delay on a bus, you could get more dry signal without opening a plug-in, just by raising the original fader a bit if the send is pre vs post fader. I use this method things where I’m trying to make the verb an atmosphere and not change the tone of the original track, that way it’s easier to do reverb throws with my faderport.

question: What instrument are you recording? It's hard to give feedback without more context.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Sounds like your room has a buildup in that frequency area so, yea, I’d say it’d be normal to want to scoop it out.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Could be your monitoring as well telling you that.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: It may be worth moving the location of both the mic and the performer. As @cian riordan says, you may be getting some build-ups because the performer, the mic, or both are placed in the middle of an acoustic node that is accentuating or sucking the energy out of particular frequencies at that point in the room. Try moving performer and mic by increments of 12"-18"  and listen to whether or not that improves the sound or works against it.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Additionally, if your mic is placed low, close to the performer's chest, that may be giving some extra resonance from the singer's torso at they sing. Raising the mic higher and away from their torso could change the balance of low-frequency energy for the better.

question:
If it already sounds good to you as is, perhaps you don’t need to worry about  editing it to “perfection”. Follow your intuition here and do what sounds good. 

One can certainly edit tracks into oblivion with certain techniques and before you know it you’ve got a sterile-sounding feel on your record.

I would start by asking yourself “What am I trying to achieve?” and then if you still feel that it needs some editing go for it, rather than working from a technique that you saw someone do and shoe-horning your music into it.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Always always always edit things before adding new things. @BoozleBAM 

Whether or not to edit super to the grid is 100% a creative choice in feel.

That super gridded feel can feel more polished. 

A more natural performance can be more emotive. 

Both are effective at making amazing songs.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Performance > tone always.
Editing and making everything how it should be is more important than the EQ. If things are fucky time wise in a bad way it’ll never feel good.

expert_answers.content: If your in protools just playlist it 🤷

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: My first move before beat detective is saving the unedited take to a playlist. Then I can edit fearlessly and always pull from that without any worry if something is weird or needs to be natural.

question: Here's two examples of songs with nylon guitar: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ihpcN_vns0k

expert_answers.content: @hendrick these are awesome!

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: FYI, They're playing a steel string in the Usher video, but it's still a nylon on the recording.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: The other big difference is the neck/fingerboard shapes. Steel string necks are typically akin to electric guitars. If you can play electric guitar you'll pick up a steel string easy, while a nylon guitar takes a little bit of adjustment because the fretboards are much wider and the string spacing is wide to match. It's nothing you can't get used to, but it can lead you to different playing styles on each.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Now all that said, Ovation guitars are somewhat unique. They've got that plasticky back, instead of wood, which can make for a more biting, articulate, tone. They can sometimes be a bit hybrid in their sound and form factor. So again, just put your hands on the guitar, if you can, and see how it feels/sounds to you. If it sounds good and it feels good it is good.

Some 'pre-amps' that I do come out of the box for distortion on a regular basis are: Ampex 351 (god bless this thing) and the Scully 280. But I'm looking for real distortion that I'm typically using in parallel, nothing subtle. I use Spectre/Saturn/Decapitator/Neutron for that stuff.
