question:
Process/Theory:
I see lots of people’s previous responses say they begin with getting the overheads to sound great and then start blending in close mics. If the drums were recorded by someone who knew what they were doing, with a good sounding kit, in a nice room — this would be a wonderful way to approach things. However 90% of the time that’s not the case with tracks that come my way. So I’m solving fro two problems — making the drums:
1) The foundational rhythm element. It doesn’t matter how good tonally your drums sound, they need to fill specific duties to carry the rhythm of the song. This is usually problem solving with phase within the elements of the drum set and then mostly getting the kick and snare to sit right around the rest of the instruments. Literally getting the right transients in the right frequency ranges — agnostic of ‘tone’ and ‘vibe’.
2) The sense of space for the mix. The drums are a huge part of this… and the foundation for the aesthetic of a mix. Is it a tight space? Big verby snare? This is all great, but will rarely deal with this stuff until #1 is taken care of. So my process starts with close mics.

After poking around and listening to the close mic various options to get a sense of what I’m working with, I’ll start with getting everything in phase. Solo the kick drum mics and get those in phase with each-other. If they don’t add up, I’ll start playing with HP filters at various Q’s to try and get things closer. You’d be surprised what you can get away with even when things are even 90 degrees out. Then, I’ll start introducing more spot mics (snare, toms, HH) and start getting things in focus with just phase flips. By the time you get to the overheads and rooms, you should have all the spot mics in phase with each-other so then you can get a better sense of how the overheads are going to play into the game.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
I'll gate everything with the Pro-G. Usually as tight as I can while sometimes automating threshhold to make sure ghostnotes don't get lost. I'll peel back the ratio once I have everything triggering properly to let some bleed in to taste. Sometimes I'll only gate 2-3 dB to just get something to pop. Sometimes its in a vaccum.
I will very rarely compress individual drum mics. And I pray that the recording engineer didn’t either. I like most of my compression to come from the busses. It sounds more natural to my ear and allows you to get away with a more compressed, exciting sound than just whacking the close mics. I’ll find at the beginning my drum mixes will be very ‘pokey’ — I want each drum to sound explosive and over the top. That way when i start compressing them, they maintain their transient quality when they start getting dynamically reduced.

I’m always cutting tons of 250-350 out of the kick drums and trying to manufacture any attack with saturation instead of EQ. Having a SansAmp or a Saturn plugin adding high end always sounds more natural to me than just additive EQ. I’m always very wary of the 2-5khz region, and find even-order harmonics are the best bet to fill in the blanks there.

I tend to like my snare drums warm, so often low-shelving down the super low end and keeping the 150-300 ‘boosh’ intact. I try to avoid using HPF on drum mics because at this point, things should be relatively in phase, so if I put a filter on, it’s going to throw the whole kaboodle off whack. Shelves are your friend here. And same as with the kick drums re: adding high end — I’m wary off adding the snap in the 2-5khz range, I’ll try and have the body of the snare drum really singing so I only have to add a little bit of top end, often above 5khz just for some air.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
A tangent…

I’m lucky to have spent many years in a great studio with lots of great drums & gear… not to mention being mentored by one of the great engineers of our time. Having this perspective is massively useful in mixing other peoples tracks, because I feel I have a north star of what good drums can sound like if they’re recorded and performed properly. It used to be that my starting point for mixing drums were working with tracks that I had recorded myself… and most of the above problems were solved before the mix stage. These days, with smaller budgets and time constraints, its very rare that this is a possibility.

I’m including this drum tracking session from a few years ago that I recorded at Barefoot. It was for a project that Matt was producing that never saw the light of day. But we went all out with the drum setup in the big room, through the console, and had a great drummer. This might be useful for some people who have never gotten properly recorded drum tracks… to get a sense of how good thigns can sound before the ‘mix’ stage. These are the tracks that were printed into Pro Tools off of the console, and the three busses were prints of the outboard compressor busses we were using while monitoring. It’s unlikely these busses would get used in mixing, but they’re a good reference to what we were listening to in the room while we were tracking. But as you’ll notice, the individual drum blend can stand on it’s own two feet. Hopefully this is useful as well.

Thanks for coming to my Ted talk.

question: How close do you put your vocalist to a mic? I’ve almost always done pretty dang close to the mic because anything else seems too roomy / spacious / unfocused. But I see and hear people singing several inches away. What am I missing?

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content:
room tone and proximity effect are why.

If you have a great sounding room you can back off the mic and you’ll introduce room tone, or the sound of the room into the mic’d bleed.

If you have a dead room you can back off with this happening less, there will still be some sound there, but less.

A lot of studio mics are used with the Cardioid polar pattern depending on the source and what sound you need for the recording, getting closer to the mic can introduce more low end from what’s know as proximity effect, this can exaggerate the way the lows are heard from the source on a record.

If you find yourself EQing out low end, maybe back off the microphone a bit and experiment with how far and hear how much room gets introduce as you add more preamp gain when you do this.

It’s a choice, and a decision, learn why you like it and where.

Omni mics have little to no proximity effect, figure 8 also have some proximity effect, use this to your advantage.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: great answer! @Zack Hames it's worth playing with different distances to see how it sounds in the context of each song. just make sure you match gain because of course being farther away will be lower in volume. but you may find that a little bit of room bleed in a song isn't so bad, and you might like the balanced tone better being a few inches away from the mic. I've been playing with this effect for about 25 years and even yesterday had an artist at the house where we did vocal takes at different distances from the mic. never stop experimenting and learning!

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: In the last few years I’ve been doing vocals with an Omni mic, but pretty close, still get a little room, but not so much boom

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: Did this exact thing tonight on a hype vocal. Ended up 12 inches away with the u87 on Omni and compressing the shit out of it on the way in. Super cool way to put the hype man behind the lead without a bunch of itb work.

question: Anyone have any good tips or techniques for recording backing vocals? Mic recomendations, mic techniques, etc

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: The easiest thing is just different mic positioning. The classic is to stand a few feet back from the mic and record BVs that way. If you have multiple mics, just try a different mic for BVs. See if you like the contrast. It's a creative decision more than anything else. Close mic, stacked harmonies with the same mic as the lead vocal also sound nice. Just depends what you're after. Experiment and let your ears decide!

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: One approach that hasn't been mentioned is using a different singer/singers for the backgrounds so that they contrast the lead vocalist. That can add a ton of character to a track and keep the timbre from being same-y.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Or, if you don't have other singers handy, adopt a "character" when performing your backgrounds. Kendrick Lamar is great at this. If he's tracking a chorus (group of vocalists) responding to his lyrics they'll have a distinct affect to differentiate the different narrative personalities.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Trey Spruance once described his process for multi-tracking a string section using one violinist (I'm paraphrasing): "After each string take I give the player a new prompt about their personality: "Now you're second violin and you're gunning for first-chair's spot, so you're gonna be trying a little too hard and playing just a hair too loud to get the conductor's notice. You've got something to prove." or "Now you're 6th chair and you're just happy to be here. Your vibrato is going to be a little lax." Etc, etc, etc.

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content: To my ears M50s sound very congested, especially in comparison to their direct competition - Beyer 770s(I own both). The transients(which for me are absolutely crucial to hear when producing or mixing) are almost inaudible on the M50s, while decently audible on the 770s. I do not find the M50s or the 770s even close to "well balanced", they both are a bit too budget for that distinction(they both have extreme presence peaks at their respective frequencies). I know someone who is very happy with the Shure SRH940s and Shure 1840s for critical listening(same drivers, I think). The M50s and 770s are both pretty much unusable in the low end under 50-60hz for me, I don't feel they translate well there. A few mastering engineers use the Blue closed-back headphones as a low-end reference, they would probably be worth a try. Audeze stuff is pretty good for transient response, but more expensive.

question: 24 bit vs 32 bit mixing? What are the benefits of upsampling to 32 bits?

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Unless you're doing scientific testing, I would think that there is very little reason to ever need 32 bits of audio information when making music. 24 bits of dynamic range is already huuuge.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: We listen to most records in 16 bit and that sounds fine. 17 bits is *double* that resolution. 18 bits is *quadruple* that resolution. By using 24 bits we've increased the resolution of the dynamic range 256 times compared to a 16 bit signal. I've never seen any evidence that we can hear the difference between 24bits of audio and 32 bits.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: I think there's a case to be made for DSP processing in your plugins at 24bit vs 16bit, in order to avoid artifacts. But I think to go higher would be diminishing returns.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Happy to help. I suspect someone else may eventually chime in with something that I've overlooked, so check back in later.

community_answers.author: thejadenmejia
community_answers.content: Thank you so much for all the help! Very detailed and clear. I was reading a sound on sound article on Clint Gibbs and he stated that the first thing he does is upsample the project from 24 to 32. He gave no reasoning as to why so I thought I would ask here. Thank you once again 😎

question: How much of an impact does your front wall treatment make/how wide is it? Getting my build together finally

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: the concept is to couple your speakers to the front wall to remove or minimize SBIR and to leverage the room gain you get by being up against the boundary and then treat that energy at the rear wall. you will see most folks recommend this approach in small room contexts. i forget what exactly is considered an acoustically small room but most all residential rooms fall into this bucket.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: I found this to be true in my current studio. There was a null somewhere around 80hz with my speakers a little further out, and moving them closer to the wall lowered that null in frequency significantly. Not sure if this is what the science says, but that seemed to be my experience. Got it much less in a critical zone, then threw some bass traps on either side of the speakers and lessened it even more.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: If you have the space for it and your monitors can be mounted as such, soffits are a great idea

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: It removes the influence of sbir entirely and actually improves bass response by making effectively an infinite baffle

question: Yea pressing the album to vinyl . Any advise ? 🙇🏻‍♂️

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
I would tell them there's a few things to consider when pressing vinyl:
1) Mastering is especially important as it’s the real bridge between the music and the mechanical production of the record. I had the great pleasure of mastering a few records for vinyl with Doug Sax (give him a google) and there’s a lot more to the process than modern mastering for digital services. They will actually cut the acetate disc which will be what manufacturers use to make the metal stamper that actually molds the records. A lot of thought goes into this process such as the width of the grooves to accommodate bass frequencies, etc. If you want a good sounding record, there’s no way around working with a seasoned professional.

2) Side lengths are important, as is track order. The more music you put on a side of vinyl, the less fidelity it will have as a whole. There will be sacrifices in the manufacturing to accommodate all of the music, so it’s best to keep your side lengths under 20 mins. Closer to 15 mins per side is ideal sonically, but sometimes that means doing double records and that just gets expensive. Also the order in which the tracks play on each side plays a part. The songs at the beginning of the side have more bandwidth and less distortion… it basically diminishes the closer you get to the center. Whatever the last track on the side is will just sound worse. It’s a flaw in the medium… so think about that.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
3) Not all manufacturers are created equal. With vinyl pressing plants months behind on their bookings, there are many budget plants that seem to be doing things for cheaper and quicker. You get what you pay for. QRP in Kansas are the best in the business. RTI in CA used to be the gold standard, but they dogged me real hard on a project about 10 years ago and never made things right. Even Doug Sax had to step in to set them straight.

The short of it is, if someone is venturing down the path of manufacturing vinyl for their project — *especially* if it’s self funded — they have to ask what they’re really looking to achieve. If they want a high-quality, analog preservation of their record for all to enjoy, then they need to be prepared to spend some real coin to achieve good results. If they just want a physical item to sell at shows and toss in a download code — that’s OK too — but it will still be pricey, and probably won’t sound great if you do it on the cheap. Just my $0.02.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Ok damn. Lemme clear my schedule and write my manifesto… brb.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
Mixing Drums:

After now listening to many of Jon & Matt’s podcasts, as well as existing on this discord for a while, I’ve found myself feeling a little perplexed by people’s ability to mix things so fast. It finally clicked that many folks these days (especially in the pop world) are getting stems to mix from — not full multitrack sessions — and often not real drumsets/instruments in real rooms. In my world, for better or worse, I’m almost always getting multitrack files. So the prospect of only spending 2-3 hours on a mix is just impossible. That will often times barely get me past the drum sound! So for us mere mortals that are still stuck mixing real instruments, here’s my process for approaching drum mixing.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
Template:
I’ve attached a slimmed down version of my mix template with all of the drum bussing. This has evolved over many years and has taken many forms, but it’s really just a good starting point for me and speeds up my workflow quite a bit. I’ve got three main busses that feed into a master drum buss. ‘DRUM SUB’ is my uncompressed (or lightly compressed) buss. ‘DRUM PAR’ is my heavily compressed buss, and ‘DRUM DIST’ is my parallel distortion buss. I don’t necessarily always use these, but having them ready to go makes it easier to quickly audition different ideas. Sometimes I’ll duplicate one or two of them to get another flavor involved. Again, everything to taste. 

Also in the template are some very basic aux’s I find myself using often. There are two parallel SansAmp busses. I have two because often times if I use one on the kick drum, it rarely works for the snare drum, so I have a second one ready to go. There’s also a ‘SNARE SLAP’ and ‘SNARE GATE VERB’ that rarely get used but if I need to inject a little mojo, they’re a good starting point.

The ‘D SUB TRIM’ is just a master fader controlling everything going into the bussing, so if I get a little overzealous with level, I can manage the gain staging quickly without having volume automation grouped. These three (sometimes more) busses then feed into the final ‘DRUM MSTR’ , where I’ll do final overall EQ tweaks and level adjustments.

community_answers.author: mixedbywong_my
community_answers.content: I’ll share them later when I’m in the home studio 😃

community_answers.author: sethearnest
community_answers.content: Yeah I use Trigger 2, as well

community_answers.author: jantrit
community_answers.content: There’s no one size fits all 100% of the time but my process looks something like this. 1.Phase! As others have said picking one mic as a phase constant and then checking other mics against this can yield great results. I don’t do a huge amount of mixing live drums that I didn’t track but this is usually the single biggest improvement. 2. I start with the over heads and work from there, usually filtering a touch of low end but I really like to keep these as a full picture of the whole kit. 3. Subtle saturation, I find an instance of Saturn works wonders on some kicks and a lot of other drum sources. 4. Gating and compression, can work wonders to clean up a kick or snare, always checking to make sure that any processing is actually an improvement. 5. Additive eq, boost those pleasing freqs! I should note that 95% of this whole process happens while listening to everything, I don’t usually solo any one element to do any of this (except to start the gating maybe)

question:
I have a bit of a weird technical question I can’t wrap my head around. That I’ve never really thought about before. (might be over thinking it). I’m gonna completely simplify and exaggerate. When we talk about making room in a mix, usually we usually talk about giving each sound it’s own space in the mix. I understand this from a frequency point of view. But when talking about mono vs wide sounds I’m kinda lost. 

If let’s say i have 2 sounds, one is mono and one is wide.  Would that leave one with more headroom compared to having the same 2 sounds both in mono? 

Or would the wide sound take up more head room, because to make a sound wide, it needs to be different on both sides. But doesn’t that mean that you would have double the amount of signal as you would need two different versions of the same sound playing at once to achieve wideness? 

Fx a mono guitar and a mono vocal both centre vs a completely anti phase guitar and mono vocal. I know the latter will make each sound more intelligible but wouldn’t you at the same time provide more information resulting in less headroom?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: If you have a mono sound on a mono track, it will sound mono. If you have mono sound on a stereo track, it will still sound mono. You can add delays, phasing, pitch shifting, etc to make it sound 'wide'... and yes, it will theoretically take up more space in the mix. As far as taking up more headroom, there's just too many variables to figure out there. But if you have the mono sound on a mono track, and the mono sound on a stereo track, with modern pan laws, they would both take up the same headroom.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
Neat question. If you're mixing in two channels (L/R) the headroom should be the same no matter where you pan it (with some caveats which we'll get to). If you have a kick drum panned dead center coming in at -6dB on your digital meter it's going to be coming in at -6 in both the L channel and -6 in the R channel. Each channel has it's own independent headroom that doesn't affect the other (until we add a limiter with linked channels), so let's simplify things a bit and mute the R channel for now:

Now you have your L channel with the kick panned "center" and the R channel is muted.  If you were to pan this kick to the hard left it would not affect the volume of the L channel at all. That's because the panning effect is created by subtracting gain from the R channel only. Making the kick sound like it's leaning to the left.

Now there's one big element I've left out so far, and that's *pan law*. Ableton Live has a -3dB pan law. This means that sounds panned to the center are reduced by 3dB. Because if a sound is being played at the same volume by both the L and R channels then their voltage will combine to create a sound that is louder than intended. So all DAWs and mixers compensate for this added loudness by turning down the gain of sounds as they are panned closer to the center (and shared between both speakers).

Since all modern DAWs and mixers have pan laws implemented, what happens when you now pan the kick hard left is that it ends up becoming 3dB louder than it was when it was panned in the center, because it is no longer being turned down by the pan law when it’s centered.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
So to answer your question, yes, a sound will technically take up more headroom when hard-panned (or spread), because the pan law makes it a little louder when panned to the extremes. However because this also makes the sound perceptually louder you’re likely to turn the sound down a little bit to compensate for the boost in volume, thus buying you back the headroom you’d have lost.

I may have missed a few things. Other DAWs use other pan laws, and admittedly I'm not up to date on the minutiae of it all. So don’t hesitate to amend, or correct me on this stuff, folks.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Some DAWs like Pro Tools can actually change pan law. PT can do -2.5dB, -3dB, -4.5dB, and -6dB. Mixes sound different with different pan laws - and I'll bounce some stuff real quick to demonstrate.

question:
Does anyone have any tips on getting better at a musical instrument? 

I’ve been playing guitar on and off for the past couple of years and haven’t felt like I’ve progressed much so I thought I’d see if anyone had any advice on what to practice/practice routines/general up-skilling stuff when it comes to playing an instrument 😊

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content:
I agree mostly with this! I’ve been playing instruments for 20 years and have made a living from it. If you want to get good, it is aactually pretty easy and anyone can do it with the right mindset and patience(key word here). Firstly stop playing on and off, just play as often as you can preferably every day if not every other day.  Stop worrying about scales chords and theory, and just play. Learn as many songs as you can, like really learn them. Your ear will get better at picking up details, like groove and technique over time, so just learn the songs as good as you can and then move one to the next. Try and make it through a 1000 songs over the next few years. You don’t need to remember them, just get through them and move on. You will pretty quickly start recognising patterns in music and realise most music is made up of the same few combinations of chords notes and so on. At this point I would recognise learning some theory, so that you will be able to name those musical patterns be it cadences, notes, chords, extensions and so on.  Then depending on what with your playing. This next bit is super important. If you don’t care about playing in bands or performing for people then you can do this whole thing by your self. But if you want to play with real people on a stage or a basement then you need to spend time playing with people as much as you can. Learn some songs go to a jam session either at a local pub, church or what ever you have in your city. Having friends who play is also great as you might be able to get a chance to play with them regularly, maby even make a band. When learning a song, make sure you can play it all the way through with either a metronome or a drum track before moving on. Video taping also helps to be able to get an objective look/listen to your playing so you will know, what you need to be mindful of. 

Keith Jarrett the pianist learned one 1000 songs the first year for a restaurant piano gig before he was known or good.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content:
This is of course all perfect scenario stuff and will be impossible to do perfectly so don’t be hard on yourself if it seems like too much.

So in short just play a fuck ton and learn a Fuck ton of songs ✌️

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: Sorry if it’s hard to read, just emptied my head in a long stream of thought. 🕺💃

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: I just recently got super into piano because voice leading is just so much easier when looking a a piano, the visual aspect of a piano just makes so much sense with traditional westeren theory. When making vocal harmonies it is awesome to be able to visualise the harmonies if you can’t think of one or just looking for inspo!

community_answers.author: Josh
community_answers.content: Being that I grew up in metal, and then switched to pop, all of those years of learning how to play deathcore were wasted as I couldn’t even tell you what the fuck I was playing. I’d recommend just learning new songs to start. That’ll get your brain working differently. And then learning different chord voicings. That’s what I’m on right now.

community_answers.author: Josh
community_answers.content: Or you can just play the riff from scar tissue for 10 hours straight. Either works.

community_answers.author: Zakhiggins
community_answers.content:
I find it's kind of like physical exercise, your long term improvement is never linear, and as you get more experienced, you need to be smarter with how you practice if you want to progress.

What helped me improve guitar was treating it like a gym programme, pick a specific thing for a specific amount of time to practice on a Monday for example, and do that every Monday, then have another thing you practice on Tuesday etc etc. Take videos to track your progression over time. Showing up and doing it consistently over a really long time will be infinitely more valuable than a few really intense sessions here and there

question:
maybe not a newb question but I thought it was really interesting what Jon said in regards to distortion of converters. I noticed something similar by experimenting with different clocks on my rather cheap interface. 
One being the internal clock and the other a high quality Antelope Isochrone clock. The minute I hooked it up I was able to monitor a lot louder without it having the feeling of hurting my ears- the increase in clarity was immediate. 
So It seems to be the case that this subtle (intermodulation?) distortion literally hurts our ears and can make people go deaf. 40 of Drake was saying something similar, so I'm wondering if there's more to this.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Your mind is fooling you. Not even joking. You expect a difference, so there is one.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: If anything an external clock on a single converter will introduce more jitter because of coax cables than using a decent internal clock.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Just a quick converter test, been meaning to do this for a while. Here’s a sine wave run through 16 conversion cycles. Out one output and into the next. You can barely see a harmonic sneaking in, and the tiniest amount of noise on the Pro-Q on the right after all those cycles.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: This is an Apollo X16, there are higher end boxes and certainly lower end boxes, but… I just think converters/clocks are waaay over hyped. Not trying to pile on but I just think these conversations are an expensive distraction from making music!

community_answers.author: KushKadett
community_answers.content: nope I've done the blind test.

community_answers.author: KushKadett
community_answers.content: This kind of distortion isnt the pleasant kind but makes things sound phasey and unpleasantly harsh

community_answers.author: KushKadett
community_answers.content: a good clock cleared up my pretty shitty converter, but it can depend on the type of converter you have if it makes a difference or not

community_answers.author: KushKadett
community_answers.content: anyway, whoever can speak on this subject I'd like to hear more about clarity

community_answers.author: KushKadett
community_answers.content: yeah, it's this highly controversial topic but I found it does make a difference for my converter. Now with a hilo coming in the mail soon it won't benefit from an external clock I'm pretty sure

community_answers.author: KushKadett
community_answers.content: a lot of very high level guys swear by their clocks too, so these expensive boxes must do something or else the companies would be out of business

question: Faders ITB or in analog? ITB faders do nothing except change volume. On a console, faders can have a “sound”, and the only benefit to keeping closer to 0 is to have more resolution in smaller fader moves.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: In years past it may have mattered but not really any more

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I think there's been a lot of talk on the streams about making volume adjustments w/ clip gain vs fader adjustments -- and there's a lot of food for discussion there. Having tracks get leveled out before hitting processing chains can have real advantages and can make things easier when it comes time to mix, as you're not worried about compressors or distortion plugs overreacting.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: …but I’d add to that: if you’re giving yourself an anxiety attack about supposed degraded sound quality by using a fader in pro tools, don’t. It’s fine, move those faders around, automate shit, whatever!

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Exactly, it's just 1's and 0's. In the analog world, faders definitely had a sound... PG flying faders vs. SSL VCA faders, etc... it was an actual gain stage so it had a sonic imprint, for better or worse.

community_answers.author: sloth
community_answers.content: @cian riordan sorry,should've mentioned,ITB

community_answers.author: sloth
community_answers.content: I see,thank you for the reply

question: An additional question for anyone to answer: I’ve gotten projects sent to me where there’s verb panned left and then right—is this technique more prone to phase cancellation issues, and if so, why?

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
Yeah. I suppose it would come down to the particulars of a given reverb, but I think your rationale is mostly correct. The verb may already be de-correlating the L/R channels (making them different from each other) in the optimal amount.

Something else to keep in mind is that different frequencies will likely have different amounts of phase rotation from the dry input signal, so flipping the polarity on one channel (left or right) might cause some frequencies to nullify and some to be accentuated. I wouldn't worry about trying to predict these relationships. It's all a mess by design. Use your ears and see what sounds good.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: A nice flavor of spatialization that hasn't been mentioned can come from FFT manipulation (Fast Fourier Transform). The Michael Norris plugin set have a cool *randomize phase* feature that will wash out a sound slightly in a way that sounds like it's been put in an echo chamber. I love the sound of it. And if i'm not mistaken this technique also folds down to mono really well.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content:
thanks! @Slow Hand & @oaklandmatt. 

Something i've been noticing a lot lately is, when playing with width effects, i keep preferring, sticking to only one type of widening at a time, instead of combining. To me it achieves the "clearest" or most intentional result. For example, for some cool widening on guitar i could use a pingpong slap where one side is phase-flipped. It sounds huge and great, now let's say i also want to chorus it. For some reason it seems to loose some of the width or wow effect of the original widening technique. So i'll usually try a few different effect and see which one i prefer, and 9/10 it always achieves my preferred effect picking one, even tho i like the idea of combining, different techniques to sound "unique". The Diminishing returns seem to work against the sound i like in my earholes. I've noticed in a lot of sessions i've been given or been in, a lot of people seem to love adding a bajillion subtle widening things on their lead vocals and when ever i just choose one and turn it up, people usually ask what crazy voodoo i'm doing. 

This is all in the context of widening a mono or less wide sound.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content:
Writing this and thinking more about it, maybe to achieve a unique type of widening thats not just a parallel chorus, flanger or delay. You could make 3 different widener busses and filter them before the widening so they widen different frequencies with little overlap. hmm. gonna have to try this soon! a cool routing could be 

Leadvox - 
aux - Main Widen Fader
bus - FreqSplitter
AUX(100-400)(h3000) - AUX(400-2k)(Chorus)  - AUX(2k-20k)(Microshift)

question: hiya, newbie question : does changing levels of faders for examples between kick in, out, and  subkick change the phase relationship ?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
This is a good question.

The short answer is yes and no.  The phase interaction is more dramatic and obvious the closer in level the two sources are. So if you turn one of them WAY louder than the other, even if they're phasing out, it will be way less obvious. If the frequencies (usually the low end) that are fighting phase wise are the exact same volume, it will be super obvious that htey are phasing out.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: So, while it doesn't affect the phase relationship as far as timing, it does affect the resulting amount of phase cancellation.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: This is a useful way to check phase too - try to get the two sounds at the same volume, the flip the polarity to see what sounds better. You can also time adjust or slide kick sounds to make them work better together (in milliseconds)

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: It's a lot of guess and check. Change the volumes, flip the polarity, adjust the timing of the kicks, and a great way is to get them to phase out as much as possible then flip it back to be as full as possible.

question: **Tiny TLDR** - Which sample rate you use is not a deal breaker, or even close. You can make a great sounding record at any sample rate. There are edge cases where it can make a meaningful difference but in modern Pop, Rock and Hip Hop production it’s not *that* important

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Disclaimer - I’m going to play a little fast and loose with scientific terms here in an effort to make this useful for everyone. Fuller can clean up my mess if he wants 🙂

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content:
- **Higher sample rates reduce aliasing.** There is effectively no difference between 44.1 and 48k here but a meaningful difference at 96k and above. Aliasing is caused by non linear processes like distortion, and dynamics processing (compressor or limiter). Lots online about what it is and why it happens but you can sum it up by saying it’s an inharmonic, digital sounding hash that can feel bright but in a kind of ugly way (but remember sometimes ugly is good)
- **Higher sample rates reduce the impact of Anti Imaging and Anti Aliasing filters in AD to DA converters.** Filtering is necessary for accurate capture and replay of analog signals, and it in the early days of digital it used to be a real challenge. Now it’s basically a solved problem, but if you are doing acoustic music, with delicate transient information there is still a small but real advantage to higher rates
- **Higher sample rates reduce overshoot and inter sample peaks on limiters.** This really only matters if you are sending your loud mixes directly to release, otherwise your mastering girl or guy should handle that

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content:
- **More samples (slices) per second equals a better representation of the analog waveform.** Within half the band of the sample rate (say up to 22.05k for 44.1k) this is demonstrably not true. I know that is confounding, but digital and information theory is basically miraculous
- **We can hear/feel/sense sounds above 20k.** We truly really cannot and if you experiment with significant energy above 20k you’ll actually see problems creep in for electronics and speakers etc. Information above 20k is not our friend (space for harmonic information to live without aliasing back excepted)
- **Working at multiples of 44.1k is better because the sample rate conversion will work better.** This used to be a little bit true a long time ago but hasn’t been for a long time. Use the SRC in iZotope RX on it’s stock preset to 44.1 and you are in pretty good shape
- **Digital EQs work better at higher sample rates because of cramping.** Cramping was an esoteric problem with older digital EQs that looked bad on analyzers but never actually sounded very bad. It’s a solved problem nowadays with most EQs.
- **Video and film is at 48k so we must start there.** Yes film and TV still work at 48k (although YouTube specs 44.1 now) but I have sent a million tracks for sync at 44.1 and it gets dropped in with SRC and away we go

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: @Slow Hand I'm new to discord and not sure how to make this look good, particularly line spacing etc. Please edit at will or let me know how to improve

community_answers.author: 1ggy
community_answers.content: Love this @Nomograph Mastering

question:
I don’t disagree with you, it’s definitely a common workflow in rnb hip hop and it’s how it’s done more often than not. But even then, rappers write verses with pen and rnb writers can sing on their own to write a song. The way I’ve been going about it is I ask if they have any lyrics at least- with people I have encountered the answer is almost always no. So as a producer, I don’t really have any context to work with. And I’ve tried- many times they end up really disconnected contextually even though they may sound right. 

If they are putting out a lot of volume that they just prefer to get halfway there then it’s a different story, but new artists with no music out yet or a few singles or one EP out having no lyrics or song on them is why I feel the way I do about “send me a beat” situation.

My perspective may not be as informed because haven’t gotten to work with a good rapper yet. Some of the people that I have tried to work with that insist on this approach don’t know how to work with fitting words into a bar unless they have drums.

Same with RnB- I like to work with keys or guitar in the room and build together from ground up. But my experience has often been people just don’t know what they want or don’t know how to write on their own. 

My frustration is- “can you at least tell me what’s on your mind?”. Whatever works, works. But if they don’t have any thematic vision then I can barely see it working out 😦

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: Ill usually have a bunch of productions or beats lying around for people who just want something finished to write on. If i have someone who is more engaged ill cook something up, with them in the studio, and if they dig the general Vibe ill leave it there, a little over simplified to write on, and then once i have a topline, chorus or verse, ill finish the Production around the vocal

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: My biggest tip is to always let the vocal Dictate the production.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: With the stuff I work on, vocal is always priority nr 1. A good song with a shitty production 10/10 times beats a shitty song with a sick production. I always prefere to just put down some drums/groove and/or some chords or a melody, then get the general vocal vibe and produce around it. So many vocalist will get distracted by productions that are too finished or busy.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: I’d reccomend taking on the role as Beat stars. If you are working with someone who wants something finished to write on and you don’t have your own stuff, get some beats from other producers(maybe people you know). Being able to pull up a bunch of stuff that will inspire the artist, even if it’s not your own productions is actually worth a lot to make them feel comfortable

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content: So I’ve been encouraging people to use beatstars in those cases (if they require music in order to begin writing)

community_answers.author: cy (sigh)
community_answers.content:
ah that makes sense. 
I've always been  extremely picky with rappers and its either they have bars or im co-writing (and in those cases they lean less towards being heavily lyrical). 

rnb tends to be a bit more flexible and they tend to be more open to feedback /changes. 
most rappers i know personally would take big offense to sending them to beatstars tbh 😂
im more likely to send them to other producers that work how they like 

i will say that hip-hop. especially underground /non radio friendly stuff is my bag/my community and im also an artist in that community ao i def approach it differently than just being a producer /engineer

community_answers.author: cy (sigh)
community_answers.content: best way to work imo. If i feel we need changes  its almost always bring the vocal out a bit more to serve the song

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content:
I do a lot of RnB and they have all been beat first. Most cases I’m reaching out to people with things I made- when it was other way around I had a really hard time finding the direction. It was all references and vague vision- but they definitely had solid understanding of what they didn’t want- which was kind of frustrating to me. I’d like them to either leave it open, or have a more solid vision. But most people with solid vision usually have lyrics IME

But interesting- I have never had anyone take offense to the beatstars recommendation. It’s not because I don’t want to work with them per se- I’m just trying to find them a way to get started haha

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content: That’s a good idea. Curating the beats so I can get them started then figure it out from there and maybe help some of the homies make connections with rappers.

question:
so i’ve been working w this artist producing their songs for a couple years for a steady price per song but now i’m looking to ask for a “raise”, since i feel i have more experience than when we started. how should i approach that conversation??

i tried to really go the extra mile with the latest song (as if i was getting paid more) and they absolutely loved it on the first demo. with this result i kinda want to say something along the lines of “hey you can see our quality can be much higher now can u pls pay more?” 😭 pls help 🙏🏽

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: You just gotta take the risk and ask. It’s shocking how often you can ask for something and actually get it, particularly when you’re not being malicious.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: If they’re your homie or long term collaborator they’ll support you

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: If you can do it and not come off as pushy or weird, I’ve sometimes invoiced a client their old rate, and said something like, “since our last batch of songs, I’ve raised my rates; let’s do this one at the old rate but maybe have a conversation next time about it.” Then it can feel to them like you’re looking out for them and throwing them a bone, but setup a conversation down the road.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: All the more reason to get paid more!

community_answers.author: Zakhiggins
community_answers.content: To play devil's advocate, in my experience sometimes it's worth keeping your original prices with artists you've been working with a long time, and use the good work you've done with them to get more work at a higher price.. The extra jobs you get from good work is probably worth more than what ever extra money you get from one job

community_answers.author: Zakhiggins
community_answers.content: Also, if they find out through you or otherwise that you're charging others more, they might be inclined to pay you more too, not wanting to leave you short.

community_answers.author: hendrick
community_answers.content: yeah my gf suggested this bc i actually have raised my prices for others clients haha but i felt awkward bringing that up with the artist

community_answers.author: hendrick
community_answers.content: also it’s complicated for people to find me through this artist bc i’m doing pretty much ghost producer work so i’m not explicitly credited ya feel me

community_answers.author: hendrick
community_answers.content: this is a great approach!!

question:
Tape Machine question:

When people run to tape machines now, are they mostly just running through the electronics of the machines or are they really recording it to tape? How much of the sound is the machine vs the tape itself?

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: I think it would be for the sound of the tape and machine itself, live printing off the repro head into tools

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: for others it could be about the limitations also, only 16 or 25 tracks, waiting for rewind to playback all the negative things that drew us all to digital would be the reason to go back to tape to me, the romantic ideal and nostalgia of yesterday knowing it won’t be a “modern” record

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Got an Otari recently and definitely a slight sound to just the machine but most of the stuff you want happens when running onto tape.  Like @Eric Martin said I’m recording while monitoring repro head and recording back to digital all in one step and then using a square wave I placed at the top to line it back up.

expert_answers.author: Edward Rivera
expert_answers.content: I think if you're going from the repro head into tools you're cutting off a significant of information based on the sample rate

question:
got a couple noob questions about mixers having label rates, still not sure i totally get it. 

what's the argument for having a label rate vs. an indie rate? are you not doing the same service regardless? is indie rate technically a discount? the one argument that makes total sense is that an indie rate is discounted because you don't have to spend 7+ months chasing down the payment through a label's bureaucracy. but conceptually is there any other reason for it? also, is that always the case or do some labels have more respectable turnarounds on payment. 

i have one rate and that's what I value my service. I don't see why it matters who is footing the bill. makes sense with production and points discrepancies, but mixing? huh?

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: yea totally! i get the discrepancy on flexibility with the rate, that makes total sense. I've also seen some people do a discount for anyone that can pay up front. like 10% or something. no clue if a label has ever worked out for that though, they take so long to fill an invoice it borders on disrespectful

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: For me, my rate depends on how quick something needs to be turned around and how intense I have to be with delivery (different versions, alts, stems, etc)

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: I’ll always do the same level of work regardless of rate though

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content:
Like that diagram of “good, cheap, fast; pick two”
I’ll always aim to do my best but it’s either going to be cheap or it’s going to be fast

community_answers.author: Ingmar Carlson
community_answers.content: Great question! Personally always on the fence about this myself, though I still do it. I don't actually quote two different rates anymore, but I do tend to be more flexible when there isn't a label budget involved (especially not a major). I do believe that it makes a difference who's footing the bill, which you've already framed very well above! I don't feel the same way about playing hardball with a major (who might not even pay me in the same calendar year) as I would with an independent artist paying out of pocket who's coming to me saying they're a fan of my work (many of whom are willing to pay me as soon as they send files).

community_answers.author: Ingmar Carlson
community_answers.content: Questionable ethics, maybe, in not valuing my work consistently and not sticking to a "tier," so to speak. That's where this gets sticky for me. Just hard for me to give a hard "no" to people who truly value my work sometimes.

community_answers.author: Ingmar Carlson
community_answers.content: Lol yea it's wild! Never done the discount for paying upfront, personally, or ever asked an out-of-pocket client to do so. They just do it of their own accord sometimes!

community_answers.author: Ingmar Carlson
community_answers.content: Would love to jam on the ethics here though. I feel sketch sometimes about not being firmer on "my rate"

community_answers.author: Ingmar Carlson
community_answers.content: That too! Turnaround's always part of the negotiation for me.

question: Heyo! This is definitely an open ended question, but I'm super intrigued by the conversation; What's everyones mixing process like? I know every mix is different, but do you all have a procedure you follow each time (to an extent), or do you just Andy Wallace it & approach each mix completely differently? I'm also taking into account that people always fix up any mistakes/monitoring issues at the beginning of the mix so dw about that 🙂 - eager to hear how everyone approaches a mix & perhaps try some of these out

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content: Curveball for you. Genre and context dependent of course, but often I’ll deliberately avoid fixing “mistakes” unless they really break the spell or otherwise grate on me as the mix wears on. It can help keep me from excessive tuning, timing etc and ironing out humanity.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
You mentioned it already but one of the only consistent rituals for me is trying to split up the "mix assistant" type work on a different day if possible or at the very least with a break that involves leaving the room and doing something completely unrelated for a while.

Other than that pretty typically starting from drums/bass/vocals and trying to fill in around that.  But that's on an ideal day for me - more often it's just getting excited about something I heard, getting an idea, and playing around with the mix a lot.  I'm pretty early on in the journey with mixing relatively but realized I was getting burned out already if I didn't continue experimenting and playing around with a song the way I did when I first got interested in this in the first place.  Usually trying new things on every single mix because I have the luxury of usually not being up against the clock working on indie releases.

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Absolutely loving the safe isolation procedure here . 👌🏼

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Mods Looking out for the discord gang in the realist way .

community_answers.author: ! Andy !
community_answers.content: & I really like that approach, it could be said for anything in life; can get really boring if you're not trying to relate new experiences

question: For the first time, I’m being offered royalty points as payment for mixing a record. The gig isn’t locked down yet or anything but I feel unprepared for making sure I’m set up to receive that deal and collect on it. What do I need to be on top of here?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: 1) Decide if that's really OK for you. Royalty points are great on big records, but amount to very little on most releases. Upfront fees are the bread and butter of most working mix engineers.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: 2) Have a mix agreement signed by both parties. Make sure the details of the royalty, what it applies to, and whats required as a deliverable are spelled out clearly.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: 3) A soundexchange letter of direction would be good to draft up -- it'll help you claim streaming royalties quicker than royalties on the master.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: 4) Down the road if you suspect the record is selling and might be profitable, hire a manager or lawyer to chase what you're owed. I wouldn't count on label or artist reaching out to pay you.

community_answers.author: thegreatcarsoni
community_answers.content: Yeah I don’t really mind on this because I have basically no credits and it’s way more important for me to do the work

community_answers.author: thegreatcarsoni
community_answers.content: Great actionable stuff, much appreciated dude. Thank you

community_answers.author: popaganda.
community_answers.content: If it happens to be an indie thing and they’re distributing through a service that does revenue splits make sure you’re set up on that.

community_answers.author: Chad Rodgers
community_answers.content: Many of the distributors automate revenue payments for splits and stuff now which is great, it makes it much easier to guarantee receiving your share. I don’t really see anything from my 4% producer fee on new/emerging artists really, and usually claim it after they’ve recouped fees, but if any of those songs happened to get a big sync or randomly blew up, I’d kick myself for not agreeing to points or having something in writing. I’m coming from a producer-writer perspective as opposed to mixer, but similar vibes.

question: And where are you located, and what's your budget?

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: I found lots of spaces in LA when I was looking (2020/2021) in the $3k-$3.5k/m range that were decent to pretty nice. Ended up in a cheaper spot since my studio partner and I found a crazy deal on a place that worked for us, but that was seemingly very much the exception not the rule. Not sure how prices have changed in the last few years.

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: If you're doing any kind of office or flex space, be very up front about what you'll use the room for. They're not going to have much isolation, and other people renting aren't going to necessarily want to put up with it during business hours. I had a couple friends do that, and they had to use headphones during the day until everyone left. They were fine with it, but it would've been a real drag for me. (Also limiting in terms of when you can have client playbacks, vocal sessions, etc.)

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: You absolutely are going to want a place that you have 24 hour access to, private locks, parking (for you at the minimum, bonus if there's a spot for guests)

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: I don't know about the Long Beach area, but $1k/mo. seems very low for LA for any kind of half decent studio space

question: Was it @Edward Rivera then?? Someone on here suggested that to me... and it works!

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Possibly but I have used that a bunch of times and it’s worked more than it hasn’t for me

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Only maybe worth slowly collecting the most common ones if you want to open sessions from collaborators, but whatever works works!  Stock plugins are also stupid good in daws now.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
One other thing about paid plugins from large companies - you can count on Waves or UAD, Soundtoys, Izotope all updating their tools on newer OS.  Some (definitely not all) free plugs are made by people starting out in developing plugins and they might move on to other things.

Actually in the middle of this situation now where a single dev plugin was used on a track and I can’t even buy the license anymore.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: As long as you don’t mind that (or if you are on Windows it may not become an issue) then there’s no reason to immediately abandon what’s working

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: I do like it thus far. I don't pan the mics hard R and L either, but rather at about 66 degrees, maintaining as much of the integrity of the kit image as possible. Makes a difference.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: It makes a "reverb" almost, and I can use the room mics instead of putting a room emulation on my bottom snare mic if I want to.

community_answers.author: Nick Stetina
community_answers.content: Absolutely no reason not to use free and/or stock plug-ins if you like the results you get, work faster and enjoy it more.

community_answers.author: esquinalee
community_answers.content: If it sounds good… it is good. There’s a lot out there that stock plugins won’t do, or single 3rd party plugins that do what 3 or more stock plugs might, but I would maybe check out videos on some of the more common 3rd party plugin staples like Soundtoys & Fabfilter & Valhalla and suss out which ones give you colors and options you don’t already have that you might like

community_answers.author: Nick Stetina
community_answers.content: I would also caution against trying to switch everything out at once, that sounds like a lot to wrap your head around. If you identify some part of the process that you feel could potentially be improved, then you might start auditioning plug-ins to solve that specific problem/opportunity. Be ruthlessly objective in your review period!

question: I can imagine - I have a TREMENDOUS amount of respect for the guy I've been working with. Just the generosity and time he's put into me alone is unfathomable - but we have very, very different approaches to things. Many of his methods are totally counterintuitive to me and really don't really work for my process; He makes them sound amazing. To each their own.

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: In my time as an assistant to three different composers, and then working as an additional composer for a few more, I found equal value in the things I didn't want to adopt as much as the things I did learn. It's all part of taste making and discovering what makes you unique.

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: (That's not an excuse for brushing something off, though. Absorb as much as possible, learn different perspectives and techniques, and then filter it after you understand it.)

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
One of the reasons I think this way is because anytime you EQ something, you are introducing phase shifts around either side of the frequency you're using. I find low end to be particularly sensitive to phase shifts. Phase shifts blur sound slightly, which is particularly bad for the low end instrument that you want to be punchy and full. 

While EQ may boost your overall low end, often times you are losing punch and clarity at the same time.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: Pultec Qs, even at their narrowest settings, are pretty broad. Instead of reaching for eq first, try just turning it up.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: I concur - And I'm really glad you mentioned the word "taste," too. It's really all about that at the end of the day.

community_answers.author: Charlie Deane "Hypn0.iRL"
community_answers.content: My best advice is to learn absolutely everything his way all the way and make that your method 100% then build from there once you’re done. Apprenticeships work much better and are more beneficial if you drop the idea of having a method to begin with.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: I actually agree with you. We're not in the same country and this wasn't really an apprenticeships, per say. Otherwise, I would agree with you 100.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Thank you so much for clarifying.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Will try. Thank you.

question: Why the 6 over 5? Functionally or sound?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: the prophet 5 is more for the vintage head. the prophet 6 is way more versatile, and sounds incredible.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
When I was doing my deep dive recently - there's a couple great videos put together by Starsky Carr and J3P0 with comparisons.  I think Prophet 5 wins out on raw tone from the oscillators, but the 6 is 90% of that flavor with a much more modern filter.  They added vintage mode a couple years back which really helped it step even closer to the Prophet 5/10, and the modern features like the Arp, Sequencer, and on board effects as well as that very sick analog distortion circuit make it a lot more versatile for sound design (within the Prophet tonescape obviously).

I'm still in the honeymoon phase with mine but I'm glad I went with a P6 personally.  A lot more viable as a performance instrument and it can also get very very very close to the P5/P10 sounds if you keep it dry and keep the filter closed a bit more.

The only thing the P6 doesn't do that the P5/P10 can that I wish it could is the way it does voice allocation in non-unison modes - I believe it always steps through round-robin with voices, whereas the P5/P10 retriggers the same voice for the same key until you move away from that key.  Not a huge deal since you can use Unison 1 voice for basses if you want to retrigger the same voice each time.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Also the P6 is a lot smaller for what that's worth - 49 vs 61 and a much smaller body, only 20lbs vs 31lbs

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: Take 5 fan over here, especially for the money. But EVERY studio you go in to in LA and Nashville seems to have a prophet 6, so it’s not a terrible idea to get fluent on them

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content:
You didn’t ask me and I don’t have experiences with Prophet 5, but Prophet 6’s filters are… just magical. Prophet 6 has two discrete filters for each per voice. When you fatten up unison- you can get that packing bump of resonance with the filter. That’s kind of the sound of Prophet 6 thing

OB6 also sound great, my friend has it- but I don’t really have much experience with them. I like how the unison sounds on it, and OB6 uses SVF (state variable filter) and it’s gives this thin, but thick texture. Both prophet 6 and ob 6 have very distinctive/recognizable sound. 

(funny coming from a guy who has NO hardware synth- but I’ve messed with a few of them! + I was a HUGE synth nerd)

community_answers.author: lystell
community_answers.content:
Haha, no worries. 
Great info! I need to try one. I had of late realised how fun and creative it is with hw synths. 
I have the Behringer Moog. Like it!
Hydrasynth. Fun and sounds great. Quite complicated though.

community_answers.author: Josh
community_answers.content: Also no polyphonic glide on P5

community_answers.author: Josh
community_answers.content: Oh also for people who want the prophet sound but don’t have the dough, the Take 5 is actually closer to a prophet 6 than than the Rev2. It uses the same voice chips (idk what they’re called) and the same filter. The filter isn’t setup quite the same but you wouldn’t know the difference unless you go full Q on the resonance

question: Are you in ProTools?

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
Case dependent on song of course but generally 3 phases

1) Clean - clean up obvious issues, noise, excessive low end, overly roomy, overly dynamic (sometimes completely raw like this might have 20-30db or higher swings in dynamic range between sections) clip gain

2) Dynamics and EQ in track context - compress and EQ how you usually would for what's appropriate

3) Stylize - effects, saturation, stylized EQ

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
This isn’t for everyone, but a few big mixers like this technique. 

After you clean & clip gain, (RX is super helpful for plosives, mouth noises, de essing,) this is one of the only ways I know to take a vocal from raw to sounding like it was tracked well. 

The concept is mostly about balancing a spitty compressor like an 1176 and a slower/warmer compressor like a Fairchild, and then bussing both of those to a new aux, then eq’ing compressing saturating de essing like that was the vocal you weee given in the first place.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
If you want vocals to sound expensive, COMPRESS THE SHIT OUT OF ‘EM. 

You don’t wanna hear the pump, but you wanna hear every nuance in the performance.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: Compressing like this introduces a new set of problems with esses & breaths, so its tradeoffs.

question: Is the verdict in on monitor controllers? All pretty much the same thing??

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Definitely not! The trend seems to be moving towards driving speakers directly from the DAC via AES… but for those of us who like the utility of a dedicated monitor controller, there’s some value in taking the minute, near inaudible hit in fidelity.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Most monitor controllers have analog circuitry and that will be the sonic bottle neck… some just sound cleaner than others, not to mention stepped attenuators vs potentiometers and how they balance L/R signals and eventually shift over time.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: The I/O can also be quite different between them — some will have more analog inputs vs digital, etc. others will have better features for integrating subs and additional sets of speakers. Mine even had a USB DAC and a phone preamp which makes it a real Swiss Army knife in the studio.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I had the presonus and I’ll say that you get what you pay for. Lots of flexibility but terrible Sonics and build quality.

question: So, if I'm understanding correctly, your approach would be to lay down rough vox, guitars, bass, record drums over that, then come in and lay all that over the drums again, correct?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Not quite. Drums first, layer up. Build the house from the foundation. Don’t start with the roof.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: Usually when I’m working alone, I’ll sketch rough midi drums, a couple of loops, etc. then lay down a guitar or two and a rough vocal on top of that, if it takes more than two hours, you’re over cooking it. Then I send that to my drummer, who plays actual drums to that rough. I then build all the keeper takes on top of that real drum track.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Pre-pro out however you need wi the drum loop, midi drums, whatever. But when you start recording for real, start with the rhythm instruments and build up.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content:
If you’re the drummer, I think it doesn’t matter as much, have an idea - execute.

I know drummers who play to the pre-pro track, then hear he final track and think, I would have done things a bit different had I known all these other parts were going to be there. It’s a matter of accents form some people and I think beginning is great, but coming in to track at the end can work too

question: I got standard clip recently and have been reading up on the manual and some of the discord conversations but am still figuring out how to apply that information intuitively into my own workflow (or at least having the confidence to feel like I really know what I'm doing with it). I'd love to hear, on a very basic level, how you all approach using the plugin and if there are any starting points that you would recommend. Also curious how this might change in different use cases (i.e. mastering, mix bus, drum bus). Are you simply sliding down the "clip" fader until you reduce the peaks a little and then making up gain with another plugin? Are you touching the other 3 faders at all? Do you find yourself frequently auditioning and changing modes and oversampling amounts or sticking to consistent setting. Thanks!

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Easy for me, the above is my start point. I think Soft Clipping is a bad idea in mastering so it’s hard clip only here

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: The oversampling filter has a very strong color so use that mindfully

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: At 48 or 44.1’any more the 4x oversampling is a waste of resource. What matters more is filter type (linear better mostly) and cutoff frequency

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: For production and mixing I’ll let others advise

community_answers.author: Zakhiggins
community_answers.content:
Ive found myself getting some extra loudness recently by putting standardclip before a limiter on my group buses, not the master bus. Id use standardclip gently to just catch and even out the transients. And the limiter not to limit, but to basically gain stage post plugins. Not every bus, usually just drums and maaaybe bass or something thats very pokey. I find i can get way more out of my master bus limiter that way while keeping the dynamics.

Also standardclip is cool if u automate up the gain and down the clip on a vocal that is dynamic if you want it to distort tastefully in parts. Sounds good in shouty loud music

ExFAT has given me problems so I avoid it. It seems to work for some other folks but these days my go to is a SSD running APFS. I gravitate towards the Samsung T7, they’ve been super reliable. Avoid SanDisk, but I think there are some other folks using things from other brands like Crucial.

Hard drives are super susceptible to damage and weird mechanical failure when moving them around, and they’re much slower. Do yourself a favor and work from a solid state (and keep everything backed up in multiple places)

question:
Hey there! What’s good ?
So I’m trying to solve this basic but yet important topic.
I’ve read here on the discord that a higher sample rate will ensure less aliasing and digital eqs will work better, also that I should be symmetrical with the buffer size (let’s say I use 128 and 48k). 
My questions here are
1- If I want to upload music to spotify ( which I guess it converts it all to 44.1k ) should I still use a higher sample rate ?
2- What buffer size and sample rate would stick to for recording ? And for mixing ? (Music only)
Thank you! Have a good day!

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Start here! https://www.livewithmattrad.com/resources/sample-rates-in-modern-record-making

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Lmao was literally about to link that

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content:
The buffer has nothing to do with sample rate or fidelity of a given capture. Buffer only matters for the performance of your computer. For setting your buffer, you'll have to find the balance between latency and stability if you're recording. If you're mixing, raise the buffer until your system is stable. 

For sample rate and bit depth, you will be fine working at 48/24.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: If you’re producing, a lot of instrument plugins aren’t 96khz compatible. 48k is pretty much industry standard

community_answers.author: T1NGA
community_answers.content: That’s useful ! But I’m still a little confused

community_answers.author: T1NGA
community_answers.content:
I’m using 48k at the moment, but the article mentions 96k is better overall.
As I said before, all my projects will be uploaded to spotify.

community_answers.author: T1NGA
community_answers.content: I really want to know what your buffer size is , I’m sticking to the lowest one I could get (48) but I’m afraid of losing information or not letting the system ‘breathe’

community_answers.author: T1NGA
community_answers.content:
So basically my options are
1- 48khz 48 samples

All this considering latency and quality, I’m so lost 😞

question: Howww... is everybody recording DI bass?? Last time I think I just went XLR out of my Radial Passive DI Box into the front of my interface, but I dooonn't... think that's right? Maybe I had some type of additional preamp going??  It was a little noisy if I remember correctly. Surprisingly, after 30 mins of Youtube I couldn't find a straightforward tutorial. Everything involved an amp or a PA or something else weird...

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: yeah if you're using a DI box you use a mic preamp after it

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Some interfaces have a DI built in either on a combo jack (but you have to tell it to use the hi Z input) or as a separately labeled instrument input but since you already have a separate box might as well use it.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content:
Well, it all depends on what gear you have and/or want to use.

If you have a DI box, an outboard preamp you want to use, and an available line input on your interface yes.
If you have a DI box and an interface with built in mic preamps but no outboard preamp, do that. If you have an interface with an instrument input but no DI box and no outboard mic preamp do that.

Some outboard preamps even have a DI input on it that sounds pretty good, but without knowing your exact setup idk what to advise. Based on the above info though you should be able to make that choice.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Overall it helps to understand the differences between instrument level, mic level, and line level and when each one is important.

question: I'm really shy to ask this but I'm just gonna get it out of the way: Those of you who track drums last - What is your protocol? As a solo, "one man band" type, I have found the best success starting out with click, then going to guitar, vox, bass and finally drums - slaving everything to the click the whole way down. I don't know why, but this is just what works for me when I'm doing everything on my own. This is quite surprising to me because it's the opposite of how I've ever done it when collaborating with others, but it is what it is. I just want to make sure I'm not missing anything moving forward. Thank you.

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: When I track drums last it’s because I have programmed drums from pre pro so I can make sure all the instruments are tight/can be changed on a whim then I track drums to replace the programmed drums

expert_answers.content: Yeah the whole record is usually tracked before drums if I do it that way
