question: Everybody who got their gear insured - How did you do it? My insurance company and I agreed on a process: I assess the value of the gear and document it. Then, I take that list to Guitar Center and they confirm or deny whether my assessments are accurate and adjust where necessary. The only problem is that guitar center is being assholes and really dragging their feet and whatever I can understand why. Is there some other third party I can go through? Some "phone-in assessor" or something?? All I need is a signature of an official business. My signature doesn't count because I'm not an "official business" - Guitar Centers would count because they essentially act as a pawn shop assessing the value of gear and buying it in etc. etc. Even if there were another insurance company I could go through for just this gear thing I would be open to that.

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content:
In the UK there are specialist providers for musicians and producers with studios. You submit a spreadsheet of your inventory including the value it would cost to replace each item (I update annually based on reverb / eBay current prices), and the location of cover needed (just in studio, or maybe on the road nationally or internationally if you play shows too). 

Not sure if the same in the US but I’d imagine there’s similar.

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content: Hopefully someone who’s actually had to claim can recommend a provider, but this feels like a googleable question at least to get some quotes

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: https://www.musicproinsurance.com/

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: I personally wouldn't gamble with a rider on a home owner's policy unless it's a specific music instrument and music gear coverage they specifically offer. I'd spend the couple hundred extra for peace of mind with a company who understands gear, instruments, touring, studio vs. home, etc.

community_answers.author: Brian Reynolds
community_answers.content: I have insurance for my apartment via Progressive. I just decided how much $ coverage I wanted and pay a monthly payment. I need to increase the coverage and this comment will get me to do that today, thanks

community_answers.content: Yeah, this is exactly what I'm talking about! Thanks, man.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Maybe someone else here will know of a company.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Definitely a bit pricey compared to what the home owners insurance can do, but I might just have to go this route!

Can I get 16 analog inputs and 16 analog outputs by connecting ADAT Out from unit 1 to ADAT In on unit 2 + ADAT Out from unit 2 to ADAT in on unit 1? Also please let me know if I am just thinking about this all wrong.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: yeah just make sure you're clocking correctly (the leader should be the interface that's connected via usb and if you wanna be super pro you'd use a BNC word clock cable from the Clarett to the Octopre

expert_answers.content: Clock the rest to the Octopre

question: Hey - I TRACKED_DRUMS_FIRST, okay??

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content:
1. Write song 
2. Demo song 
3. Track drums
4. Edit/comp drums
5. Track guitars
6. Comp and edit as needed
7. Track bass 
8. Comp and edit as needed
9. Track vocals
10. Comp, tune and edit as needed
11. Track lead guitars and synths or extra production 
12. Comp and edit as needed
13. Organize and clean up session
14. Mix said song 
15. Do revisions on said mix till needed
16. Send song to mastering
17. Upload said master to DSP of choice 
18. Repeat steps 1-17 till satisfied

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Repeat steps 1-17 till satisfied

question:
Thanks Matt! What I’m picking up is keep my head down, make sick records and take full advantage of any opportunities shown to me. It seems like internships/assistant positions are altogether quite rare these days, hopefully I can find something. Any advice for something you’d like to see in a cold email?? Is that the route, or do you reckon establishing contact with other intentions first?

Your advice on personal connections and trust really speaks to and affirms what I’ve been trying to cultivate. Living in a smaller town, those connections come easily and run deep, but often without the same big city opportunities.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
To second matt, most everyone I’ve seen who had a great “come up” started because someone liked a record they did with a small shitty unknown band. My first real big break came from helping out with and swapping songs with a college buddy, who then managed to get a record deal, and I got to come up and help a little bit and meet with their producer. After a brief stint in Australia in another band, like Matt Rad, I relentlessly (but respectfully) kept reaching out to the producer to see if there was any toilets I could clean or any help at all I could give him, or even if he was just available for a quick lunch and could I play him some bands I was working on.  After a couple months he brought me in and taught me melodyne saying “if you get good at this you’re going to own a house someday”. 

This post is coming from inside the house. 

I think the mistake a lot of people make is they reach out hoping that someone can help them, and not with the intent of how they can help the person they’re reaching out to. I never planned to be Vocal Producer to the Stars ™️ but it turned out it was a job that needed to be done that other people didn’t want to do, and I started to get passed from big name producer to bigger name producer, and then I got enough clout to actually be the middle sized name producer. But it starts with going “hey, what do YOU need” and not “hey can you help ME”

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I just cold reached out to Eric V. after I met him through Matt. Told him I wanted to just hang on the couch for a day and watch him work. Two weeks later I'm moving to LA to work for him. @Tyler Graham hit me on this discord forum almost 4 years ago to come by for coffee -- he ended up working as my mix assistant until this past summer... he is now the head engineer at a new studio in town.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Figure out what you wanna learn and who you wanna learn it from first. Then start plotting the path to get there.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: But also realize that mentorship does not equal a career... you still need to be able to operate on your own two feet, outside the shadow of whoever you're trying to work for.

question: - He's talking about centering the snare in the overheads here, though, right?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: ESPECIALLY dense guitar music.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I am sure there's a perfect world where the snare is centered in the OH's and is "distant" sounding enough that it doesn't negatively affect the close mic, etc.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: for my usual big mic setup, the cymbalas are so much louder in the OH's than the snare, it couldn't possibly matter.

question:
My take, after listening, was that a ME should have no problem working on the non limited mix. I heard the clipping but it wasn’t ugly. There are lots of things that go into making a record, and a little clipping here and there isn’t gonna be the difference in a song hitting or not. 

But also- allowing yourself to be curious without being fearful... Taking someone’s note and asking, without judgment, if there’s something you might’ve missed, is worthwhile.

Deeper still, and I’m still working this out: taking the blame and taking the credit are the same thing, I think. Admitting you were wrong can be a sort of superpower, and all the sting and shame disappear and all you’re left with is the learning and growing and relationship building. Walls go down on all sides and it becomes a team effort again. 

It’s real easy to let ego ruin a good feeling. Being able to say “shit what did I miss?” is wayyyy easier than saying “but I already said it was good so i can’t go back on it…” it takes longer to get there sometimes, but in the end it’s the path of least resistance. 

BBQ Sauce.

question:
This has been my experience;

Mixing was always guess and check. It was also a lot of mixing in compensations. Example: when the vocal is barely too loud it’s actually perfect. When the low end is just barely too thin it’s actually perfect. 

To me, the right monitoring is whatever you can mix 100% intuitively and then be satisfied far more often than not when listening on other systems. 

So, In short:

-are you able to mix intuitively and not be shocked by what the mix sounds like outside of the studio?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
PMC twotwo8’s were a step in the right direction for me of what was possible. PMC 6-2’s have been “easy mode” compared to any other speaker I’ve ever used. (Typical offerings from Yamaha, Genelec, Dynaudio, JBL and some other brands like Emotiva). 

I’ve never used ATC’s, mums, or Neumann. But at a certain level it’s about what works for you. 

I find the entry level Kali’s to be the best bang for your buck early on. If you’re on Yamaha HS8’s or KRK’s and NOT happy with your results, id consider them. Everyone I’ve suggested them to ( mostly musicians and producers) love them and whenever I hear them I don’t feel like I’m in some weird EQ’d hellscape

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: 1000 words to say what everyone else said in 10, but this has bothered me for my entire career and I feel like I’ve maybe made some headway now that I don’t abhor every mix I do now.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I think we should ask @river some questions before we start talking in specifics

community_answers.author: onanisland
community_answers.content:
First you have to figure out if its the Speakers or the Room. Most often its the room.

I'll reiterate what @NoahNeedleman & @David Fuller said but with real-world example. 

I've had people come by and ask to check their work in my room (because its a "no-compromise" aka what you hear is what you get) though I told them to get a bunch of their stuff if they want to find out where exactly they're making the same mistakes. We eventually saw the pattern and then they'd either have to compensate for that, or fix their rooms.

community_answers.author: onanisland
community_answers.content: I also have to point out that, while great monitors and great rooms are revealing, you still have to put in the time. It's one thing to come in and fix the mistakes of a close to finished mix, its another to mix something from scratch. So it's hard to know if your monitoring system is holding you back but still a very good option is to check the speakers, check the room, check what you can improve and test in others setup

question:
Let’s start a thread about off days. Like you go in the studio and everything is just wrong and feels bad. What makes this happen? How often do you get them? 

i’m only bringing this up because I walked in the studio today, and it was an absolute disaster from start to finish. I don’t know why I kept going thinking it was going to get better.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
It’s usually for me some sort of fatigue or mental block. I’m tired and uninspired, usually from lack of sleep or poor diet. 

I essentially make 99% of my life choices around avoiding this feeling. This includes light exercise (yoga, walking) eating enough decent food, getting enough sleep, and not drinking alcohol or caffeine regularly.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I either accept it’s not going To happen today, or I go do something to change my feeling. A good meal, a walk around the block, going to grab a coffee.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Also I find when I’m having a bad work day I end up on my phone a lot more. So removing that from my general area can really help me refocus. 

Also I love to do lists. Writing out a plan can make it way easier to knock things out when you’re having an off day.

community_answers.author: Tyler Graham
community_answers.content: I go through a solid week, two weeks of manic, unbridled work, followed by couple week of inevitable burn out. I anticipate it coming and it doesn’t have the same demoralizing effect that it had when I started. I know that i’m just at the bottom of the sine wave, so to speak. Its pretty essential to vary your work and expand your horizons. When I burn out on mixing, move to production. When I burn out on production, tracking, etc.

question:
From my side -- this gets down to "what is mastering even for?" territory -- but to the question at hand, it completely depends. As it must. Every project and song is different. Even on the same project, from the same mixer, it can vary widely. Mixers differ in how they deliver as well.

My opinon is mixers should take the song as far as they can, get it as close to finished as possible, this is better for the music to me. Don't even think about mastering. Then any great ME can add more x/y/z as they hear it (not always level, mastering is also about restraint). 

If you can be concerned with making the music the most itself and singular as possible, really listening for the song, you are doing the right thing. Maybe it needs to be loud, maybe not. Often it seems to me there is a misplaced focus on continuity, or a comparison to a reference, which leads me to ask...are we listening for the music anymore? Or some target that is not what we've actually made?

Just listen for what's there, and do absolutely everything you know how to do to help that. Any competent ME can take it from there, however you prefer to deliver

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
Short answer; it’s program dependent. And everything depends on everything. 

Long answer:

I spent a long time hoping MEs would answer these questions for me, but honestly not a one of them knows wtf they’re doing. Certainly not enough to quantify things like “how much louder will I make your track.”

Best thing I did along the way was develop relationships with MEs. Usually one at a time, and worked through my questions in real time. Figured out what happened when masters come back and i felt amazing vs when they come back and I felt just ok. 

Over time I’ve developed a philosophy for myself, (and while that changes/evolves over time,) I’m now confident when I send a mix to master that what I’ll get back will be a more finished  version of my ideas. And “more finished” is not necessarily correlated to “how loud.”

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: I feel like there’s subtext here that I may be misreading.

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: It varies 100% depending on the project. Sometimes same level, sometimes louder, sometimes quieter

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: I find this perspective interesting. I suppose the original post also almost implies that the mastering is bringing a lot to how the mixes are presenting too -- which maybe it is maybe it isn't. But I think it's important for mixers (all of us really) to know though...the people at the top, like really at the top who you are most likely comparing to are unbelievably good. Not kinda good. Like REALLY good, and there is often a big gulf between them and even more mid-tier, on the way up folks (who are still very legit pros). And when you really hear it, it's shocking. And inspiring. And you realize why they are there

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: And would encourage @louisvie to not consider what mastering may or may not bring, and take it as far as he can himself given skills he has now, not assuming mastering will do anything

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: Perhaps others feel differently, I'm very open to hearing!

community_answers.author: Josh Bowman
community_answers.content: Make it sound and feel as finished as you can. Then let the ME  see if/where they can elevate it further. I think in modern record making, except in really specific relationships where it’s been communicated, the best result comes from everyone at every stage doing their absolute best and then passing it onto the next person.

@BoozleBAM it's worth adding that it's fun to realize that the drum set is just that: a set of drums. The idea that one person plays all the drums in one coordinated set all at once is a pretty narrow part of the whole of drumming, percussion, rhythm, etc. 

There are SO many cool and interesting ways to make "drums" happens.

I would spend some time with some of these records that people are sharing, and thinking about ALL the rhythmic components, both separately and together. 

Take some time, be patient, and try to expand your brain in how you think about this stuff. Lots of good insight from people here and some amazing trails for you to follow. I'm excited for you!

question: I mean I make most of my decisions with my eyes closed, the visuals are just a guide, right?

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content:
There are plenty of times that I’ll use a high pass on or above the fundamental frequency, depending on context. If I have 5 instruments all playing the same note, then chances are some of them want to live in different parts of the frequency range (maybe strummy guitars are more about the transients and first harmonics, for example). 

As everyone’s saying, if it sounds good it is good, but I wouldn’t overthink the note-to-frequency thing too much.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: A high register piano could have loads of info well below the fundamental that add a sense of weight or atmosphere, or a low register guitar could need tons of the fundamental, first, second, whatever harmonic passed out of it.

question: Check out Ethan Gruska’s album Slowmotionary—is the piano sound at all like that? If so I’d use that as a North Star. Or Phoebe Bridgers Punisher. Knowing Noire a bit I imagine it might be that real rolled off kinda vibe. When I’ve mixed stuff like that, I do a combo of aggressively attenuating the boominess, and using Spectre/Neutron exciter/Saturn to get as much life out of the midrange as I can before things start getting crunchy or harsh. Then you gotta also just remember that it was the sound they chose and you need to respect that. So it’s a balance.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Oh and you mention certain notes being blown out. Don’t be afraid to find those and surgically dip those frequencies.

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: Noire has a bunch of settings, maybe your artist is using a preset with some unpleasant ones. If you have access to the instrument, go in and check things like color, tonal shift, punch, bass, etc... That said, I haven't found Noire to be a particularly unwieldy sounding instrument, so it could be that the way it was played needs some MIDI taming.

question:
on day jobs and switching careers as a burnt out 20 something

Hey yall, I have a few questions on how can one make a successful transition between careers, since Im kinda burnt out on corporate jobs and wanna take a hand at becoming a performer/producer/writer/engineer for a career:

-when exactly is the right time to switch? somewhere around making the same amount as the day job?

-is taking a leap a valid strategy? It seems to me that if I cant build momentum working full time on music for ~6 months, its not happening, and I really have no free time w my current job + study situation

-is working music jobs good for momentum, or does it hinder you? Im talking doing bar cover gigs for money/making content while building skills during the day

-how is it living w roommates as a musician? Want to get out of my folks’s somewhat soon, and trying to figure out the logistics of needing to practice or record every day

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
Hey howdy hey. Stream of consciousness response here:

First of all- great question. Haven’t seen you around these parts yet so I don’t know your situation and can’t speak to your specifics. But, there are some overarching philosophical ideas worth considering. 

1) the answer to each of these questions is different for every person. None of us got into music because we’re risk averse and looking for stability, so dont think just cause you’re “going full time” or you start calling it a “career” that somehow that will be different. 

2) and this is universally true, you’ll never be younger or have fewer responsibilities than you do now.

3) don’t take the leap if you’re not willing to: be poor. Have roommates. Eat ramen. Breakup with girlfriends/boyfriends who expect more from you. Borrow money for your cellphone bill. Drive a shitty car. Etc etc. 

But also, if you don’t bet on yourself, no one else is going to either.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: 6 months is not long enough. Think 10 years.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: If you can do all that for 10 years, you’ll find a way to make it.

community_answers.author: jet
community_answers.content: thanks for the reply! happy to finally contribute haha, been lurking for a while now

community_answers.author: jet
community_answers.content: I definitely feel you on the “risk” part - Ive been consciously (and unconsciously) avoiding a lot of situations that would put me in long term commitments - some of that is fear of failure, some of it is like Im keeping that ‘music job’ door open as long as I can

community_answers.author: jet
community_answers.content: I dont really know how far I can push myself when talking lifestyle habits, because all Ive ever known is 9 to 5s and a good home situation. You can all guess how thats going for the creative part of me that has no free time or a real incentive to lock in 😅

community_answers.author: sethearnest
community_answers.content:
Co-signing everything Noah said. Especially the "not 6mos but 10years" mindset. 

To one of your points, it could be argued taking the leap is the *only* strategy that'll help a person get through the various valleys of despair. If you're all in, then you're more likely to figure it out. Building the plane on the way down sort of idea.

question:
Here goes…
Million ways to skin this cat. I’ll give you food for thought.

1. At least double track. My personal goal, is to get the sound to be as awesome and huge and perfect with 1 pair of guitar tracks doubled, with 1 mic on an amp. That’s the ideal scenario for me. That said There are people that sum 4 mics down to 1 signal on a mixer and it sounds amazing.  

2. The more performances  you add of the same part, the more blurry it will sound.if you need different textures, consider recording a DI so it can be blended in with your amp in any manner of your choice, either reamping, distorting with a plugin, whatever. (Check phase)

3. I like when the left and right are *subtly* different, no drastically different. You hear “the left and right being different is what makes something wide”
This is true. But I loathe when it’s so different it feels lopsided.

How do we address this? 

-double track using the same guitar so the tuning and intonation is most similar 

-change the amp head but keep the same cabinet/speaker so the overall EQ is similar but my the gain structure is different

If you use 2 different guitars, consider the scale lengths. This will change subtle intonation things, for better or worse.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
So, try to keep some things the same, change smaller things.

If you do left side with a les paul a Marshall and an sm57, then the right side with a strat through a twin with a ribbon mic, it’s gonna sounding fucking weird and disconnected. I find that to be not the move.

I often double track with the exact same rig, I don’t care about the “phase” argument. It just feels tight and huge to me. I may use a different boost pedal or something super subtle.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Also….
Try tracking one take 
Track your double
Remove the initial track, and THEN double over your second take. I find this gets the rhythm and vibe much tighter when you double over a double

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Also, let your bass be the thing that lives below 150hz. Not that you need to hi pass at 150hz. But don’t let big huge wallowing low end eat up your mix.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Older analog equipment tends to be more temperamental in my experience... console power supplies, etc. But most consumer modern stuff is pretty robust and bulletproof. question:
here's my 2 cents;

I used to feel the same way - i wanted the snare and kick to be very "Centered" in my room mics and overheads. and i'd get these like, super forward, up front snare sounds in those mics. Then I'd pull up my snare mic. and it sounded...the same.  I found that if the snare sounds the same in the OH's and rooms as it does in the close mic, it ends up sounding smaller bc of phase or lack of variety.

if you're using 16 drum channels and 8 of them sound the same, what's the point?

The OH's and rooms for me with that many microphones, i am trying to get width or energy. so the differences between the left and right is what makes it sound big and immersive, and let's the snare mics be their own thing dead center. 

Now, if I am doing a 1-5 mic setup, I will concern myself more with all of that stuff and try to get the snare to sound really great and centered.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I like what @cian riordan is saying, about you can have the snare centered and have width if placed correctly. You have an advantage since you're recording yourself in your own space. you're not up against a clock of someone else's studio or someone else's time.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: a HUGE thing for me has been to not give a flying fuck what it sounds like in solo. It's a hard habit to break. 100% easier said than done.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: it's like if anything the weird shitty thing I am hearing is gonna rip in the mix. I love "blowing peoples minds" when they are like "that snare is super ringy" when it is soloed, then the whole drum mix comes in and you would never call it ringy.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: This is very interesting - Kind of like when double tracking guitars... the variation can make it big.

question: whichever route leads to faster creation is good with me

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content:
I went through an iteration of using an Allen & Heath MixWiz and it was good until the preamp card fried, got a RAMSA console in as a stopgap and decided that I needed to go the pre route.

Now I have 2 Neve OPX’s, 2 Neve DPX’s and 4 Phoenix Audio DRS’s, and 4 Great Rivers, it’s not exactly a console but functions like it for me and everything is essentially under warranty (for now)

Most tracking dates are done with the DPX’s and some outboard comps, drums are normalled to the Phoenix Audio’s

basically all my “profit” for two years dedicated to preamps.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
I got locked into 500 series while I was touring (for like 10 years,) and once I got my home studio setup I had everything hard wired, each mic had its own dedicated chain. All so I could work at the speed of my creativity focusing on parts & performance rather than capture & sonics. 

About 5 years in I was fast and savvy enough that I could let the Sonics play a bigger role without sacrificing momentum, so last year I installed a patch bay. Now just grabbing a mic to record takes a little longer, but I can do a lot more fun & creative work on the way in. 

So even if you decided to go 500 series, I’d argue that the modularity isn’t as big of a selling point on a microcosmic level. 

It might be worth thinking about the 500 series like a console, get yourself 8 Avedia Ma5s and do all your eq & compression in the box.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Hell, I have my 500 series stuff addressable on my patchbay so it's kind of the best of both worlds for the overdubs etc that I do at home

community_answers.content: I mean if you’re gonna be mixing on it and doing effects throws and automation then yes- otherwise just get some preamps

question: i need help to unlearn everything, feel like i dont know how to mix, anyone have tips

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
i love this question. i've been doing this for long enough that the cycles of how records sound has changed several times. so every few years i try and take some time to unlearn/relearn.

there's no good short answer, but i'd start with taking some time outside of mixing to just listen to records. whether you've done this before or not, get to know your speakers and your monitoring environment better than before. listen to your favorite records that you know well, and make some tweaks. you don't necessarily have to redo your whole setup, but listen to your speakers in slightly different positions, different settings on the back of the speaker, etc. and really dig into listening and enjoy yourself.

that's usually enough to make me think about mixes very differently (which ultimately means i get better when i re-incorporate most of the things i already know). but if you need more, just try and simplify. start a mixing by just leveling everything. clip gain and leveling and panning. then balance frequencies and compress (via compressor or saturator or limiter or whatever). basically, with fresh ears, go back to basics.

not sure if that will transform you into a new mixer, but that's an outline of an approach i use when i feel like i need a big talent upgrade

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Hi Rae, these are awesome headphones but -- like any closed back headphone -- it's going to be hard to get a real sense of how things are going translate in the real world..  especially when it comes to low end. Everything on headphones is going to sound clear and direct, when that may not be the case coming through speakers. Checking stuff on some decent monitors in a decent room -- or even in your car --  is always the best way to know if things sound off or not. If you're stuck with headphones, something open back like a Sennheiser 600 will give you a less-hyped, more honest picture of your mix. They're also much less fatiguing to work on for long periods of time! But even to this day with my nice setup, I'm always checking the low end in different places... In my car, I'll know within 10 seconds of listening if things are where they're supposed to be or not.

question:
@thejadenmejia this is something that will probably be different for all of us. I’d consider what you’re recording (just vocals? Full band? Etc) Do you want to have a day rate, hourly rate, or song rate? For me, I prefer day rates + the consideration of how many different things I’m recording. 

I’d also consider if you are only recording, or if you are also going to be mixing the project. You could stack the two rates on top of each other, or work something out with the artist where it’s “Normally I charge this for recording and this for mixing, but if I do the whole project, i’ll give you this deal”. Not necessary, but slightly dropping my recording rate and mixing the whole project is something i’ve done in the past

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: If people aren’t negotiating with you on your rate and accepting it fast, up your rate.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: the more you charge, the more people will value you too, have you listened to the “Attack and Release Show” that podcast talks about rates a lot and they firmly believe in upping your rate sooner than later.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: You can also approach it, as I did for quite a while, from a monthly cost angle. If you want to work 20 days a month, maybe build in a healthy buffer so that if you only book 10, you’ll still make ends meet. Make a day rate from there, and an hourly rate from that. I’ve played this out several times over the years, and it usually comes out pretty close to where most working engineers settle in whichever city I was in at the time.

community_answers.author: thejadenmejia
community_answers.content: I usually just record vocals! Most artists that come in are artists bringing in mp3s. Sometimes I’ll record electric and acoustic guitars and I’ve tracked drums before. I usually do an hourly rate, but I find downsides to that method at times. My vocal chain is pretty good and I’m adding a Sony C800G to my mic locker. I’ve had recording experience for 4 years. Started when I was 15 and mentored under a local engineer. I have been charging $50/per hour. And I like your idea of the recording-mixing deal. Even still, I’m just at a loss on what to charge for mixing and recording. 😭

community_answers.author: alecdibell2
community_answers.content: @thejadenmejia i think it’s really going to just come from trial and error as far as how you would like to price those things. Definitely see what’s common is your local area and your output vs others. Don’t be scared to up your rate if the value is there

question: So I have a bunch of acoustic panels, how do I know where to put them strategically?

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: I’m sure you’ve read this or could find it with a quick google search, but starting with the first reflection points would be my first step. Side walls next to the listening position and ceiling above. Then probably behind the listening position and perhaps behind the speakers. If you have anything to use as a bass trap, I’d recommend using something like fuzzmeasure to shoot the room and experiment with placing that stuff in different places. You’ll be able to see peaks and valleys moving around in the low end, assuming what you’re using is actually effective at sucking up bass. There are people with much more knowledge than me, but that’s where I’d start!

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: At its most basic, ceiling above listening position, first reflections at front of room, and the rear wall are most critical

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: in most cases, putting your speakers up against the front wall will be the way forward

community_answers.author: chris_donlin

community_answers.author: Zakhiggins
community_answers.content: compression would definitely bring up the noise floor

community_answers.author: Rob Domos
community_answers.content:
If it’s the hissing kind of noise that you get more of when you switch from condensers to dynamics and ribbons, then it’s not the kind of noise that is coming from the room. 

In rooms the main things you would be concerned about would be reflection (which you fix with treatment) and mechanical noise from things like computer fans, clocks, etc. and condenser mics would pick those kinds of sounds up more, not less. 

Any unison pre in the Apollo should be plenty low noise to not bother you on your condenser mics. I agree with others that not using any unison pre will make the noise floor lower, but I disagree with them in that I think using the unison pres is a pretty good idea often. 

That said, if you’re struggling with noise, definitely try not compressing on the way in because compressors are only going to raise the noise floor. 

On dynamic mics and ribbon mics, you can decrease your noise floor pretty considerably by picking up a cloudlifter and throwing that in the chain. 

If you do all of the above and still have a high noise floor then either the Apollo is broken (which is pretty unlikely), or your microphone is picking up mechanical noise from your air conditioning, computer fan, refrigerator, etc. if those are the issue, then tackle the issue there. Turn off the A/C, turn off the fridge, turn off the LED lights, etc and see what you hear.

community_answers.author: Josh
community_answers.content: Yo so my twin actually broke and I had a crazy ass noise floor. Got my arrow and it disappeared. I haven’t met a single person with a broke Apollo.

question: https://www.dropbox.com/s/10kkcrmbp2muipi/CR%20DRUM%20TEMP.ptx?dl=0

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
I'll gate everything with the Pro-G. Usually as tight as I can while sometimes automating threshhold to make sure ghostnotes don't get lost. I'll peel back the ratio once I have everything triggering properly to let some bleed in to taste. Sometimes I'll only gate 2-3 dB to just get something to pop. Sometimes its in a vaccum.
I will very rarely compress individual drum mics. And I pray that the recording engineer didn’t either. I like most of my compression to come from the busses. It sounds more natural to my ear and allows you to get away with a more compressed, exciting sound than just whacking the close mics. I’ll find at the beginning my drum mixes will be very ‘pokey’ — I want each drum to sound explosive and over the top. That way when i start compressing them, they maintain their transient quality when they start getting dynamically reduced.

I’m always cutting tons of 250-350 out of the kick drums and trying to manufacture any attack with saturation instead of EQ. Having a SansAmp or a Saturn plugin adding high end always sounds more natural to me than just additive EQ. I’m always very wary of the 2-5khz region, and find even-order harmonics are the best bet to fill in the blanks there.

I tend to like my snare drums warm, so often low-shelving down the super low end and keeping the 150-300 ‘boosh’ intact. I try to avoid using HPF on drum mics because at this point, things should be relatively in phase, so if I put a filter on, it’s going to throw the whole kaboodle off whack. Shelves are your friend here. And same as with the kick drums re: adding high end — I’m wary off adding the snap in the 2-5khz range, I’ll try and have the body of the snare drum really singing so I only have to add a little bit of top end, often above 5khz just for some air.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
A tangent…

I’m lucky to have spent many years in a great studio with lots of great drums & gear… not to mention being mentored by one of the great engineers of our time. Having this perspective is massively useful in mixing other peoples tracks, because I feel I have a north star of what good drums can sound like if they’re recorded and performed properly. It used to be that my starting point for mixing drums were working with tracks that I had recorded myself… and most of the above problems were solved before the mix stage. These days, with smaller budgets and time constraints, its very rare that this is a possibility.

I’m including this drum tracking session from a few years ago that I recorded at Barefoot. It was for a project that Matt was producing that never saw the light of day. But we went all out with the drum setup in the big room, through the console, and had a great drummer. This might be useful for some people who have never gotten properly recorded drum tracks… to get a sense of how good thigns can sound before the ‘mix’ stage. These are the tracks that were printed into Pro Tools off of the console, and the three busses were prints of the outboard compressor busses we were using while monitoring. It’s unlikely these busses would get used in mixing, but they’re a good reference to what we were listening to in the room while we were tracking. But as you’ll notice, the individual drum blend can stand on it’s own two feet. Hopefully this is useful as well.

Thanks for coming to my Ted talk.

question:
Anyone have tips for recording live vocals while someone plays a grand piano? Id rather not use an SM58 but am open to any other mics, condenser or dynamic.

This is for a live video session, piano will be in a booth so I’m only dealing with piano bleed. I won’t have time to experiment much before the session so wondering if anyone has any wild suggestions!

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: my 2 cents: SM7 is all i've used for things like this and it works great. anything too fancy and you're running the risk of lot plosives/ bad mic technique since i imagine you're not gonna want to bother with a pop screen

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I know it's not sexy, but the rejection from an SM58 (or even better, a Beta 58) is worth considering.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: @cian riordan @oaklandmatt thanks for the tips guys! I will probably try both if I have time.

community_answers.author: jantrit
community_answers.content: Seconding the 7b always had great luck with it in those kinds of situations. You could also try a 48 or 49 in fig 8 a little in front / above the player angled down towards them with the piano in the null but like Matt says then you’re juggling so many more variables like the person moving about/ the room. The 7b never fails! And it’s easy, and it sounds great

community_answers.author: absflores
community_answers.content: 67s with a 87 in the middle underneath or my preferred method, 67s with a stereo small condenser on middle C.

community_answers.author: absflores
community_answers.content: The lower mic should be where the lower strings and middle strings meet. The higher one the equal opposite. Omnidirectional is the way in the studio for pianos.

community_answers.author: absflores
community_answers.content: Mix wise, the 67s are the foundation and the stereo mic in the middle should blend in to fill in the gap. You’ll hear it.

question: Both myself and the artist want to make sure the length of silence, and transitions between songs (where applicable) are as intentional and fine tuned as possible. Obviously each song has been mixed in a separate project file, so wondering if anyone has workflows they recommend for doing final mix deliverables on an album and fine tuning the space and/or transitions between songs?

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: That's something to discuss with the mastering engineer, who does the final sequencing. Assuming there is a mastering engineer in question.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Talk to your friendly neighborhood ME. This is what they'll do. Would advise to not be too precious about this as it's a relative crapshoot when it comes to streaming, especially where overlapping is involved. On the vinyl version, by all means go for it. But when it comes to the streaming version, sometimes letting the songs be the songs is the best you can do without introducing hiccups or weird shit in a playlist context.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
I always put 3/4 of a second of silence in front of each song to account for playback errors. It’s done me very well so far and feels like “instant” start without losing the initial transient.

I put all the mixes in a session and do exactly what you said, make transitions in that final pass.

community_answers.author: SoundOfPatrick
community_answers.content: The best idea I've had so far is bouncing all the sings individually with surplus tails, and then dragging them all into a project and spacing out how I want the transitions and then rebouncing from the project. question:
Power question:

I just had a power strip completely die - and I think melt slightly! All the gear was totally protected (pretty nice power strip, but old at this point).  It had my Computer, my PMC twotwo8's, a synth, some other odds and ends plugged into it.

So, what are some best practices when it comes to power/electrical and recording/music gear? Does it really matter if things are on separate outlets if they all go to the same breaker? and if they are on separate breakers and then interconnecting later on, isn't there potential for ground loops / noise?

This is the first time I've had one completely fry - I've had things shut off but nothing like this.

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: That power strip probably had an internal short. Admittedly, I'm a little leery of running that much stuff off one circuit, especially stuff that draws lots of current on the same strip like the monitors and the computer.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Interesting, that must be it.

question: Bit random but do dynamic EQs just slide the gain up or down in relation to a threshold or are they actually compressing and expanding the incoming signal/frequency(s)?

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: If I understand your question correctly, there is no difference between what you've described. Compression and expansion are simply turning the volume up or down. Dynamic EQ is no different aside from the fact that it's limited to a specific frequency.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Compression is knocking level down at a certain threshold. Dynamic EQ can be used to compress or expand very specific EQ ranges at a certain threshold. It's like super focused multiband compression with the ability to expand or compress.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
i actually don't know what this means. maybe someone on here can come explain. "gain movement" is "more transparent than compression" doesn't make sense to me. seems like the same thing.

other than that dynamic eq and multiband compression are essentially the same. there are multiband compressors that will split the signal into multiple bands by default, so you're gonna get some phase shift between the bands, even if you're not compressing. but some plugins you can disengage the bands so depending on the plug-in architecture, you'd presumably not be getting the phase shift if you're turning off the band splitting

community_answers.author: Maxim
community_answers.content: Hmm, I always saw compression and volume as 2 different things. One just compresses the signal "making smaller" and the other just gains it with volume. Would probably be easier to describe with a drawing. Might be the same thing and I'm just envisioning words differently though.

community_answers.author: Maxim
community_answers.content:
"Unlike compression, dynamic EQ affects the sound by dynamically changing the gain of an EQ band. Like compression, however, and using the threshold, it does this proportionally in response to the amplitude of the input signal."

From Izotope website

community_answers.author: Maxim
community_answers.content: I view compression as "squeezing" sound together if that makes sense. So I didn't understand the use of Dynamic EQ if it's just compression that you can set like an eq. But if it's just a workflow thing that's cool I guess.

community_answers.author: Maxim
community_answers.content:
Yeah to me visually it makes a lot of sense that there is a difference between the two in terms of processing. But the different use cases seem pretty obvious too:

"If you want to attenuate a specific “problem” frequency or small range of frequencies, a dynamic EQ would be your best bet. The option to have narrower bands allows for this kind of focused attenuation.

Conversely, if you’re trying to control larger areas of the frequency spectrum, a multiband compressor works well. Also the non-linear way a compressor attenuates signal can add character to a signal. If you don’t need the surgical control, but want some subtle sonic coloration, a multiband compressor can be a better choice than a dynamic EQ."

question: with narrative i mean the incentive to cater towards the prosumer crowd, which has obviously blown up due to the democratization of music production and become a big market for software companies in particular

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: You should be critical of both

expert_answers.author: David Fuller
expert_answers.content: Realistically unless an implementation is so bad as to be broken jitter is a non-issue

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Agreed -- be critical of everything. Be critical of things that are expensive for the sake of being expensive. Things that are just  instagram ads shilling to newbies. Critical of  Greg Wells pandering to whatever his base is. But recommending a 4k converter based on 'audible conversion quality' isn't helpful if the consumer doesn't have a million other ducks in a row first -- room treatment, adequate monitoring, proper gainstaging, etc. Jon has that figured out, so it makes sense for him. But when people come into a forum with questionable knowledge and background in music production asking what's the best converter, I think it's fair to ask some prying questions before just making blanket recommendations on what one person heard or not. I have plenty of semi-OK stuff that still gets used on the regular, and plenty of expensive gear that I would happily toss out of my workflow. They're all just tools. And whether its bougie DW Fearn or a black-friday Acustica plugin, , if it works for your workflow and gets you results you're happy with, then its worth whatever money you're willing to pay for it.

community_answers.content: software is alot more profitable than hardware since it has no overhead costs once something is developed

question: I know it’s not your main genre, but have you ever done any hip hop or 808 based pop music? If do whats your mindset when working with predominantly big transients and a lot of sub frequencies? I’m always struggling getting to competitive loudness. Sometimes it’ll sound great sometimes it won’t. I’m just not very consistent with it tbh.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: I haven’t found a good consistent workflow yet. Other genres are fine. These just tend to mess with me. I’m not getting how all these big release get that loud without folding in on them selves.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I don't work in it a ton, but yeah, the game is won in the low end. It's usually a matter of building up the low end  first and bringing the mix to the brink of crapping out whatever master chain you have without completely falling apart. Then trying to shoe horn in the other elements with aggressive & drastic scooping to maintain the gain structure you've got going with the 808s. Like Jon says often, it's usually about turning things down to gain headroom, and then making it up with low end boosts or high cuts. It's so impressive when it's done right -- shoutout to J.C. -- him and Ali are the best in the game IMHO.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: thanks for the answer! That is def a lot of what I’m doing as well. But doing that while trying to keep the original “sound” of the demos, while being consistent. I have a mighty respect for these guys. 🤙

question: Hey guys, this may be a silly question, but regarding Jon’s streams: can some explain to me how he usually decides to cut frequencies without sweeping for them? Is he just making decisions visually? Or only listening to the effect the cut has?

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
I think it comes down to ear training, lots of repetition (mixes), and focused practice. He's very familiar with the characteristic sound that each frequency zone imparts on a given instrument and has mixed most instruments enough times to know how to achieve a given effect without having to hunt for it.

On top of that, he's probably thinking an order of magnitude higher than that because he would also understand that if he wants to accentuate a given frequency range in an instrument then he can do that by subtracting that frequency from an adjacent instrument. In this sense, I think he's listening closely to the effect that a cut has on every other instrument in a mix - not just the instrument he's subtracting from.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: Not true. I’ve been to his place and he has a giant Price is Right esque wheel with a variety of frequencies written on it. He just gives it a massive spin and gets lucky A LOT.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
I have it on good authority that he once went a week without realizing that the wheel was busted and unwittingly submitted a mix with practically no 3.2kHz.

Surprisingly that mix was still accepted with only a single note from the A+R: "+1dB at 812Hz."

Those who heard the mix said it was "avant-garde" and "visionary". "A glimpse of the future" they said.

question:
hello gang, here's my newbie question :

what do matt & jon & every mixer ever mean when they use the word "under" ? as in, "sometimes the hihat is sitting under the vocal."

is it more of a fundamental pitch/tone thing, a delay/ambience thing, a dynamics/volume/saturation thing ? i guess it's all of it ?

i do get a sense of it when listening to good mixes but i don't really know the steps to get there for my own stuff.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: The basic answer is simply volume. If the vocal is “on top” it means it feels like the loudest thing. If somethings under, usually simply means it’s quieter.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: But reverb is potentially another way but I consider that “depth” or “behind” so to speak.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: yeah i think i usually say something is under another sound when two elements are* sitting in a similar place in the mix (pan or frequency or space) and the "over" sound is clear while the "under" never bothers it

community_answers.author: louisvie
community_answers.content: okayy thank you so much !

community_answers.author: louisvie
community_answers.content: interesting ! ty for answering.

community_answers.author: louisvie

question: Is there a shortcut in Pro Tools for moving vocals up in a playlist without pressing the ⬆️ button? Google ain’t useful.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Select the region you wanna promote to the top and hit control+option+v

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Another useful tip is using shift-S to solo each playlist. I usually move the cursor down on the time line, then shift-s, then play to audition whats on the playlist. If you are hunting for a particular word/phrase, you can highlight the region and use control-p or control-; to move up or down through the playlists, then hit shift-s, then hit play to listen. Then if its the one, promote it to the top playlist with control-option-v. If you get the motions in your brain, you can really fly through takes and get a comp together quickly.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: For sure, if you've got keyboard focus mode on (the little az button in the top right corner). I keep it off because I find I make more mistakes with it on.

question: My fellow noob mixers (< 5 years) just curious how long does it take y’all to mix a track? I know deadlines affect this but I’m just wondering where y’all are it with your experience. I feel like I’m usually spending 10 hours on a song at least. (Feel free to tell me that’s not enough)

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: It can vary for me really widely depending on what you are given.  If you are like me you might be getting a huge range of recording quality and performances.  A track with 100+ channels and live tracked drums in someone’s bedroom studio is going to take a lot longer than an acoustic track with a vocal.

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters

I’m sure others have said it, but taking an ear break from one mix to prep your next , and maybe work on a specific technical issue in another (clip gaining esses for example ) ...can just help me not get bogged down and always moving through the to do list

question:
There is a caveat here, in that Matt and I actually have an endgame here, which is keep the flow, don’t bog down the artist with nerd shit, and give them the best sounding track to work from. Where I disagree is the work to properly align it when it gets back, I’ve found it’s not too vibe killing to just have them copy paste my square wave down on to the end of their track. It’s one extra key command that most people can handle, and gives me (and the artist) the confidence that I’ve fully respected and captured their unique flow and timing. 

Right before I end up moving every word and syllable and breathe anyway.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
Beckley leans a little more pro engineer and I lean a little more art pirate. Sometimes leaning one way makes for challenges on the other side.

It seems we agree that you shouldn't compromise the sound of the track just to get some perfect grid alignment all the way through. But you also have some good technical options to make it easier on your end when you get the vocal back.

Right before you're gonna end up moving every word and syllable and breath anyway.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: I will say, I have found that just a LITTLE bit of audio nerding in my humble experience gives the artist some confidence that I’ve got them and their best interests are in safe hands with me, unlike Cians Mom.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
Also, again, after decades of getting sent a fucking mp3 with non compensated mastering bus plugins on it, you don’t whine, you line it up quick best you can and get on with it. Don’t bitch about it and deal with it after the artist leaves, slaving in a darkened room accompanied only by a glass of whiskey. 

So much of our job comes down to “just solve the fucking problem and move TF on”

question:
I have a follow up question on delay compensation in Pro Tools and will say I've run into similar problems with ODs not lining up when tracked with mixbus processing on ref file. In this scenario with the mixbus would it be that the OD files would be off by the exact amount of dly samples shown at the bottom of the mixbus track with the inserts on it or would it be that pro tools has compensated some but not all and that's why it's off? I mean I've had days where I'll print through the same chain back into pro tools on a mixdown track and it won't line up the same as the day before which just makes me question what the feckkk is going on with delay compensation in pro tools..?

Side note I've found it helpful to keep a duplicate 'submaster' / mixbus channel with zero inserts on it for use when tracking / OD. I'll flip back and forth for monitoring when need be.

question: I’m sorry what do you mean “as clean as [you] can?”

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: (@ALXCPH’s ideas are all interesting and creative btw.)

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
If you don’t want to get too creative- I would use a dynamic eq dip around the “presence” frequencies, side chained to the vocal that comes in and overlaps it. 
So vocal “b” comes in on top of vocal “a” and like 3-5k gets ducked a few db. Or maybe the very top would work better than 3-5k… depends on the vocal.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: That’s subtle, clean, easy.

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content:
I mean that there are some spots in the lead vocal where a held note from the previous line is still going while a new one comes in over it. I.e. there's a 'LV 1' and 'LV2' channel and they overlap at some points.

I know that's how the artist intended for it to sound, so I don't want to get too "creative" with it, but also don't want the tails of lines on their way out obscuring the beginning of the next line

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: The reason I referred to the sidechain stuff is because a vocal producer I used to work with would, in similar situations, use an instance of Waves Vocal Rider on each channel, sidechained to one another, to 'even it out'

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: But I'm not sure that's necessarily a best practice, or even advisable

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: That's such a good idea!

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: Subtle clean and easy indeed

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: I was thinking in terms of ducking the whole vocal but that just sounded stupid aggressive when I tried it just now

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: Thank you, I'm gonna try with the dynamic EQ

question: anyone know how to achieve and set this kind of effect up? im confused on how hes able to have the panning "tempo" synced https://youtube.com/shorts/pMdb4szzuGg?feature=share

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: I think Mike’s not talking about the panning or very placement being tempo synced, he’s talking about the reverb length

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Could be wrong, I’ll ask him for you if we don’t get a better answer here

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Mike is gonna chime in

community_answers.author: skeed
community_answers.content: OH!!! that could be it! Thank you for the reply and i appreciate that, that would be dope!

community_answers.author: MikeMillerMixes
community_answers.content: Hey guys it’s not the panning that’s synced. It’s the pre delay for the reverb. The sound is sent to pairs of objects that are mapped to points in the room and each one has a different predelay so that it moves the room.

community_answers.author: skeed
community_answers.content: Ah yesss makes sense 🙏 thanks so much for the explanation!! Loved the interview a ton

question: There's also a really interesting aspect which is that not all languages say high/low. Some use size analogy, calling low pitches 'big' and high pitches 'small' which might have to do with big, low sounds associated with natural phenomena and large animals and small, high sounds associated with small animals or slight movements (thunder or a stampede vs rustling leaves or a mouse squeaking)

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Hmmm. Low frequencies are harder to localize with our ears and end up feeling enveloping and "everywhere". On the other hand, high frequency sounds are much easier to assign to a specific location in space and end up sounding like they're actually emitting from the speaker which is usually at ear level. Perhaps that's part of it.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: I’ve personally never had that association of frequencies and height—though I’ve heard other people talk about it 🤷🏻‍♂️

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Y'know, I never really felt that way until I got some subs. Now I get it.

community_answers.author: sukhuno
community_answers.content: Could be that lower freq are omnidirectional (including the ground) whereas higher are directional and more likely to shoot at your head vs everywhere

question:
Hey guys, I have probably a noob question but here it is : 

when i read that, for example, "Halo Channel strip is Serban's channel strip of choice for all of his mixes"
What does "channel strip" means exactly ? 
Does it mean Serban puts the plugin on all of his tracks ?? 
Does it mean Serban puts the plugin just on his master track (i'm working in Ableton) ?
Does it mean Serban puts the plugin into a bus and sends some tracks into it ? 

Mainly my question is : what is a channel strip ? 

Thanks :keknervous:

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Channel strips can go anywhere, but more likely to be on individual tracks. If you think of a traditional console, every channel on a console has a channel strip (hence the name). If you're trying to emulate that workflow, you'd put them on every track.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: This is why we have a newbie question channel! ❤️

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: What the hell does it mean when mixers bounce out a mix that says “HEATED” are they literally referring to Avid HEAT or is it something else

community_answers.author: Maxim
community_answers.content:
It's basically just a plugin that has a bunch of functions in one (like EQ, compression, gate, filters). This workflow comes from the big consoles that you see (or used to see) in big studios.

It can still have its uses today to prevent decision fatigue with so many plugin options. 

That said, I wouldn't get too caught up on what Serban uses or doesn't.

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content: Alright, all clear now, thanks

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content: sorry for the boring questions, but it's really bothering me now

question: One of my genelec 1031a cones has a split around it's silicone rim. Could I (or maybe a shop) replace it with another cone? Do both of the monitors have to be calibrated to match?

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Drivers are very specific, if you replace it with anything other than the correct path the levels and frequency response can change

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Unless budget is very tight you should replace both LF drivers at the same time - old and new can be an issue in itself (from someone who has done this hundreds of times)

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: Best together if you can

community_answers.author: river
community_answers.content: Feels like it makes sense the cones would have to be very similar, and made sure they were all installed close to the original

community_answers.author: river
community_answers.content: Okay, thank you for your advice !! :)

question: If you're a busy mix and or master engineer, do you get time to retrospectively listen to your work?

community_answers.author: Jeremy Klein

community_answers.author: shaunobi
community_answers.content: It takes me years to go back, but then I do, and I remember what was going on and it brings me memories. Often times someone has to go through a major life event and then I go listen to music I mixed for them, or played with them, or whatever... community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content: I love this. Truly, I feel like the coolest part of doing music is the people. Someone I met recently gave me an advice as I was telling her that I moved to LA recently and looking to get involved with as many things as I can. She said “it will take some time to find your people and your community, but after some time it will turn into a cool little family of music makers and it is the most wonderful thing ever”. I think many people have said similar things, but that was the first time hearing the word family.

community_answers.author: Chad Rodgers
community_answers.content:
I back this so much, man. 

As a young artist I found myself deep in the UK music industry and had some awesome successes but some crushing lows, too. Meetings with the majors, false promises, yada yada… I was like a sapling in a massive forest, in good company but super overwhelmed and without the tools and advice I needed to make a lot of the right decisions. A lot of my collaborators just wanted to make some good music / earn some money and never really offered any advice or wisdom. And that’s fine, no shade there.

But fast forward to now where I’m at working as a producer with lots of new, young, independent artists, I’m doing my best to not just be a guy for hire, but a friend in the industry. I try to give my advice, share my experiences openly and honestly, and empower them as much as possible to avoid the pitfalls I found myself in like ten years ago as a hungry kid wanting to impress everyone.

All about that concept of being who you needed when you were younger, mate 👌

question: This has been on my mind lately, so I just figured I should run it across: I was being mentored (mixing) by this guy who I respect tremendously. He was always telling me that I need to replace my plugins (have been using free plugins for the longest) and suggested that I start with Waves and some of the UAD offerings. So, I went ahead and downloaded all the Waves counterparts (UAD wouldn't work on my computer for some reason) to my stable of free plugins and did a mix that way. At first I really liked it, but then the sound of the Waves stuff began to wear on me for some reason. That's the only way I can describe it - The sound started to wear on me. So, now I'm back to using my free plugins and liking mixing again. All that to say: Is there any reason I shouldn't use free plugins?? I have zero knowledge of what's going on "under the hood" of all this stuff. Zero technological prowess in that regard whatsoever. The only way i know how to tell if something is "better" than the other is by feeling, I suppose. So, yeah. And all these paid plugins, I mean... it's a lot of money. Thanks, ya'll.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Only maybe worth slowly collecting the most common ones if you want to open sessions from collaborators, but whatever works works!  Stock plugins are also stupid good in daws now.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
One other thing about paid plugins from large companies - you can count on Waves or UAD, Soundtoys, Izotope all updating their tools on newer OS.  Some (definitely not all) free plugs are made by people starting out in developing plugins and they might move on to other things.

Actually in the middle of this situation now where a single dev plugin was used on a track and I can’t even buy the license anymore.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: As long as you don’t mind that (or if you are on Windows it may not become an issue) then there’s no reason to immediately abandon what’s working

community_answers.author: Nick Stetina

community_answers.author: esquinalee
community_answers.content: If it sounds good… it is good. There’s a lot out there that stock plugins won’t do, or single 3rd party plugins that do what 3 or more stock plugs might, but I would maybe check out videos on some of the more common 3rd party plugin staples like Soundtoys & Fabfilter & Valhalla and suss out which ones give you colors and options you don’t already have that you might like

community_answers.author: Nick Stetina
community_answers.content: I would also caution against trying to switch everything out at once, that sounds like a lot to wrap your head around. If you identify some part of the process that you feel could potentially be improved, then you might start auditioning plug-ins to solve that specific problem/opportunity. Be ruthlessly objective in your review period!

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content:
There is no longevity in trying to make every song to be the perfect song. There will be shitty songs, there will be mediocre ones, and there will be great ones. 

Work until you can’t think of anything immediately actionable to make it better. Anything beyond it is experimentation- which you could do, but try not to spend more than 5 minutes on each “what if”s. 

I found 80% theory helpful. 

Do your 80% not 100%. next year, your 80% is going to be your last years 125% or possibly more

There’s beauty in capturing what it was at the time. That’s why we call records “records”. This beauty can get lost when you’re trying to do more than what it is, what it wants to be. I had to learn this the hard way, and I am still learning. 

Because language affects our thoughts, another thing I found helpful is taking the word “perfect” off the vocabulary list too. I’ve let go of the word perfect and had to put conscious effort into not using the word. 

I highly doubt that the bottleneck to you being able to put out a record is your ability or production technique. It’s the idealism. I speak from my personal experience. 

There is nothing wrong with learning, that is great. But at some point of learning- your ability and output needs to catch up to the knowledge. 

Hiring a good producer could also keep you moving forward.

question: Normal? Maybe. Healthy? No. Avoidable? Probably…

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Looks like the crowd's opinion is split 😄. To put a finer point on my answer, when I say it's not normal I don't mean to imply that you are abnormal. It's common for people to feel this level of stress and overwhelm. But it's not the sort of thing I'd ever encourage anyone to normal*ize*, if the temptation is there.

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content:
@bobby k I'm curious how old you are/where you are in your journey. I'd say as years go on, I've learned to separate feelings of pressure/responsibility/schedule density from "stress" or being "overwhelmed" in the true sense. There's that Dale Becker quote, "Don't feel victimized by your work." Making peace with what it feels like to be responsible for someone's record, or your own music, is important. It carries a lot of weight, but it's a privelage to be able to do it and it should not break your spirit. Not that that's necessarily what's got you feeling this way.

Lots of ways to dive deeper if you'd like to share more about where you're coming from.

question: For example: In Reaper you can adjust the crossfade parameters. You right click on a crossfade, and all of a sudden you can adjust the miliseconds of the crossfade, the angle of the "x", the shape of the top half of the x and the bottom half of the x... For a guy like me, this opens up a whole world of possibilities. I immediately want to know what "this crossfade sounds like and what this cross fade sounds like and what this does to this part and blah, blah, blah..." Like, there's too much shit to learn - too many parameters. And in my mind, they all sound different. You see what I'm saying??

expert_answers.author: Edward Rivera
expert_answers.content: I don’t think crossfades is the right rabbit hole to be going down

expert_answers.author: Edward Rivera
expert_answers.content: Just set the crossfades, make sure it’s not affecting your transients, and carry on. Not much else to it

expert_answers.author: Edward Rivera
expert_answers.content: Zoom in to your regions and set those crossfades to happen before the transients. If I make a cut to a drum and move it, I’ll almost always drag the region back out to the left and give myself the slack to make my crossfades

question: Very nice, thank you... Are you typically eqing a lot? Are there tracks/ sessions where you find yourself barely doing anything at all?

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: If you sweep endlessly you'll find endless "nasty frequencies" that aren't necessarily nasty in context

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: so only zap those things that bother you when everything is playing in context

expert_answers.author: Edward Rivera
expert_answers.content:
I would say pay less attention. When you’re in “hunting mode” you’re queued in on to everything except the part that matters: the music. 

Listen to the song without asking yourself “what else can I get outta here” I think that sets you up for wrong moves, more delays, etc…if there’s something that needs your attention it should be somewhat obvious and a bit basic, not some tiny clinical move that will suddenly open up the record. 

And yet, in some cases even _that_ is true.

question: I'm glad you're bringing these things up because I am currently dealing with them all. Much less experienced than everyone on here, but the one metric I keep coming back to is: Do I respond to it emotionally - The track that is... If the performance is flawless and the mix is hitting all the specs on the nerd meter, but i'm not responding to it emotionally, then, I mean... I dunno. Currently trying to reconcile this emotional response that I consider so paramount with the fact that things aren't quite where I want them to be sonically. Sometimes, I think you just have to find the right plugins that will enable you to move closer to what you want sonically without fucking with the flow. Kind of a catch 22 at times. Regarding the plugin thing being good on the stock setting: I read somewhere a while back that most plugin makers put the stock setting as stock because that's where they thought the plugin sounded best. I sometimes feel like if I use a stock setting that I'm cheating as a mixer, but am I even a mixer?? Lol. I'm just a musician fiddling with knobs.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: nobody's going to judge you for the settings you used on a plugin or if you used a preset or if it was really extra super hard or if it was really extra super easy. literally nobody cares. they'll only hear the music. focus on the music. don't conflate time spent as a yardstick for the value of the outcome -- there is often little, if any, correlation.

expert_answers.author: Edward Rivera
expert_answers.content: I read something long ago about how a delay in a project increases the chances of subsequent delays and so on and so forth. The example used was the Sydney opera house and how it underwent several delays as a result of the previous one and went way over budget. I’m articulating it horribly but it stuck with me

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Reminds me of people saying “oh but Espresso is just Splice loops, I could’ve made that song!!”

community_answers.author: Will Pragnell

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: Beautifully put. I’d argue there is an inverse correlation with time spent and outcome, if any
