question: Helped a friend through a tech issue today - and it was a long parade of  “and what about this specific combination of things?”. There were two fairly simple principles underlying all of the questions, and if learned once would pre-empt the next 50 questions too

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: It occurred to me that specific knowledge like asking a helpline person how to connect A to B is brittle. As soon as you swap B for C you have to go searching again

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: If you can go a layer deeper and gain an understanding of an underlying principle then you are much more flexible and resilient

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content: Edward De Bonos book "lateral thinking" is brilliant on this. In order that we can deduce helpful / survival info from the sensory deluge of  our external perceptions we look for patterns in everything. This is helpful until new information comes along. The choice then is do you break up the old pattern and reconfigure to accomodate the new information , or do you discount the new information to protect the old pattern .Sort of speaks to everything in life

question: My biggest thing with compression is how it changes the "pulse" of everything. How do you guys get around that?? It totally changes the pocket - Compression. I avoid it whenever possible for this reason alone. I do see it as a tool with tons of potential to create different sounds, though... Help.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: gotta dial those attack/release times

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content:
@BoozleBAM hey man hope you’ve been well . 

I find one of the things I use compression for most often is to really find the pocket and make things dance between elements

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content:
In programmed music you can shape adsr in the sampler of course, but compression allows us to do this also

Embrace it man , get a feel for it and then you’ll have so much power to manipulate that pocket . Both of an instrument and its relationship to other instruments ….and then between buses etc .

community_answers.author: Jemody
community_answers.content: Also having the right ratio helps a lot if thats an option

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Right. That's my biggest problems with most compressors - Those parameters are fixed. WHich makes zero sense to me...

community_answers.author: Jemody
community_answers.content: That tends to be the case with opto compressors from what I've found, if you get a nice vu or fet compressor you usually have more options when it comes to it

community_answers.content: Honestly I just played around with stock plugins since those usually have everything you need

community_answers.content: I havent personally tried them heavily but you can try looking into the kilohearts freeware

question: Oh, forgot to mention this yesterday- What do you think about 421 on snare??

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
It’s definitely good. I like 57 better still after many years of trying both. The 421 usually has a weird mid peak I don’t like, hihat rejection isn’t better. I do like the low end capture though. It’s totally a great choice for snare. 

441 to me is the answer if you like a 421 on snare. You’ll love the 441 when you get the chance to use one.

question: I need a headphone extension cable....will be coming out of the headphone out of an interface w a good headphone amp. Will the legnth or thickness of the cable affect quality? I can get a long 25 or 50 ft 1/8" male to 1/8" female, or a 1/4" cable that's thicker. Also, will there be any tone loss if I use a Y splitter at the headphone output at the interface so I can turn 1 output into 2?

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: the longer you do an unbalanced run (stereo over trs is unbalanced), the more susceptible you are to noise etc, the best way to avoid this on a long run is to use a balanced feed but you're probably fine with 25ft on the unbalanced run

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: No noise issues with headphone level feeds

expert_answers.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_answers.content: It’s like a small speaker cable

question: Can you describe the signal path from mic to DAW?

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: 9.9/10 if the room mics aren’t working it’s not cause the mics are bad, it’s cause the room isn’t great. Also 9/10 drum rooms aren’t great so don’t beat yourself up!

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: bundle up a section of your drum recording into a folder of multi-tracks and shoot em over, I can take a peek and see if there any big 'aha's to be had.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Okay, excellent. Yes, I have that compressor and remember being very impressed with it the last time I took it our for a spin!

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: - MIC> interface 1 pre> Spdif *out* of interface 1 into spidif *in* on interface 2 (via a digital wire)> usb out of interface 2 into laptop> DAW... Interface 1 has to kind of go in through the back of interface two and get "daisy chained" so to speak. It all sounds fine. When you hear they you just go, "yeah, those sound like rooms mics," but I've just never been able to get them to flatter any of my mixes. I want to really spend some time digging in to some of these different methods, though. I'd love to find a place for them in the mix.

question: Are you standing in the other room ever?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
I try to put my cabs in other rooms or spaces away from me.

I turn the amp up as loud or quiet as it needs to sound good. 

My JMP 100, similar to a JCM800, sits at about 3 on the master and dimed on the preamp. Sometimes I use an attenuator and go up to 7 on the master

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: @BoozleBAM I find the headphones can be fatiguing and lie about your tone, if you’re able to monitor your amp through your speakers in front of pro tools I find that to be more confidence inducing and less “what the fuck is this” later

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: But I’ve done 1000’s of recordings in the same room as the amp with headphones

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: OKay, since you're asking and I guess for posterity... I layed down what I thought were going to be scratch vocals, guitars and bass to a click a while back - I thought I was just going to discard these and lay the drums over top and come back and do everything again like I've done a million times before when working with other people. Once I finished the drums (which took a while) I tried to come in lay the bass and it was just NOT WORKING. I don't know why exactly, but I was just not syncing up. Tried it with the click without the click, neither worked... For some reason, when I'm doing all the parts on my own, i have to build things backwards - starting with the click, then guitar, vox, bass and drums last, otherwise things won't sync up. A lot of the time I spent on drums was simply writing the parts, so now that that is out of the way, tracking them again should go much more quickly. The End.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: IF I had taken the vocals more seriously when I did all those "scratch tracks" I would have an album by now, but a lot of those parts I was just humming or whispering or whatever because I was thining "these will all be replaced" anyway. So, yeah... The guitars and the bass are all times stretched to smitherenes, too, from getting things to the right tempo for the drums, so it will be nice to dial those things in and play them at the right tempo from the beginning.

question: I think from watching the LWMR streams, saturation can be a tool to increase perceived loudness without actually impacting the headroom right? That's one thing I've been trying to get into more

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
In addition to the advice here, you might want to jump on #🤝collab-talk talk and ask if there's anyone willing to give you mix feedback. I'm sure you'll get some takers and you can send stuff to folks in the DMs. 

As @masteredbyjack says, loudness is more of a perception that you achieve in the arrangement and mix than the LUFS number. Learning how to treat sounds to make them feel loud is a big part of loudness.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: A lot of the conversation about saturation on the streams we did is useful if you already understand compression. Jon talked quite a bit about sometimes using saturation instead of compression, but that is actually a pretty subtle point because most things that Jon mixes **already have tons of compression on them**. So I would say using compressors and limiters is the best place to start with making sounds you've recorded FEEL loud without just turning them up.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
When Jon receives a song to mix, there is almost always a lot of compression on the individual stems, especially drums and vocals. So he does more subtle moves to bring out the best in each mix. If you're recording stuff yourself, you will likely want to add a lot of compression to get the same modern, perceived loudness.

The fundamental thing to know is that "compression" simply means "reducing the dynamic range" (aka "compressing" the range of volume of your sound ). This can be achieved with "compressors" as well as "limiters," "saturators," "clippers," "distortion," and a number of other types of effects that do it in different ways (and may add other sonic characteristics to your sound).

community_answers.author: M J
community_answers.content: Thank you, I think I was starting to lose the forest for the trees when I heard you and him discuss that point and forgot that he did say he does receive things already compressed.

community_answers.author: M J
community_answers.content: Always appreciate the advice!

question: Is there a question attached to this or just trying to get their take on this subject?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
what you're saying makes sense. Couple things to try;

1. different click sound! I really like "marimba 2" in pro tools for some reason. really easy to hear always, feels REALLY on time.

2. Maybe try having a timed delay on one of your drum signals you can play off of. like a 1/16 note or triplet echo very faintly that, when you're in the pocket, grooves with your drumming. might be tough if you're doing really busy proggy stuff or if you're really worried about timing from an OCD perspective.

3. if you have scratch guitar/bass tracks that were tracked to a click/perfectly gridded drum thing, playing along to that is usually far more inspiring and you can rely less on the click because you can just listen to the instruments.

4. This is where having someone else record you helps. you might be totally in your head about this. a "producer" could be like "bro that take was legit perfect"

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: even if you FELT weird about it.

expert_answers.author: Will Melones
expert_answers.content: Try adding a shaker loop to your click track. I’m not a competent recording drummer, but a lot of people I record have a better time *feeling* a shaker and grooving with it like another band member, which is tough to do with a metronome

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Well, actually, there is a question, yes:

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: So, I've tested this a lot. The wording might sound weird: If I have the click track "too loud" in my headphones, I end up adapting with my drumming and my drumming kind of sucks a little bit - I end up compensating with my hits subconsciously because Im' kind of letting the click track "hit" for me. If that makes any sense. The way I can get around this is by having the click so that I can barely hear it. Only thing is, my drumming can be a little... less tight this way, and some measure of beat detective might have to be invoked at some point, if you get what I'm saying...

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Just wondering if there might be a way around this. Maybe different click sounds or something I could be doing in the pre-pro or something. Just wondering.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: - It's like, having the click at a comfortable level for me to hear it all the time results in a less impassioned take. I have to drop it past the point of it being comfortably "hearable."

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: I know that might sound absolutely wacky.

question:
1) a strong work ethic: You have to be willing to put in the time and energy into the project. You will always be the first person there and the last to leave. Once you accept this and work it into your life, it just becomes the way it is!

2) a good personality: You need to be good around people. Half of this job is psychological. You have to know when to speak up as well as when to not say anything. Talkback etiquette is crucial. Learn to read people. Never get angry or passive aggressive. You always need to be voice of reason. People have to trust you.

3) a solid skill-set: You have to always know what your doing and be confident in your abilities. Know the technical side of things. You should also be musically inclined. Be curious! Why does a song sound a certain way? How did they do it? If you don't care and don't want to know – you should do something else.

4) actual follow through: You'd be surprised how many flaky people work in this business. If you're a guy that does things when you say you'll do them and answers phonecalls/emails in a timely manner, then you're already leagues above most other people.

5) the ability to network with people and capitalize on your relationships is the only way to move forward in this business. Going to shows, parties, events, etc. You never know where work is going to come from.

Your work gets you work. Make sure everything you do is the best representation of your abilities. Don't choose which projects to care more about. Give it your all on everything... even if its a shitty gig. That word will spread and you'll start getting more work through that.

Hope this helpful. Good luck!

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Just a small note: when you say you weren’t feeling their system, that reads as a possible red flag. Assuming these studios are not run by total hacks (and therefore worthy of you not wanting to be involved), you’re most likely going to have to work on lots and lots of stuff you don’t like, for a long time. And that might apply to working in ways you wouldn’t personally choose. But—again, assuming these studios are at least semi-decent—you’ll learn a lot by involving yourself in other peoples’ work flows. Then you can take it or leave it as you see fit in your own work.

question:
What are you doing for chords? A common pitfall of static arrangements is getting locked into the same four bar chord loop. Sometimes you've got to break out of that. Start there, even if it's as simple as telling a different story with your chords over eight bars versus four bars.

Play with the harmonic rhythm of your chord changes. Some very basic examples:
1. Instead of a single chord every measure, alternate between one chord per measure and two chords per measure.
2. Hold on a single chord for six measures and then do a cadence with a quick succession of chords on bars seven and eight.
3. Take your progression and play it at half the speed (a four bar progression becomes an eight bar progression).

I know you said you're just making beats right now, but chords or a melody are going to inform and motivate your "players" and show them what to do. There needs to be some "meat" to the song for them to react to. If you don't like the melody you can mute it later. But give your "players" something to react to.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
**Other ideas:**

Call and response between the players.
Give the players big unison hits that they can land on together.
Everybody takes a big rest.
Everybody takes a big rest except one player.
Everybody plays the melody in unison.
Hocket the melody between players.
Swap roles among the players (Guitar plays like a drummer, drummer plays melodically, bassist sings).
Counterpoint.
Play dynamically.
Dynamics that rise or fall over two or more bars.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
**Some More (cause you've got me thinking):**

Kick off the song with a bang.
Write a deliberate introduction. (This is big. It will give your record propulsion, confidence and purpose instead of dropping the listener into the middle.)
End the record in a conclusive and unmistakable way.

Everybody plays as soft as they can.
Everybody plays as loud as they can.
The louder you play the simpler the part has to be.
The softer you play the faster the part has to be.

Role play. Choose an emotion/mindset and embody that as the player: melancholy, furious, chaotic, childlike, meek.

Instrumental fills every few bars.
Take a solo. A short one.
Make some noise!

Listen to your song at different tempos.
Do a dramatic speed up or slow down - This will show you new aspects of your groove.

Unexpected part entrance.
Intro solo before the band enters.

Only two instrumental parts allowed. Be minimal and sparse.
Write a melody starting with the kick pattern.

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content:
Harmonic Rhythm bit is definitely helpful. I don’t explore this often enough outside of #1. 

I think I naturally gravitate towards vamp like progressions. I want to break out of it though and have chords that tell stories rather than just feelings. 

Because of the vampy- nature of a lot of chord progressions I end up with, the first chord of new section and coming back around is something i find myself having trouble with consistently

question: When I hear Dr Luke and others talk about riding the vocal on the chandler throughout the performance into an 1176. Are they talking about riding the input or the output of the chandler?  How much gain reduction do you think those pop vocal producers in that camp are getting during tracking?

expert_answers.author: chrissorem
expert_answers.content: I can’t speak for Dr Luke,  @BatMeckley might be able to chime in here.  In my experience, on some occasions I have to ride the input gain between a verse or chorus if there is a large dynamic difference. I’d rather split that up if it’s an option for the singer but if it’s a live take you have to do whatever is necessary to make it sound great. Sometimes attenuating the output gain. Sometimes  i have my hands on the compressor input and output and I’m attenuating both. I like a 176 compressor for this as it’s  very forgiving in gain reduction. If I can’t manage any of the above I mult the vocal and have one safety track with the gain trimmed to a safe spot

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
Honestly, that line is a bit over blown. It’s more “oh the chorus is louder, let’s knock it back a click or two on the input so it doesn’t distort”

We were usually recording songs in fairly small sections, making sure to get the details right. There wasn’t a lot of jedi like fader riding. On very rare occasions if I knew there was going to be a huge dynamic shift I’d reach out and grab the output fader, but I can probably count on one hand how many times I’ve had to do that.

We were fairly conservative on the 1176 on the way in, largely cause you can’t un crunch a vocal that’s been over compressed, but once the vocal was in PT it would be hit by just irresponsible levels of compression and limiting. Like goes against how virtually every “expert” online would tell you how to do it. Most people would tell you the solo’d tracks would sound bad, but as part of the song their impact is objectively unarguable

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin

Pretty much just the meters next to the faders on PT, with calibration they correlate to loudness in the room. I use the standard RMS + Peak metering next to the fader and that works well.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
You can sneak in some early reflections from a reverb to add space around the vocals without sounding overtly spacious. That should give the sound some depth without reading as “processed”.

Björk is notorious for having her vocals bone dry. Based on what you’ve described I might give her a listen for  suggestions on how to proceed.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
@Zack Hames yes! Play with short delays and short verbs and slaps with low pass eq. H3000 has some great stereoizing chorus type effects too. 

I just did a super dry vocal that had delay and verb like this. I used waves supertap with left and right slightly different but super short delay times. Almost phasing. Barely blended in at -20dB. Then I used Valhalla Vintage Verb on the small ambience setting at like 4%. It widens the vocal and gives it space without sounding at all "wet"

question:
One approach to recalling board mixes a la Ben Baptie: If there’s a tweak, he pulls up the relevant stem (printed through the board) against the mix and flips its phase, essentially taking it out of the mix (or enough to make adjustments then recombine through ITB mix chain).

Might not work as well if there’s wow and flutter on your Otari, but could be worth experimenting with?

question: Only and all feel here -- there's not really much more than that. How does the pocket feel? The emotion? That's all really

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content:
Of course depends on the tempo, part, sound of the drums, aesthetic of the track - but a few things that have worked in different scenarios for me:

Create the impression of some distance to walls by sending snare (start there, maybe add other mics) to a short stereo delay. Often something like 90ms on one side, 120ms on the other. Feel it out on one side, then add some time to the other.

Try adding some fake distance to your existing room mics with a simple delay with no feedback (there’s a Steve Albini drum video on YouTube where he demonstrates this). You can delay both sides equally, or solo one side, delay it til it feels good/sounds cool, then do the other. Anything from 12ms-around 23 seems to work. From there things start to become more like a slap, but than can be cool too.

Smash up your existing rooms a bit, or a lot. Omnipressor, Devil Loc, UAD Zener, decapitator, Rough Rider (free), Arousor/Distressor in nuke, Lo-Fi. 

Send to a gated verb - Cian shared a drum session a while back with a short VintageVerb preset that’s often useful. RMX16 Non-Lins can be good too, although it’s easy to bring things into 80s territory this way.

Send to a short room verb like ocean way, SP2016, Pro-R, Valhalla Room, Raum. Sometimes from close mics, sometimes from overheads, sometimes just slapping it straight on room mics. A little distortion (Decapitator, Devil Loc) after is often helpful.

With all of these solutions, the thing that seems to help them gel with the rest of the real kit is drum bus processing - compression and/or saturation.

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content: Another one to check out is Eric Valentine’s drum mixing video. See what he does with Greg Well’s fok mic - SansAmp like crazy, delayed and gated from kick or snare mic to add length to that drum after it hits.

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: What you described above is definitely important re: "breathing of track"...but I also may use a longer lookahead or something if it's a soft track to make things smoother and closer, more intimate, whatever. So there is not really one way (from my side), which is of course why it changes every time. Reps reps reps

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: Last thing I'll say but if you're looking to learn limiting well I'd suggest picking one or two -- Pro L2 and Ozone can't go wrong -- use those on everything, really understand what the parameters do. Then those will broadly apply to others, the fundamentals

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
Not going to put myself in the “massively talented” category (I’ll let cian do that for me) but I do have a decent clutch of nice gear, and I’ve made records that sound like me at my place as well as completely remote spots with borrowed gear and shitty conversion. I think the main thing is speed. I’m going to keep turning the knobs untill it sounds like I want it to, and with today’s tech you can pretty much do it with anything. It’s just that with the gear I’ve chosen for myself, I get the results I want quicker. It’s not that I CANT fight the gear, it’s just that I’d rather not if I can help it. 

As someone who just switched back to a trackball after trying to work on a trackpad for two years because of the tenths of a second of latency, there’s a real creative upside to immediacy. 

Then again, there’s something really inspiring about learning new gear that might break you out of stagnant patterns of doing things.

question: I have a question, Team: I have been watching drum micing videos of this gentleman (Darrell Thorpe) when I'm alone and weeping in the middle of the night, and he has said repeatedly that he has no consideration for keeping the snare in the middle of/ equidistant from the overheads. I have found, however, that if I don't have the snare exactly the same distance from the overheads, that I can distinctly hear the snare pulling to one side or the other - no matter how much I high pass - and this bothers me. Is this gentleman doing some type of post processing trickery to minimize the snare in the overheads, or is he simply working on a genre of music where this "pulled" snare sound doesn't really matter, or...? Throw in that mono in the middle and my infantile mixing mind is fd... Thanks.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
I doubt it. He probably just simply doesn’t care that it’s pulling a little bit. 

Those overheads are unlikely the biggest part of the sound, and certainly more focused for cymbals than for the shells. The snare mic itself is going to be dead center and loud enough.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I’m in the same camp as him; unless the OH’s are the snare sound, I don’t care. It matters far more for minimal mic setups

question: Is there a best practice for running audio through another mic preamp to get some coloration? Or will it not make as much of a difference Line In vs mic in? I feel like this is a simple thing to know. I’m asking because I’m curious if running audio through my UTA MPDI-4s will give me the same or some of the coloration as when I record with it. Maybe @oaklandmatt or @cian riordan have an answer for this?

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: Cian will have a more thorough answer than me, but i'd say plug-in coloration is so good these days, that unless you're using some thing like an Unfairchild, your most economical and flexible solution is probably going to be plug-ins￼

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: as I understand it, if you send the line level into the mic input, you’ll get LOTS of coloration without even turning the input up because the mic input expects a signal that’s very quiet, and the line output is going to be loud, like -10 or +4

question:
I send shit out of the box all the time, because it’s more fun for me, I’ll send drums out to guitar pedals to get fun sounds, like the EHX bass micro synth does some weird shit to drums.

The second conversion isn’t a problem IMO, to me you leave the box because you can’t get the sound or you’ll be more inspired to get a different sound because you have your hands on the knobs and can turn two at one time which you can’t really do with a mouse. 

That’s why I still send things out to my distressor or my LCA2B(tubes) , maybe try it and find a sound you like, then try and hear if you can duplicate the sound you like using one of the saturation plugins in the box, if you can, then no need to send out again, but if you can’t, then you’ll know that you’ll do that thing again. 

Maybe it’s just more fun to send out to the gear instead of staying in the box?!?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Absolutely - I use a boss RE-20 space echo for slapback more or less exclusively, my art pro MPA is an amazing distortion box. I agree completely, tactile is just fun!

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: @Zack Hames yeah that's a great point at the end there especially. Do it for the creative fun. That's why I have things like a Juno 6. Yeah I could get the sound in the box probably, but it's fun as fuck playing with knobs and making mistakes and doing extreme shit. Love the guitar pedals vibe too.

question: This is super interesting as I'm still using a set of HS80M's I've used the same for 10 years, and these days I mostly send mix work off to another engineer because I've NEVER liked my own mixes!!! Out of interest what was your next monitoring choice?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: So I’m not crazy! I went to Emotiva Stealth 8s. They don’t make them anymore, nearly no one uses them either and not easy to find now so it’s probably not a great rec, even though I love them. One is out of commission so I’m using genelec 1032a’s with sonarworks. I started working on genelecs when I got my new job, and genuinely my mixes translated 100% more on those and they’re not even the best monitors. Sonarworks takes out the chunky low mid thing and adds more high end and low end which I like. It depends on the room/setup too. I think you can’t go wrong with any upgrade from the Yamahas. I wouldn’t buy genelec 1032s, they’re just what my studio has.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: I keep seeing those being recommended, definitely if you can go listen somewhere you’ll be able to make a really good choice! Good luck!

community_answers.author: antoniohannamusic
community_answers.content: Agree with this, also, one thing for 'live sessions" is that by the time Cameras have filmed 5 x takes to get coverage it's often no longer strictly 'live' obviously there are exceptions. For location recordings though, Isolation is absolutely key, if everyone can play with IEM's or is happy to wear headphones then I would normally DI everything, Mic up a drumkit and give the singer an SM7B having them sing directly at the drummer (obviously not always possible) then everyone else, bass, keys, guitar, DI, pick an amp sim / keys plugin and get them to do multiple passes (to a click if possible). Not trying to be prescriptive just my approach FWIW.

community_answers.author: antoniohannamusic
community_answers.content: Fair call! I'm 100% on board with Sonarworks, has made a massive difference to monitoring in every environment i've been in. Might have to hit up a few of the London based companies and give a few pairs a go, I've heard good things about the Neumann monitors!

community_answers.author: AlexLayne
community_answers.content: For those using sonarworks, I updated to the new SoundID. And I'm 99% sure they updated their algo. I always felt that I lost just a tiny tiny bit to smearing on reference 4. Now I really think they made the filters faster. It responds to transients better. Its very very slight, but its there. Plus having the speaker emus and custom curves is nice

community_answers.author: AlexLayne
community_answers.content: For me I know my room and I end up mixing bass just a wee bit hot, having a low shelf of 1.5db at 60 really helps my car translation and headphones

question: So then I would go out from my hilo into that and then back into the hilo?

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Exactly—you'd go from a line output on your interface, into the XLR on the reamp box, out of the 1/4", into your pedal(s), and then from there into your DI/interface. Pedals are super fun for this stuff!

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Exactly. Say you’re using line out 1-2 for monitoring, you could use line out 3 to feed the reamp/pedal(s), and then just whatever input you want/whatever your DI is on. If you’re in Pro Tools you can setup a hardware insert, though you’d have to use the same ins and outs (i.e. output 3, input 3).

question: what do you do when a client says they’re not willing to credit you as the mixer for a record? do you charge extra or reject the job?

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: "buyouts" def exist. Ghost producers, large songwriting fees to give away publishing, etc. Not crediting you as a mixer seems like a bad precedent to set though. Hard to say. Whenever you accept something like, you're devaluing your work and credibility in the long run (with this client and also with yourself). So it's hard to know the right answer, but I rarely do this, even when I was starting out. Just a bad precedent.

question: that's fair, i do sidechain this way often for some of the hats/percs.  can always run it out of the bus - i do like the way compression sounds on all of the drums together in parallel, but maybe that should change?

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: I’ve been parallel processing the kick and snare and drums separately and leaving the bus pretty clean with good success, it’s harder to get a handle on the mix for me if I’m processing the drums as a whole, I usually leave the bus without any processing if maybe only a tiny over clipper as protection, but even then I don’t hit the bus hard, music hits harder IMO with more dynamics and running parallel allows me to get the density of the processing with the impact of the transients staying intact.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Seconded. Sometimes things can be *too* consonant. It's a strange feeling, when everything is perfectly tuned and little bit of beating frequencies are just what's needed.

community_answers.author: $$C Z00BOY
community_answers.content:
Not sure if this is helpful for you, but I’ve really learnt over the last year.. getting the kick in tune and the decay, release in time with the song with help from an adsr in a sampler (i use maschine) will really get you there 90% ! might sound boring around all gear talk but the drums will def smack hard and keep all that fat low end intact! Also with the right adsr setting you can get punch, tightness and control of a kick a compressor wouldn’t be able to get 🔥🚀 
and if you still want more energy or aggression , instead of using parallel compression, send the kick parallel to a buss with some saturation to bring out some tone followed with a limiter might be worth a try!

community_answers.author: $$C Z00BOY
community_answers.content: and to add to the groove you want from a compressor , incase your question totally flew over my head and you’re already doing the things i said.... I’d give the TrackComp from DMG Audio a go. It got ssl, 2500, zenner, and all this classical compressor plus their own Mega Clean Models, up to x16 over sampling and dry wet, endless attack and release options and a super easy to use SC circuit and a wet/dry knob to save you a parallel send! It’s personally the only compressor I use and been for over a year now! 🙌

community_answers.author: longstoryshort
community_answers.content: Ah track comp could be interesting.  I've been meaning to try that thing. Kick tuning and all that is absolutely important...in phase especially with the bassline. Thanks!

community_answers.author: longstoryshort
community_answers.content: Some notes on kick "tuning" - I actually dislike when a kick lands on a fundamental in dance music.  I've been moving toward having the kick constantly pitching down, and never actually sitting on a note.  This gives it a LOT of power, and as long as you're able to make it stay in phase with your bassline most of the time (if you're playing multiple notes this is obviously impossible for all the time) the tuning becomes "implied" based on the rest of the tone. I hope that makes sense.

community_answers.author: longstoryshort
community_answers.content: I also do like a very short kick, so it doesn't always get to the fundamental anyways, this allows my bass to be the bass, and not a kick.  A lot easier for sidechain/mix/etc.

community_answers.author: longstoryshort
community_answers.content: it is also nice to tune snares a semitone off - if you really want it to rip at least.  i'm a big fan of this.  i also don't think the fundamental we think is really the fundamental.  it's possible the snare fundamental is like, 3hz and everything else is just an overtone, which would make sense why it usually feels somewhat acceptable compared to a note, even when it's "out of tune"

community_answers.author: $$C Z00BOY
community_answers.content: sounds cool, will try this!

community_answers.author: longstoryshort
community_answers.content: i guess to clarify more, a real snare drum (not synthetic) would be impossible to have a plain fundamental at like 200hz.  two skins, that maybe could resemble one single string of an instrument - it's technically impossible for both skins to be tuned the same.  if they're a few HZ apart, the fundamental would technically be in the single digits.  so the rest would be overtones.

community_answers.author: Zakhiggins
community_answers.content: compression would definitely bring up the noise floor

community_answers.author: Rob Domos
community_answers.content:
If it’s the hissing kind of noise that you get more of when you switch from condensers to dynamics and ribbons, then it’s not the kind of noise that is coming from the room. 

In rooms the main things you would be concerned about would be reflection (which you fix with treatment) and mechanical noise from things like computer fans, clocks, etc. and condenser mics would pick those kinds of sounds up more, not less. 

Any unison pre in the Apollo should be plenty low noise to not bother you on your condenser mics. I agree with others that not using any unison pre will make the noise floor lower, but I disagree with them in that I think using the unison pres is a pretty good idea often. 

That said, if you’re struggling with noise, definitely try not compressing on the way in because compressors are only going to raise the noise floor. 

On dynamic mics and ribbon mics, you can decrease your noise floor pretty considerably by picking up a cloudlifter and throwing that in the chain. 

If you do all of the above and still have a high noise floor then either the Apollo is broken (which is pretty unlikely), or your microphone is picking up mechanical noise from your air conditioning, computer fan, refrigerator, etc. if those are the issue, then tackle the issue there. Turn off the A/C, turn off the fridge, turn off the LED lights, etc and see what you hear.

community_answers.author: Josh
community_answers.content: Yo so my twin actually broke and I had a crazy ass noise floor. Got my arrow and it disappeared. I haven’t met a single person with a broke Apollo.

community_answers.author: jantrit
community_answers.content: Depending on what you’re looking for there are so many choices. My usual go to has been 414ebs one on the high strings and one towards where the lower and middle strings meet, both kinda following the angle of the piano body. This never fails to get a great sound. If you can take the lid off try an aea r88 diagonally across the body one side pointing to the high strings one side pointing towards the low and mids, this has been one of the most natural sounds I’ve EVER gotten from a piano. It just feels so real and right. You can also try some other great stereo mics like the sm69 on cardioid for both caps. Used to stick that in a similar position as the 88 with the lid on the big stick and then blanket the whole thing to fuck. You could get amazing separation even with drums in the room and it still sounded natural. There’s also the humble 57!!! Don’t sleep on those if you’re after a very direct and contained sound you can get a couple of those on it and get exactly what you’re after.

question:
I had a visceral, emotional reaction listening to these tracks. As a die hard EV/barefoot fan, getting to dig into these tracks is probably one of the coolest things I’ve ever gotten to do.

@cian riordan , I’ve got some questions if you’re willing to answer or remember:

Are these all UTA pres?

Do you remember what drums you were using?

How are the room mics (U67s) placed? This, alongside the chamber mics, seriously gave me goosebumps to listen to. 

How are the overheads placed? They seem super wide and right over the cymbals but when you add the snare mic it all sounds perfect. 
Is all the saturation on each channel a product of driving the UTA preamps? I’m amazed at how distorted they are when solo-ed and how much it allows them to punch through.


Sorry for my gushing, but this is just the coolest thing ever to me.  Thanks for sharing this.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Oh man I'm so glad. Give me a sec to have a think and I'll get back to ya with these answers.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
1) Yes! All MPDI-4 mic pres. Signal chain would have been Mic -> Pre -> UTA Console Line In -> Pro Tools.

2) I’m pretty sure this would’ve been a Frankenstein. Most likely Eric’s Sonor birch kick drum with a Remo Black Dot on it. Almost certainly Vistalite toms… and this sounds like a Bell Brass snare.

3) Room mics are placed probably 20 feet away, spaced wide, pointed at the kit. Eric would always point the room mics away from the drums with the cardioid null towards the drum kit, but I found I got more direct, punchy sounds with it facing the drums. Chamber mics would’ve been a foot apart, pointed 45 degs out… sort of intentionally phasey to make them wider.

4) Yeah, you’re onto it. The overheads are intentionally wide and close to the cymbals. The mono mic and close mics are doing the heavy lifting with the drums and the L/R OHs are almost just cymbal spot mics with some kit stereo information peppered in.

5) Saturation is a combination of driving the UTA pres, clipping the line input of the console, and trimming things back with the faders. Might’ve been an LA-2a on the snare with no compression, just crapping out the tubes.

Sorry wish I woulda taken pictures of this session. Dave Elitch was the drummer and he’s a fucking monster.

question: Otherwise wouldn't multiband compression be the same as dynamic eq?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Compression is knocking level down at a certain threshold. Dynamic EQ can be used to compress or expand very specific EQ ranges at a certain threshold. It's like super focused multiband compression with the ability to expand or compress.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
i actually don't know what this means. maybe someone on here can come explain. "gain movement" is "more transparent than compression" doesn't make sense to me. seems like the same thing.

other than that dynamic eq and multiband compression are essentially the same. there are multiband compressors that will split the signal into multiple bands by default, so you're gonna get some phase shift between the bands, even if you're not compressing. but some plugins you can disengage the bands so depending on the plug-in architecture, you'd presumably not be getting the phase shift if you're turning off the band splitting

community_answers.author: Maxim
community_answers.content:
"Unlike compression, dynamic EQ affects the sound by dynamically changing the gain of an EQ band. Like compression, however, and using the threshold, it does this proportionally in response to the amplitude of the input signal."

From Izotope website

community_answers.author: Maxim
community_answers.content: I view compression as "squeezing" sound together if that makes sense. So I didn't understand the use of Dynamic EQ if it's just compression that you can set like an eq. But if it's just a workflow thing that's cool I guess.

community_answers.author: Maxim
community_answers.content:
Yeah to me visually it makes a lot of sense that there is a difference between the two in terms of processing. But the different use cases seem pretty obvious too:

"If you want to attenuate a specific “problem” frequency or small range of frequencies, a dynamic EQ would be your best bet. The option to have narrower bands allows for this kind of focused attenuation.

Conversely, if you’re trying to control larger areas of the frequency spectrum, a multiband compressor works well. Also the non-linear way a compressor attenuates signal can add character to a signal. If you don’t need the surgical control, but want some subtle sonic coloration, a multiband compressor can be a better choice than a dynamic EQ."

question: Hello guys,quick question about trying to get used to the sound of compression.I was wondering what would be most effective for hearing the “concept”,for lack of better terms, of reducing the dynamic range  between trying to get used to one single plugin or shooting it out with multiple plugins ?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I think starting out with a modern compressor with all the parameters available to you will be more helpful in learning the concept. That way you can really understand the idea of a threshold, different attack/release combinations, and and compression ratios. Once you can start to understand what you're hearing, then you can apply that to other compressors that might have more fixed variables (LA2a, etc). I've always found overdoing it when you're first getting the settings will help you understand whats going on.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
One thing I'd add is the importance of matching your output levels so that the dry sound and the compressed sound are the same volume when you bypass the compression. Many compressors have have automatic volume compensation included and others will require you to adjust the makeup gain that comes after the compression.

The reason it's important is because when we're comparing the dry signal to the compressed signal, the louder of the two signals will always feel better to us. It's important to match the volume levels when comparing so that we're not fooling ourself into thinking a louder signal is better and we can hear the compression (or most effects) for what really is.

community_answers.author: itaylerner
community_answers.content:
Fabfilter has some phenomenal educational videos, including a three part guide to compression- highly recommend! Has great examples and solid explanations, huge help if you really take the time to watch, pause, rewind, internalize the information.

https://www.fabfilter.com/video

community_answers.author: sloth
community_answers.content: Thank you so much for the response

community_answers.author: sethearnest
community_answers.content: You can also try to listen very quietly. What compression is doing to any given sound feels more noticeable to a lot of people when listening quietly.

community_answers.author: Zakhiggins
community_answers.content: Also If you set the ratio to max and bring the threshold all the way down, it'll then become really obvious what attack and release are doing to the sound, so set them the way you like, then bring the ratio back, as you do that it'll be apparent what that's doing too - then set the threshold to taste and it'll be very obvious what your compressor is doing

community_answers.author: Zakhiggins
community_answers.content: I can say that for most plugins, if u really wanna hear what they're doing, just crank it

question: Does summing two stems of 4 tracks each(2 audio tracks) = summing all 8  audio tracks individually? We’re talking purely digital. Can’t seem to find an answer and haven’t gotten around to doing a null test

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content:
Noice 🤘
So if i understand this Right.  mixing a beat in one project leaving a bunch of headroom and then running a separate vocal session over that 2 track and doing all your vocal processing and mixbus processing in that project, would be the same as pulling the vocal into the instrumental session and mixing the whole song with every track separated out. (This is in a perfect world where the beat is mixed perfectly and has the right amount of space for the vocal). I see this is how a lot of people are running sessions and how they are mixing demos, to either release or send out to mix & master. I’m wondering if it’s disadvantageous sonically to the mix rather ran keeping everything in one session besides control ofc.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Everything should be identical if the gain-staging is all setup properly. Obviously, it's nice to have access to individual items (cutting EQ on an instrument b/c its clashing w/ vocals, etc) but there's beneficial aspects to this workflow as well (limiting your options, DSP use-age, etc).

question: Anyone know what can be shut off using a smart plug in the studio safely? Wasnt sure if it was a bad idea to have my monitors shut off by a smart plug or if its better to switch them off from the back (or maybe it doesnt matter idk!). Just wanna hear if anyone has any smart plug experience in their studio!

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: A switch is a switch whether it's physically or electronically controlled. In most cases, your gear isn't going to know the difference.

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: I have my lights on a smart plug, and the studio wired to a Furman power sequencer which powers everything up in a delay and ordered, then powers down backwards. The only thing that I have to manually power up is the Apogee ensemble which isn’t a hard wired switch

community_answers.content: i just have all my monitors hooked up to a power strip and just use that shut it off rather than using the on and off buttons on the back

community_answers.author: chadwahlbrink
community_answers.content:
I use a smart plug to turn on and off my noisy raid archive drives each night via a Furman power conditioner. They mount when the plug turns on, then Keyboard maestro ejects them a few hours later, and they turn off with HomeKit automation. I was tired of coming down to work and having the drives humming super loud when I walk in. 

I want to get another plug for my other Furman that powers my Apollo and monitors. I do turn off the Furman switch instead of individual components. 

All that to say, you should be good to use a smart switch for something like this. I have the WeMo plug currently. The only caution is that it’s often “good practice” to turn off your monitors before anything else, although modern gear seems a bit better about not popping your monitors!

question: How are you guys saving different versions of your Pro Tools sessions? Every time you bounce and send it or while you’re working on the track? And is the “Save Copy In” feature the only option here?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Think of a pro tools session file as “directions” for all the parameters and files. So you can save a million project files without consequence or space issues, they just tell the files and plugins were to be / set at.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
I like a save as anytime I’m about to do something complicated and hard to Command Z out of. Just a “.1” or “.2” after the song name. 
But then also when I’m about to do a whole new section of tracking- like “Nu Vox” etc

community_answers.author: samvalentine
community_answers.content:
For mixes I'll save a different version every bounce. Tracking I'll save based on significant arrangement decisions, different days recording, different artists or instruments - really depends.
But noooo I'll really only use save copy in if I'm sending a session off to someone. Check out save as - it just creates a new ptx file in the same session folder. Doesn't duplicate all of your audio files etc. Shortcut is command control s on mac

community_answers.author: sethearnest
community_answers.content:
I do a Save-As at any point in a production or mixing phase that I think “this feels really great to me right now in this moment” and/or if I do some sort of major change to arrangement, massive tonal change, etc. I’ll also print that version to use as my new “ref” as a mix comes together. Sometimes you make one decision then head down a cascade of changes from that one decision. Sometimes it’s great; other times you go back to the previous “this feels great to me in this moment” version and realize your cascade is a disaster. 

Like @samvalentine , Save Copy In is only for sending sessions for me.

community_answers.author: Tyler Graham
community_answers.content:
File_name [day working on mix].[iteration that day].[bounce] - [note]. So it’d look like 

Song 1.4.0 - vocals

(first day on mix, 4th iteration that day, no bounce). I save incrementally because those .ptx files take up next to no space, why not

community_answers.author: chris_donlin
community_answers.content:
I do a save as every time I make significant changes in a production session: SongTitle_InProg_#

Once the production is ready for mix, I save the final production as SongTitle_FinalProd. Commit tracks clean up fades, etc. - this is kind of the mix prep stage. When it’s ready for mixing, I do a save copy in so everything on the top of the session is all that’s there for the mics. No hidden or inactive tracks, etc.

community_answers.author: samvalentine
community_answers.content: This mix prep stage is huge. I also like to delete unused audio files from the new "saved copy in" session. (Command + shift + U then command + shift + B in the clip pool.) greatly reduces the size of the session you're sending!

question:
No idea where I'm supposed to ask this so I'll throw it here;

Is it possible that setting my buffer size to 2048 would result in more glitches than when I set it to 1024? I seem to get less glitches the higher I increase the buffer, as expected, all the way up to 1024. But going to 2048 seems to give me a bit more problems. I'm not sure if it's actually actually happening, and I'm not sure how to properly test this, but this is what I'm feeling and hearing

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: typically, the lower you go, the more glitches you'll get. it doesn't make sense that going higher would result in anything more than more latency, but lots of things are possible when so many variables (plugins, CPU, OS, other shit running, etc) are potentially in play.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: I definitely experienced this on my M1 Macbook - some explanation I saw seemed to make sense to me where the power saving/efficiency settings adjust the clock speed of the cpu cores to meet the demand/load.  I think similar features are implemented in Intel systems depending on how you have your power settings set in the BIOS and OS (at least in Windows).  So counterintuitively if you aren't pushing your cores to the limit they won't be operating as effectively.  When I'm working on the Mac I keep the buffer as low as possible and then tick it up during the mix process, and on Windows my machine is usually really stable at 1024 from start to finish in a mix so I just leave it there, but I've also disabled any sort of power saving stuff on my PC in the BIOS so the clock speeds should be relatively stable.  Again, I'm not sure if this is actually the cause or not but just what I've seen posted about online anecdotally!

community_answers.author: rse
community_answers.content: I must say I thought I was completely crazy for thinking this (and I still think I am tbh) but I recently talked to someone with the exact same experience as me in another discord. So far my Google searches have not resulted in anything. It's not bothering me, but I was curious if there was any way to test this or if anyone had more information on this

community_answers.author: rse
community_answers.content: That does seem to make sense, I'll be looking at whatever power saving i got going on. I do have all power saving and stuff turned off for FL studio specifically I think, but I'll look into my bios settings forsure

community_answers.author: jonmatteson
community_answers.content: i’ve also notice on my m1 that sessions seem to be happiest/run most efficiently at 128 or 256

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
Perhaps I can address your issue at the source with how you have your Ableton compressor set up:

You're saying that you cannot get your 808 to duck low enough each time the kick hits. The first thing that stands out to me is that you're using a soft ratio. You need to crank that ratio up to at *least* a 4:1 ratio, but you might be even better off with an 8:1 or higher ratio. You need a high ratio to get the deeper ducking effect that it seems you're seeking.

Using a soft ratio will never get you a big duck unless you have the threshold pulled all of the way down. And even then it's probably going to have issues recovering correctly after each duck.

community_answers.author: benigma

question:
Is there a proven way to train your ears to hear for clashing frequencies in a mix?
Like,Right Now,i eq to give precidence to a certain instrument over the other but still i would not able to tell that what region of frequency is clashing without looking at the frequency spectrum.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Practice practice practice. It gets easier with time and experience. 

Also reliable monitoring makes it easier! Good question though

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
Use EQs with knobs and no frequency analyzer. Your brain will always defer to what you see over what you hear, and if you’re drawing lines and looking at analyzers you’re essentially “seeing” the sound as much as hearing it. Which ultimately is really useful for getting good results and solving problems quickly. But, if you want to focus on what you’re hearing, you have to minimize the visual activity. 
Using a 1073 style eq, your brain will start to connect sounds with numbers, and so you’ll hear something and start thinking “snare needs more 200 and less 600” or whatever, and then you’ll start to associate numbers with abstract concepts like “brightness” or “punch.” 

And it will be your ears not your eyes doing the work 🙌🏻

@Zack Hames is right- the more you do it the better you get at it, and there’s no substitute for time.

community_answers.author: Gazing Wrmth | Mixes & Masters
community_answers.content:
Aight @Zack Hames 🙌
Will do this @NoahNeedleman ⚡
Thanks for the Suggestions!🍻

question: hey y’all i could use some advice on how to deal with revisions. i don’t like charging or setting limits but some artists i’ve been working with have been asking for mix changes / arrangement changes months after it got approved and sent to mastering. i had one song where all the drum samples were replaced with live drums, the bass and guitar was recut and a bunch of backgrounds got sent in over the course of 6 months. where do you draw the line on changes like that? i feel like i’m living inside of the ship of theseus thought experiment 😭

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
Honestly might have to set boundaries on future projects. Maybe something simple like “I do as many revisions as needed to a point. If it becomes a completely different song or you want changes 6 months later I will charge you an additional fee”

Almost all business caveats and additional costs come from things having happened that the “business” is obviously trying to prevent.

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Or simply say I don’t have time to make these revisions without further compensation. It’s been 6 months, I didn’t plan for this.

question: If it’s someone worth getting return work from, just eat it. How long could it really take?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: You're very much being taken advantage of here. I would recommend politely writing them an email saying that you've done the work that you were hired to do (especially if things have been delivered for mastering) and given the amount of additional work they're requesting, you need to negotiate a new fee for said work.

expert_answers.author: peterlabberton
expert_answers.content: Yeah, among other things, the mix having been already approved at one point and sent to mastering is a good place to draw the line. I’d say anything that substantively changes the song or requires a real re-mix on your part is grounds for renegotiating, and having that laid out at the outset is always preferable.

community_answers.author: joshua_wav
community_answers.content: thanks for the quick response y’all!!! needed to make sure i wasn’t going insane.

community_answers.author: itaylerner
community_answers.content: I always say unlimited revisions until any new stems / files are sent, then it’s an additional fee. I can always tell them not to worry about it if it’s something small and simple, but i at least have it there as a safety net

community_answers.author: hank01564
community_answers.content: I personally don’t feel like unlimited revisions are fair to the engineer unless you’re charging top dollar. Most of us aren’t, most mixes should be able to be completed within three recalls, and anything beyond should have additional compensation. Otherwise, your time is no longer being paid for and you’re in a perennial chokehold of “turn this up, turn this back down”

question: Hey guys, really really newbie question but i am struggling so much that i need to ask. What is gain staging and how can i do it properly ? I know the basics like noise floor, clipping over 0 but there are so many different information out there I just can't tell which is right. Some say you need -6 db of headroom blablabla but i watch Jon Castelli or any other mix engineers mixing they are mixing to 0 and loud af. It feels like im doing something wrong and but i don't know what im doing wrong if that makes any sense. Would love to hear how you guys approach it and would love to learn from you. Thanks.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
This is a very broad question with many different answers, but I think the easiest way to sum up the concept of ‘gain staging’ is simply figuring out what level every ‘device’ is expecting and/or which level is ideal to get the results you want. These ‘devices’ can be a plugin, a piece of hardware, an A/D/A converter, an auxiliary bus, a mix bus, etc.

In analog world… there might be fathomable difference when a compressor or amplifier receives -10dBVU vs +10 dBVU. Accounting for these differences would be considered gain staging — and you’d be looking for what gets the ideal sound out of your box.

In digital world… some plugins may react similarly and others may not care if you’re sending -6dBFS or -0.01dBFS. It’s usually case by case as there are myriad plugins. You also need to consider what level the plugin is sending signal out — as this will affect how the next plugin processes the audio, or how much headroom it has to work with. Let’s say I’m sending signal out of a compressor plugin into an EQ plugin — and lets say I’m using the compressor to beef up mean volume of the signal and then I want to EQ some more low end into the signal after the fact. Well, I’m going to be adding gain in the compressor and then the level going into the EQ will be hotter than originally intended. Id want to trim down the output of the compressor (or the input of the EQ) so you have headroom to be able to boost those frequencies without clipping the output of the EQ. In a 32-bit floating mixer like Pro Tools, these issues become less audible as the mixer has higher headroom than its indicating, but you never actually know — and it’s best to just stick to the parameters that you have control over. If you were to do this same function with an analog compressor and EQ, there would be very noticeable distortion if you didn’t stage the gain properly.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content:
Sometimes gain staging is just managing the signals going to an auxiliary bus or a master fader. If you’ve got everything summing into - say - an aux bus in pro tools, and that aux bus is clipping, then that will be audible distortion going into the next gain stage. It may sound good, it probably doesn’t — so its something to account for earlier down the chain. If you’re going into a master fader in pro tools, and your signal is over 0dBFS, you can simply turn down the master fader, and it is actually turning down all the signals going to it, not just the output. This is useful because you can then throttle the input to your first plugin in the chain — say a limiter or maximizer. It’d be a shame to have a fancy clipper on your master bus, only to be clipping the signal in the chain before even getting to it.

It’s a bit of a scattershot answer to a scattershot question, but the reality is that everything affects everything in audio. And having your head wrapped around signals levels going in and out of things will help you make faster decisions and help you troubleshoot quickly when things aren’t sounding quite right.

community_answers.author: emre
community_answers.content: And i keep hearing the ''Oh i can push me mixes really loud cuz my gain staging is so good''

question:
I wrote in my notes from the Bainz episode that the way each guest/mixer talks about gainstaging the various tracks of a mix, it definitely is the mixer’s version of a “business mission statement,” which @Slow Hand alludes to with the idea of talking about how one choice ripples to inform all of our other decisions. Gainstaging sets the record up to show off its best qualities—and are those qualities in the low end of a booming bass synth and the natural silky quality of the vocalist, or maybe you want the mid range to feel really detailed yet cohesive and warm. 

Understanding this, for me, made the finishing process that Jon talks about make sense. Level setting inherently overlaps with the kind of decision making process of EQing, which is something you can probably understand best from this clip of Bainz talking about how he can get a vocal to be so upfront in his mixes because he’s surgical in what he keeps in there. The way I understood it, he’s cleaned up the vocal a ton, set the levels of his tracks by what feels important to bring to the forefront for the listener, and then he uses those levels to inform his EQ moves throughout.

https://www.instagram.com/tv/CkSeHgrosyx/?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y=

expert_answers.author: ehutton21
expert_answers.content:
What Jon talks about doing with headroom, for me, didn’t make sense until I heard what Bainz said in different incarnations on different occasions. 

By turning everything down 6 DBs midway through or near the end of the mix process, and then slowly pushing levels up to set your “balance” and then taking an EQ and using it very deliberately, you get a real gut check on “have I been deliberate with what I’m emphasizing for the listener.”

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
Pretty much all the info above is great for general understanding. (And I do mean *great*)

To answer your other question, my personal approach usually leads me to making up 2-3db on 2buss processing. So before I instantiate and add any gain from inflators or limiters at the end of my master fader chain, I have 2-3db of headroom. 
Starting with kik snare bass around -6db, adding in vocals and everything else all balanced properly usually gets me to around -2. Which is more than enough for a mastering engineer but not enough to get myself into trouble tryna get to make it loud with my Ozone or whatever. 

That’s just my process currently. No doubt there’s different ways to get there, some likely much better, but this has been working well for my purposes.

question:
Following last night's #👩🍳mixing-talk chat re good online sources of nuts & bolts audio info, I made the following list for my bud.

I want to make it robust so it can be a resource to provide whenever these question comes up, so come on gang, poke holes in it.

I've included an orchestral/scoring section, and having done a little work in that world I personally found these resources helpful, but maybe @LAPhill could chime in? Props to @Adam Thein for the general section.

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content:
**General**

Interview style material can be great, and sources like Mix With The Masters where you can watch legitimate professionals working while they explain why they do what they do. Of course, you first need to understand the tools in order to understand why people use them in certain ways in specific situations, so building your knowledge of the fundamentals is important.

In general beware of anything with hyped titles like “30 MIXING HACKS I WISH I KNEW”. The internet is awash with misinformation, so it’s important to assess who the information is coming from, and what their agenda may be (whether that’s building subscribers, or shilling a product etc). If in doubt, research the records these people have worked on, and listen to them to see if you actually like how they sound!


**Engineering/Mixing/Production**

Steve Albini / Electrical Audio: https://www.youtube.com/@ElectricalAudioOfficial

Making records with Eric Valentine: https://www.youtube.com/@mrwev

Just For The Record - Mixing/interview streams - https://www.youtube.com/@JFTRLive

Sol State - Clips from longer form streams by (mostly electronic and pop) producers - https://www.youtube.com/@SolStateMusic

Live With Matt Rad (focused around Instagram Live interviews, with a generous community on Discord - generally skewing towards pop)
Insta: https://www.instagram.com/livewithmattrad/
Discord: https://discord.com/invite/fcfEtxRbWT
Podcast on Spotify, Apple Music etc.
YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/@LivewithMattRad
YouTube Clips Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCs8ZKTveuxghTN-QaHFemsw

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content:
**Orchestral/Scoring**

Spitfire Audio - obviously focusing on their own products, but they are excellent and the tutorials are made by real life working composers, with interviews, studio tours and workflow suggestions - https://www.youtube.com/@spitfireaudiollp

Spitfire’s Christian Henson - as above, but from his own account - https://www.youtube.com/@ChristianHensonMusic

JunkieXL (Mad Max Fury Road, Hans Zimmer protegé) walks through projects, gear setup, music theory, professional practice stuff - https://www.youtube.com/@junkiexlofficial

question: @Nomograph Mastering if it's not too much trouble, do you think you could ELI5 (or point me in the direction of a resource which explains) the unfuckology behind speakers right up against the wall? I keep seeing it referenced in this Discord/on the podcast and it seems really counter to everything I've been told before

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: Not to overstep, but I’m convinced it has to do with trying to keep the sound waves bouncing off the wall behind your speakers as in phase as possible. The further from the wall the bigger the delay before it combines with the forward moving sound waves.

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content: Ideally you want the speaker mounted in the wall.

community_answers.author: JakeTB
community_answers.content:
The boundary effect is a welcome help in 2023 musicmaking since it helps with your headroom and low end. 

There are other technical trade offs the smarter people can outline, but the energy coming off the wall is a nice thing with the low end in today’s records.

community_answers.author: JakeTB
community_answers.content: And as @ALXCPH said above, soffit mounted is best in the perfect world. But for the rest of us, against the wall seems to get better consistent results

community_answers.author: JakeTB
community_answers.content: Also if you check out the unf*ck conversation at the gift shop on YouTube, Ruairi goes in on it there

question:
tfw @oaklandmatt says one thing, @BatMeckley says another

Given that this can be true I guess the technical considerations should outweigh  'do what sounds better', I didn't think of that.

Have you really had things misalign like that so many times?

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
Man. 85 percent of the tracks I’d get would require an hour of trying to line up the song PROPERLY to the grid. It’s not as easy as lining a kick to the grid as half you guys are using kick samples that have space before the transient.  When I’m out here nudging and stretching vocals at 1/1000th of second resolutions, which can dramatically change the pocket and vibe, it’s a kick in the teeth then if the whole track ends up being a tenth of a second off. 

The trick I came up with was putting four low frequency Square wave bursts maybe an 1/8th note long each at the beginning or end of each song. That means at no matter the master bus processing (or worse the mp3 meta data at the beginning pushing the song back) you can recalibrate EXACTLY the track back on to the grid. In that case, once you’ve figured that bit out, slap whatever you want on the bus. The square wave trick is how we were able to prove how logic or ableton was bouncing out of time even when a ton of people didn’t hear it or notice.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: Conceptually, I like the track to sound 🔥 when the artist tracks, because again it VERY MUCH informs their performance. On a track I worked on this week, building up the beat even just a little completely changed how the artist sang to the track

community_answers.author: austenballard
community_answers.content: The only comparable situations I have personally had were when something in the other person's vocal chain wasn't PDC'd properly, or they tracked at a different sample rate, and the file that came back was misaligned. But that's just my own limited experience.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
I love my dear friend @BatMeckley but I think he's wrong here. Just send the instrumental how it sounds the best, and have them send you a bounced ref along with the vocal. I ask them to send me the session too as I have Pro Tools, Logic, and Ableton and can play with their processing and do a new bounce if need be.

If a vocal bounce comes back with some delay uncompensated or otherwise off the grid, lining up the vocal will NOT take you an hour. You simply line up the ref to your session and the vocal to the ref (the latter is 99% of time already done since they're bouncing from the same session). This takes a few minutes max and I've done it dozens of times. Nudge and flip some phase and you're within a couple samples. You're fine.

question: In photography we use drum scanners that can scan even the oldest film and print them at incredible resolution (there's that word again) but those scanners are useless on say, a shot on a digital camera from 1999 at 12MP. Would it not be the same idea to want to preserve the resolution of tape instead of baking in a session at whatever sample rate it was ran at ?

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
Huh yeah I understand - but for what I’m using it for I don’t need anything above nyquist personally, I’m just using it as an effect not for tracking

To be clear my use case is in mixing/post production - running tracks captured at 44.1 or 48k most often, using tape for compression/color/distortion and then bringing back in digitally at the same sample rate as the session.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Most of the “tape” sound is the actual tape itself. The level hitting it, the bias, and how the eqs are set make huge differences in how it performs and sounds.

question: Got a patch bay question that I've tried googling with little results -- is there a standard format for batch bay organization (as well as labeling)? I usually wing it and fine tune based on what works best for my workflow and style

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: There's some standards that are useful -- outs over ins, normalling strategy... that type of stuff. Really comes down to what you're trying to achieve. If you're operating a big tracking studio, then you want that workflow in mind: tie lines normalled to mic pres, mic outs normalled to A/D inputs, D/A outs normalled to monitor controller & headphone boxes, etc. If you're in a mixing room (like me), I have things setup so outboard gear is accessible via hardware inserts through patchbay normalization. As for labelling, I've been using my own spreadsheet system that I find more useful than patchbay labelling software. Here's an example of my setup from last year:

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: sick this is good info! i just transitioned from hybrid mixing to more recording focused and the patch bay completely changed -- so now lines from the snake box go directly through pre's to converters via normalling, and putting stuff in for mix will involve more patching now. before it was the opposite -- could throw anything into a mix without the need for a patch cable.

question:
**Shift + ?**: Open *Info View*.

This will open a help window in the lower-left corner and reveal descriptions of everything that they move their mouse cursor over. Including any relevant key commands.

I would put that at the top of their list, because it will enable them to educate themselves as they go.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
@river I would also mention that they can find the key command for most tasks within the dropdown menus (red arrow)

@Maxim If you ever forget the key command to hide *Info View* you can just click the little triangle/arrow in the lower-left corner (yellow arrow)

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
My most-used commands are:

Cmd + Opt + B: Open/close browser.
Cmd + Opt + L: Open/close bottom track window.
Shift + Tab: Toggle between *Instrument View* and *Clip View* in the bottom track window.

I'm a habitual window toggler. If I'm not using the window it gets hidden immediately. I probably wouldn't mention it to a newbie, but it's probably a nice reminder for more seasoned users.

community_answers.content: Dude thank you been trying to figure out how to get rid of that info box for ages
