question:
Does anyone know a way to track whos uploading your music to youtube/streaming services? Like content ID stuff...

Say I upload some beats to youtube, someone rips em and uploads it, how to track whos doing that...

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
The landscape for pitching songs has changed dramatically in the last decade. It still exists, but it has shrunk to the point where even the top level writers can't rely on it as much.

This is simply because many more people can write songs and make demos quickly. This results in two things: the market is flooded with songs, and artists who used to rely on pitch songs are now writing (or co-writing) the majority of their material.

Many songs that used to be sent to an artist are now brought into the room and finished with the artist themselves. Like, you'd pitch a chorus or a 3/4 finished song to an artist and finish with them on the spot.

The genres where pitching songs still predominates are country the (industry is still writer–driven), EDM (many artists are performers who do not write or produce), and pop (but they're mostly just looking for HITS).

Another consequence of this shrinking pitch landscape is that the projects that need "outside" songs are much more gate-kept by people in the industry. In country, there are publishers and labels that generally source the songs. In pop, labels and executive producers (of specific projects) tend to be the gate keepers, and in EDM it is a similar combo.

So, to answer your question directly, the best way to pitch songs is to build direct relationships with artists or go through the various business people who gate-keep the process.

To advise you based on your question: make incredible records with your friends, peers, and the people around you, and get visibility that way. Hustle like crazy and use every moment of new visibility as a stepping stone to get in the mix with the larger music community. Ultimately you probably sign a publishing deal and sing with a manager where you get business representatives to help guide you and connect you further.

As with all things music, if you actually really for real make A+ records, people will find you. It's just that this is a lot harder than people think.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
This is all rings very true IME. 

My wife is a publisher at Big Machine, and I’ve been working in country for the last 8 years or so-  I can say it’s also going in the same direction as pop: while pitching still happens at a higher frequency than any other genre, more and more songs are getting finished with the artist in the room.

community_answers.author: kaevox.wav

question:
What is the difference between an EQ and a filter? When doing lowpass stuff (especially when automated) I sometimes use an eq (like fabfilter pro q3) or a filter (fabfilter volcano) and I‘m not really sure why I‘m grabbing one over the other in any given situation 
Is a filter just an eq u use slightly differently or is there more to it?

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: Organize, retitle, color code, group, quick gain staging/leveling to get all the loudest parts of the song hitting around -3db, import any templates I wanna work from. All the things I’d have my assistant do if I wasn’t my own assistant.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: It’s my understanding that there filters within certain eqs, like proQ3. Dedicated filters like volcano may handle resonant peaks in specific ways.

community_answers.author: Zach Hughes
community_answers.content: Might be helpful to think of an EQ as a tool that simply boosts or cuts gain at specific frequencies using different filter types (i.e. bell, notch, HP, LP, etc...). HPF is still an EQ move. Not wholly accurate to conflate the two though they are used synonymously at times. Context dependent. Filter could be describing the shape of the EQ move being made. But if I said hey filter out everything below 100hz vs hey EQ out everything below 100hz - I mean the same thing. Might be a little more nuance to the history of the language used I could be missing; perhaps someone else could fill in. I think volcano has some non-linear harmonic / saturation component to it but I'm not super familiar with that plug.

question: Heyo - any idea how to get the effect at 0:40 on the lyric brain?? Been trying to use a granulator with some sick automation for it but it just ain't cutting it https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zm7c2FDb7jQ

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
It sounds like a delay unit with a *freeze* function that captures the audio buffer and makes it repeat infinitely without decay or degradation. Soundtoys *Primal Tap* has this feature. You might be able to cheat it using a regular delay unit if you set the feedback amount to 100% and disable the filtering or modulation  in the feedback loop so that it doesn't degrade.

Also, that echo is drenched in a large reverb.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Yup! *Delay* has it. If you click the infinity button (circled in red) it is the same functionality. It will freeze the buffer at a length equivalent to your delay time and not decay.

question: in case this has been brought up before pls lmk but... what does it usually look like when you start to earn a meaningful back end on big songs you have producer/songwriting credits on? do you need management to get that money? what's the whole process like after the music is released? can someone ELI5?

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
I'd get in touch with a music lawyer who can help you make sure you have everything in place to collect all your back end - there's a lot of revenue sources you'll want to make sure you are collecting from.

Often you'll have had a producer agreement in place and a letter of direction that will be sent to the distributor/label so that if you have points on the master you'll be paid directly from them.

You'll also need to have a PRO/Publisher in place to collect songwriting royalties, and many folks have in place a publisher deal or publisher admin deal to collect those royalties on your behalf in exhange for a % of your royalty.  In my case I am set up with BMI in the US as my PRO and Publisher and have an admin pub deal with Sentric to collect in territories outside the US.

Also you'll want to be set up with SoundExchange to collect digital performance royalties (SiriusXM, iHeart, Pandora).  This often also involves the letter of direction that is kicked off with your producer agreement.

I'm probably forgetting something but I'd highly recommend talking with a music lawyer to get things set up and working for you.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Also I don't know much about it but I think you can use the MLC to help collect mechanical royalties in the US if you don't have a pub or admin pub deal to do so.

community_answers.author: SoundsLikeJoe
community_answers.content: I find MLC to be especially bad interface to manage/navigate. I understand it's new, and having growth pains....  but it also feels a bit like a closed black box and intentionally unhelpful UX.

question: What does it mean when people say eq can be "destructive" to kick? I keep on hearing this. Because the only thing that I've found that works for my kick is to absolutely obliterate it with pulteq at 30hz and 5k. Sometimes even layering multiple pulteqs!  - That and taking a BIG scoop out of everything in and around 780hz. I'm experimenting with gating agressively in paralell, too. But, I digress a bit...

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
One of the reasons I think this way is because anytime you EQ something, you are introducing phase shifts around either side of the frequency you're using. I find low end to be particularly sensitive to phase shifts. Phase shifts blur sound slightly, which is particularly bad for the low end instrument that you want to be punchy and full. 

While EQ may boost your overall low end, often times you are losing punch and clarity at the same time.

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: Pultec Qs, even at their narrowest settings, are pretty broad. Instead of reaching for eq first, try just turning it up.

question: Dude, this is such an insightful response - I almost got chills reading it. thank you so much for taking the time... Re eqing in solo vs in context: Typically, I listen to everything going at once, and then if I hear something that bothers me consistently, I'll solo the thing and pull out the freqs - but you know, I should probably start doing it all in context... More in context eqing I think would be good, yeah... I don't know how, but sometimes is it possible that those "nasty freqs" can kind of aid things in a way?

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: If you sweep endlessly you'll find endless "nasty frequencies" that aren't necessarily nasty in context

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: so only zap those things that bother you when everything is playing in context

community_answers.author: Josh Bowman
community_answers.content: Anythings possible! Everything in audio is context dependant. Glad it was useful info! Both solo and not solo are super useful and i do both often.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: I hear tracks sometimes and i say to myself "Oh, wow. This is definitely very heavily highpassed..." and then I hear tracks where it's like they just left in all the low end... Context dependent I suppose - And taste, too!

community_answers.author: Josh Bowman
community_answers.content: Answering your own questions there! haha. Yes. Everything is on the table. It all depends on the source, and your desired outcome.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Hell yeah. Right. Yes.

community_answers.author: Josh Bowman
community_answers.content: Would be hard to give anyone advice on EQing without hearing the thing. Otherwise its just guessing

community_answers.content: Yeah, yeah, totally.

question: Hello everyone!  I have this question: I'm a producer from Vietnam. Currently I'm using Focusrite 2i2 and a pair of Focal Evo 65 to mix and master my own songs. Even though i've learnt and practiced a lot of mixing stuff but my mixes sound still amateur. I'm thinking of upgrading to UAD Apollo for better converters as i've learnt that DA converter does affect what i can hear out of my speakers. Could you guys kindly give me more insight into this issue? Thanks!

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
Hey. Welcome! 

Based on what you've shared, it sounds like you're early in your journey making records. There are a lot of reasons that an Apollo might be a good investment, but buying them for the converters probably isn't the best use of your money at this stage.

The difference that converters will make (if any) is very very small compared to other factors. Factors like having a good room to listen in, acoustic treatment for the room, and the monitors you're listening through. I would prioritize those and consider converters to be very low priority until you get those other factors working well.

So unless there are other reasons that you'd like to have an Apollo I think you can save your money for the time being.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Your results will almost always be attributed to your skills! In this case, while I'd focus my attention on getting some reps in on various mixing projects, there's certainly room to grow in your equipment stable. Headphones are a great starting point and will likely continue to be useful down the road, but mixing on speakers helps you make things translate better to the real world (car & home stereos, public spaces, etc). So a pair of decent entry level monitors would be my next purchase. It will also prove useful for collaborating with other folks down the road as you can all hear the same thing from the same source.

question: For manual de-essing do you prefer using Melodyne over clip gain and RX? Or do you do multiple passes using different tools over the course of working on a production/mix?

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: It’s just so intuitive and so easy, and when you have all the doubles and harmonies lined up you can really match pitch and timing to comically tight tolerances. Earlier on in my career I actually fucked up a project with Larry Klein because I tuned and timed the harmonies too tight and it collapsed the stereo field. It’s very easy to get things so locked in in standalone that you can get everything to phase.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content: My buddy Andrew puts a pretty heavy low pass on the instrumental while tuning, says it really helps, especially with groove. He does great work, works for him.

community_answers.author: Josh
community_answers.content: Also I feel aside from splitting notes, the other most important part of tuning is knowing what not to tune

community_answers.author: itaylerner
community_answers.content: ohhh that's right - it's cause I'm stuck on Melodyne Editor and I need Melodyne Studio to have multiple tracks in there. Really gotta send it on that, doing harmonies / backgrounds without it is comical.

community_answers.author: itaylerner
community_answers.content: I find myself needing to adjust autotune settings on BVs for that same reason - the weird phase interaction when layered vocals are tuned too similarly is just awful

community_answers.author: Josh
community_answers.content: Ryan just hyped me up so hard.

community_answers.author: thegreatcarsoni
community_answers.content: This is why I like tuning with as many other elements on as possible for at least part of the tuning process. I saw Ian Kirkpatrick shelf down the lows and highs of the mix to help focus on the vocals while tuning, that’s been super useful for me!

community_answers.author: thegreatcarsoni
community_answers.content: Totally! Btw, had Larry Klein at my studio several years ago to do an interview for a podcast. Really cool guy, must’ve been awesome to work with him.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content:
The buffer has nothing to do with sample rate or fidelity of a given capture. Buffer only matters for the performance of your computer. For setting your buffer, you'll have to find the balance between latency and stability if you're recording. If you're mixing, raise the buffer until your system is stable. 

For sample rate and bit depth, you will be fine working at 48/24.

question: So, is it DI box into preamp into... interface??

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content:
Well, it all depends on what gear you have and/or want to use.

If you have a DI box, an outboard preamp you want to use, and an available line input on your interface yes.
If you have a DI box and an interface with built in mic preamps but no outboard preamp, do that. If you have an interface with an instrument input but no DI box and no outboard mic preamp do that.

Some outboard preamps even have a DI input on it that sounds pretty good, but without knowing your exact setup idk what to advise. Based on the above info though you should be able to make that choice.

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content: Overall it helps to understand the differences between instrument level, mic level, and line level and when each one is important.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: Swapping headphones feels like getting a new prescription on your glasses after several years.  The signatures can be so wildly different and it typically takes me 6-8 weeks of listening to them regularly to get well adjusted.  I wouldn’t recommend switching out monitoring in general mid-project - better to use what you know and get to the finish line than to suddenly add a lot of doubt to the work.

question:
Mastering only here -- but it absolutely changes every time. However, is that actually the best thing for a mixer to be adjusting all the time when mixing? I'm not so sure. Someone like @Matt Huber who is a monster and has tested things extensively, long track record, sure. Would wonder what others think about people on the earlier side of the journey though. 

Understanding limiting, what it feels like and does is basically essential in modern record making though

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content:
Of course depends on the tempo, part, sound of the drums, aesthetic of the track - but a few things that have worked in different scenarios for me:

Create the impression of some distance to walls by sending snare (start there, maybe add other mics) to a short stereo delay. Often something like 90ms on one side, 120ms on the other. Feel it out on one side, then add some time to the other.

Try adding some fake distance to your existing room mics with a simple delay with no feedback (there’s a Steve Albini drum video on YouTube where he demonstrates this). You can delay both sides equally, or solo one side, delay it til it feels good/sounds cool, then do the other. Anything from 12ms-around 23 seems to work. From there things start to become more like a slap, but than can be cool too.

Smash up your existing rooms a bit, or a lot. Omnipressor, Devil Loc, UAD Zener, decapitator, Rough Rider (free), Arousor/Distressor in nuke, Lo-Fi. 

Send to a gated verb - Cian shared a drum session a while back with a short VintageVerb preset that’s often useful. RMX16 Non-Lins can be good too, although it’s easy to bring things into 80s territory this way.

Send to a short room verb like ocean way, SP2016, Pro-R, Valhalla Room, Raum. Sometimes from close mics, sometimes from overheads, sometimes just slapping it straight on room mics. A little distortion (Decapitator, Devil Loc) after is often helpful.

With all of these solutions, the thing that seems to help them gel with the rest of the real kit is drum bus processing - compression and/or saturation.

expert_answers.author: Ross Fortune
expert_answers.content: Another one to check out is Eric Valentine’s drum mixing video. See what he does with Greg Well’s fok mic - SansAmp like crazy, delayed and gated from kick or snare mic to add length to that drum after it hits.

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: What you described above is definitely important re: "breathing of track"...but I also may use a longer lookahead or something if it's a soft track to make things smoother and closer, more intimate, whatever. So there is not really one way (from my side), which is of course why it changes every time. Reps reps reps

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: Last thing I'll say but if you're looking to learn limiting well I'd suggest picking one or two -- Pro L2 and Ozone can't go wrong -- use those on everything, really understand what the parameters do. Then those will broadly apply to others, the fundamentals

question: My father is a contractor. I was as well. Changed hundreds of outlets. If your not going to reground the whole system and don't have a long standing relationship with an electrician. They're probably  not coming for outlets. A handyman will be your best bet to offload the work practically if you don't want to do it yourself. Like I said in deleted comments, if you going to do it yourself. Get the electricty detector pen. And check each outlet before starting. Even after turning off the breaker. Just cause the first 4 are off. The fifth might be on the washer and dryer breaker line a floor above. The electricity wont kill ya, but it will zoom ya. Also if renting landlord should be consulted first to see if theyll carry the weight of the task. Considering the state of the 30 plus year old outlets, probably unlikely. question: Is this a sign that you should consider having a Manager?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I would say that if taking up managerial tasks on your own (basic communication, scheduling, basic deal negotiating, and invoicing) starts to eat into productive working time (producing, mixing, etc) — then the 20% fee will pay for itself. If you’re not there yet, just get a good lawyer for the bigger deals and save the $ until it really becomes a necessity.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Managers aren’t agents, they will rarely get you work. They are mostly there to help facilitate and curate the momentum you already have as a producer/mixer/masterer.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
Probably not responsive at all, or only noticeable on less extreme settings. 

Granular synthesis is something that tends to obscure what's played into it. It takes a small recording of what you play and then it chops it into little pieces and rearranges them or modulates the playback speed. So the nuances of what you play often get smeared and obscured. Subtlety like vibrato tends to get lost.

And if I want it to be more on the ambient side I turn more wet and more repeats

I"m new to this and not sure what the difference would be if the company "understands gear" or not - If it's covered, it's... covered, right? expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: Every item in Music Pro is covered individually, same as your homeowner's. My experience with filing a claim with Music Pro was painless. I filed it, provided the documentation and got paid. The damage happened on the road, which is covered by Music Pro. I don't know that your homeowner's will be so responsive or flexible to the real world scenarios of how instruments and gear get used in practice. If you never leave your home with your gear, maybe you'll be fine. If I have vintage instruments, amps, things no longer in production and the like, I am going with the company who understands what replacing that stuff may look like.

question: Thank you!  One real and simple example is this band repeatedly requested "guitar up" "vocals down" over and over again and the guy is pretty new to guitar so it was pretty shambolic, which I was trying to hide a little.  The balance was getting ridiculous, to my ears at least, but I just went with it.  "It's their record, not mine!"  But then there's part of me that feels responsible for them like I can't let them shoot themselves in the foot.  I thought maybe they're listening in a car and it sounds weird.  Or a phone speaker.  Just some paranoia.  I think I'm struggling a little like "when do I step in and try to say something and when do I not?"  This was their first EP of their young lives FYI.   I imagine the more pro bands are not asking you to make crazy revisions.    (and to be clear - the revision notes are mostly great and make the song better)

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
This is a constant in record making. Balancing your own thoughts with those of your client or collaborators. 

Cian is right on of course, but I’d encourage you not to think of it as binary. Almost always, there’s a version of their note that makes the song better, and it’s your job to hear it. 

In the end, it’s their record tho, and they’re the ones who will be playing it out, selling it, promoting it however they can… so they’re the ones who *need* to be happy with it in the end. 

My longtime producer & collaborator Jon Kaplan used to say “it’s your record, you can be wrong if you want to.” I give that to artists I work with now. Going in I tell them I’m going to treat you like an equal, until you tell me it’s your record and you can be wrong if you want to. 

Honestly that one idea has eased the tension on so many occasions for me.

expert_answers.author: Rollmottle
expert_answers.content: This is fantastic. Thanks for sharing.

community_answers.author: sarawls
community_answers.content: And for any of you lurkers that are trying to get people to pay you to record them, this is obvious, but I can tell you it works SO WELL.  Whatever artist you record, go to their shows.  Be cool, in both the "hip" sense of the word and the "nice and easy person to be around" sense of the word.  Even better, have your band play with them and be good.  People start lining up to have you record them.  It's crazy.

community_answers.author: sarawls
community_answers.content: Playing in bands my whole life and paying other people to record my bands, a lot of the studio people I knew were kind of hermits.  Go to as many shows as you can.  With locals playing.

I'm not Conor, but I'll jump in: That Mr. Beast document is illuminating because it drives home how single-minded, clear, and focused he is on his objective. So the remarkable part - for me - is that he's not trying to make great videos. He's trying to make great *Youtube* videos. Videos that perform exceptionally within the Youtube ecosystem. FYI, that excerpt is from an internal document for his business that was made public. It's all about orienting his staff towards how they do things, and what they are here to do. To get everyone aligned on the mission. It's a pretty remarkable act of leadership; whether you like Mr. Beast or not.

community_answers.author: Zach Hughes

I totally see that. Viewed in that light the single minded focus is somewhat admirable. A guy named Rob Horning writes some interesting pieces on social media. Not an endorsement but here's a snippet that stuck out where he was talking about Mrbeast (I'm still trying to decide what this means to me):

"The further the performer is willing to go to get attention, the more valuable the audience’s attention-giving capability becomes to themselves. (“Sycophantic” chatbots serve this purpose as well.) The more pointless the challenge undertaken is, the more unmotivated or rational the charity is, the less it interferes with the audience’s experience of the value of their ability to watch — how “important” their passive viewing can be made to feel. That feeling replaces conventional “fun” or “interest.”

question: In RX, there's no synchronized playback if I'm wanting to flip between two versions of a mix is there?

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: No. That would be *great*, though.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
Pick a tool and push it really hard. See what happens.
Use a tool somewhere it's not supposed to be used.
Ask where the trend is for an instrument and go in the opposite direction. See where that takes you.
Invert your balances.
Go minimal. Strip it away.
Go maximal. Keep adding.
Play with dramatic perspective.
Do three fast mixes and each time it has to be radically different from the previous mix.

question:
I expect this will be common knowledge to the vets but might be new to others (as it is to me ) and thought it looked a fascinating technique im going to try and wanted to share :

I just watched Steve albini describe how he would use an equalizer in a feedback loop to generate a resonant frequency, then blend that tone with the original kick drum signal to allow him to choose a complementary pitch/note with the eq and via the feedback loop also add sustain to taste . 
If others know a better routing please do correct me : i think he sent the kick to the eq as an aux (not an insert), then brings the return back in a new channel , then sends that channel back to the eq again, creating the feedback loop and blends that into the mix to support the untreated kick. 
I feel this is a little different to regular ITB parallels or VOG processing in that he’s creating a feedback loop/resonance at a chosen note …sort of like synthesising an 808 ? Kinda genius. 
(This is happening OTB with hardware )

expert_answers.author: Edward Rivera
expert_answers.content: Yeah that’s the routing. He liked the gml since you can really get fancy with it but any digital parametric will do the trick. You have to be careful with the feedback loop because too much signal will start to produce oscillation _fast_. Be delicate with it, but what’s great is that you can also control the length of the kick drum this way

expert_answers.author: spectrummasters
expert_answers.content:
I was thinking  you might be the one to confirm this Edward 

I’m gonna try it next  week on a mix I have where the kick is lacking low end but I’d like to try to not use a sample 

Thanks bro . Have a great weekend

question:
As purely an instrumentalist at the moment, I'm trying to expand the sounds I can get in my productions with singing (mainly supporting artists with BGVs/vocal pads/doubling etc.).
My voice and tone is very weak to support artists in most styles at the moment, so I'll be starting from ground 0 in my practice routine.
So far, I've been practicing going up and down scales with a met (half-time and full-time), using different syllables thru the scales, and singing long tones with different syllables.

Does anyone have sources and or advice for a beginner to strengthen their singing voice?

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
1. Sing a lot every day. If you don't, no other advice matters. Sing songs you like, sing in the shower, sing because you're now a singer. IN ADDITION TO THIS:

2. Hire a decent vocal coach and do a few vocal lessons (even a single lesson with a great teacher is important). You will get someone to teach you in-person how to breathe properly (that's the power source for the instrument you're learning). ALSO, you'll come away with a recording of a vocal warm up (somewhere between 5-20 minutes usually). YOU WILL THEN:

3. Start EVERY day with vocal warm ups.

4. Do whatever else you want to do that gets you singing a lot. Make it fun. I like learning songs, doing a voice memo every time I sing, and occasionally listening back. I sing bob dylan songs for my girlfriend. I record tons of vocals for songs I'm working on. Etc

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: Also: A great vocal warm up from a great vocal coach will do a lot of things physically for your instrument, plus you're essentially learning the fundamentals of scales and runs. This will replace the thing you're already doing, while covering a lot more ground.

community_answers.author: Beck Nebel
community_answers.content: Scales and exercises are all good and cool, but singing along to actual songs, finding where your voice feels good, and recording it is where I think you’ll actually find something. Singing into a mic and trying different tones, distances, effort levels will all help you get more comfortable with your voice.

question: Baking isn’t necessarily something you can do over and over again… eventually, the oxide will just lift off the tape for good and it’ll be stuck to your heads and tape guides. There’s surely some decent one-pass reels available in LA or Nashville markets, but if I were you, start off in a good foot and just invest in some new reels to get you going. I assume you’re doing layback and not actually tracking/storing on tape? I have t used the new RTM but ATR has been reliable in my experience.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: My mx5050 is setup for Sm911 and the RTM stuff has been great.  Nashville Recording Supply has what you need.  Also had good experiences buying new ATR tape.  Never had shedding during the time I used them.  Had terrible luck with any Ampex 456 I got second hand with shedding.

question: I have a question: I recorded drums at my place, then I sent those wavs to my mixer to edit and tracked guitars and bass over his edited drums (just a stereo mix) - Is it customary for me to ask for those edited wavs? I want to make sure that I can always get back to that stage of the project. Thanks.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
I'm going to take a stab but it's a little picky on the terminology and it's long-winded:

Usually working with a mixer is like driving down a one way street in terms of file swapping.  You typically bring in a mixer when your song and production is fully complete, you've made it the best version of itself you could reach on your own but still want to bring in someone with more experience to help you take it to that next level of polish.  So typically in this version of a client/mixer relationship you probably wouldn't ever ask for the multitrack post-edit without some sort of unique circumstance that you'd be communicating with them directly.

It sounds to me in your other conversations here that in your case, the mixer is really filling a engineering/additional production role in your project.  They are taking files of yours before they can see the entire picture of the song and helping shape the tones, doing the editing, and managing the files for you as you submit more pieces to them over time.  In this type of working relationship files are typically shared in a two way street style.  You both are collaborating and working together toward the finish line.  This role is not something I would call a mixer though - they may still do your final mixes but they are also acting as an engineer or even producer.

I know this is being a little semantic but I think it's important because the context changes how you can describe it as customary or not.

As always, you'll need to chat directly to them and explain a bit why you want to get those edited multitracks back.  My first assumption sadly if I were in your buddy's shoes is that you weren't happy with the work and wanted to send those files to someone else.  So if that's the case, let them know early, and if that's not the case, let them know why you want the files.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Second what Adam said… but also, if you’re paying him for his time, then he shouldn’t have any reason not to send them to you,

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Yep. I get it. Yeah - you're right on everything. He's not just a mixer in my case. Definitely doing some more heavy lifting/ production duties - And I did hire him as a co-producer and mixer, so yeah. I need to be more clear on the terminology. Thanks, Adam.

question: I would suggest making sure that you like their output. Listen to things they've mixed and make sure they gel with your aesthetic. There's a technical baseline that you want to ensure your mixer can meet -- it's usually pretty obvious when they're hitting below it. Like Noah said, a personal connection is great because it usually makes the communication a little easier. They'll be less precious about reaching out to you for feedback/additional files/etc and you'll be more candid in your feedback. Also, if you haven't worked with that person, very easy to find people who have and shoot them a quick note. "How was your experience? Would you hire them again?" From there you can just go down the list of pricing, availability, etc.

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
He’s too humble to say it, so I will, but when you hire a guy like Cian you’re getting talent, not genre. While there’s something to be said about a mixer who worked with a band you like, a lot of that is the e band you like.

While Cian has worked on bands and records I dig, if you pay attention to his discography it’s not just one style. The style or genre isn’t the through line, the consistent quality is. When looking for mixers, try to separate the mix from the band.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
It all starts with a well-written song. That’s the foundation of a hit record. 

The production and engineering are important and worth doing well, but if the core song isn’t as good as it can be then it’s much less likely to be a hit. It’s worth focusing a lot of your efforts on making the song as compelling as you can.

question: @kidcutler hit all the practical cons...running all the infrastructure to stand up a new structure is pricey. also, once you get the city or county involved, they'll want their cut and re-assess the property to include the new building for an updated tax basis. i would think about long term...would you purpose build a space that is specifically a studio? or would you just build a structure and make a studio inside? for re-sale, if it's a purpose-built studio, that certainly narrows the audience who would find a purpose-built studio a value-add to the purchase. if it's just a building that can be turned back into an ADU or garage easily, then that's an easier thing for most buyers to wrap their head around and probably a value-add. if you can build it as an ADU or garage, this might also change the way it's assessed. depending on the laws where you live, you might be able to get away with a building up to a certain square footage for "free." the way in which the building is classified might also make a difference. here in Glendale, CA, they've really loosened the ADU laws to encourage people to build to relieve pressure on a short-supply rental market. if you stay under a certain square footage, your tax basis does not change. i think it's a generally a great idea if you have the $$$$$$ and patience. if this is what you'll be doing for, well, your life, then it seems like a worthy investment to make.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: I was lucky that my garage was separated from my house. It was an old derelict shed at best, but it had a foundation and rough structure which saved me a boatload of money. If you have to pour a new slab -- and especially if you're going to do plumbing -- it will be expensive and you'll be doing enough work to justify getting permits involved so you can claim resale if you ever sell your house.

community_answers.author: sethearnest
community_answers.content: @kidcutler and @Rollmottle are nailing it. One other thing to consider re: the value-add vs. not to a future buyer is location/city. In Nashville, something like this is probably more valuable to more people than even LA, and certainly more so than any other city I can think of. A purpose-built studio in probably anywhere but Nashville would more likely be seen as a "we'd have to reno that building", whereas a mother-in-law suite vibe used as a studio but still a MIL suite might be more value to more people in most cities.

community_answers.author: sethearnest
community_answers.content: I'm actually going through a similar thought process right now re: how to build an external building, so fresh on my mind.

question: It's replicating the original 1073 preamp gain knob, which had a few off switches for utility purposes. The old 80 series consoles often had a universal phantom power strapped across all the channels – the off position was a quick way to kill phantom if you needed to hot patch a mic. Also just a quick way to kill signal to a channel if there was a feedback spike or something.

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content:
For me if I were you. I’d have done it like this

1.scratch out the song with programmed drums and focus on making sure the click track is right. Do as many tempo changes and push and pulls till it feels right. Map out the song to where it feels exactly how you want it. Do minimal programming to get the idea’s across you don’t have to go wild with velocities. Since your a drummer you should know what your playing and it’ll make it way easier

2. Track rthym guitars and bass and comp them while you track 

3. Track vocals

Either tune em your self or comp them like crazy whatever makes you happy 

4. Track leads 

5. Track drums 

6. Mix it

question: Only difference I can think of is if you have effects going *before* any processing on a buss, i.e. drum tracks going to a buss, sending to a reverb also going into the same buss, as opposed to sending to a reverb from the drum buss itself. Is that what you’re getting at, @Deleted User ?

expert_answers.author: Eric Martin
expert_answers.content: if you have a reverb or delay on a bus, you could get more dry signal without opening a plug-in, just by raising the original fader a bit if the send is pre vs post fader. I use this method things where I’m trying to make the verb an atmosphere and not change the tone of the original track, that way it’s easier to do reverb throws with my faderport.

question: After spending years studying from afar, I buckled down and started mixing at the end of last year. LWMR really helped everything click for me. I used to be an artist, so I have years and years of recording experience, and doing rough mixes for myself and the homies, but I’m very new to this side of things. I was lurking around on here and I see that it’s common when starting out that doing free mixes can easily turn into doing much more. I only have 2 real “clients” right now but I’m mixing, producing, writing, recording… I love it, don’t get me wrong. The more I can help, the better. I guess I’m just having trouble navigating this space. Going deep with these 2 artists, I’m having a hard time building a portfolio, which is messing with my confidence. Specially with mixing. I can get thumbs up from the people I’m working with, my mentor (my old engineer), but without audience interaction I don’t know what to do with that. I’d like to take on more work, but I only have 1 mix out. Hopefully an EP a couple more mixes by the end of next month. I feel weird shopping myself with no portfolio, free work or not. I don’t know where I stand, where to focus my energy and everything just feels like it’s on slow-drip. Any advice?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Reps, reps, reps. However you swing it. Just do it as much as you can for as many people as you can. That’s how we all started. In this industry, like any industry, there’s a direct line between success and how much time you’ve put into *doing the thing*.

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content:
If you also produce and write, you could try building your portfolio as a mixer using your own songs. You can collaborate with a singer/artist, or bring in AI vocals on the songs you wrote. 

If you record bands, you can take the recording you did and mix it even though your job was to just record. Show it to the band and see what they say, ask them if you can use it as part of your portfolio. Make sure you ask !! 

You can also build relationships with producers with similar experience level as you and offer to mix their stuff. Producers can bring you a lot of work because they work with multiple artists

If you have other stuff that you’ve mixed in the past but they are not the best representation of your current skill level then mix them again so you can include them on your portfolio.

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content:
Mixing and mastering can mess up carefully crafted arrangements/recordings. In order for someone to give it a go with you, it would take some level of trust that they won’t be getting back a fucked up mix. 

I’m a producer that occasionally mix for others, and I found it the easiest to get in on earning people’s trust by offering other things first. Record them, or tune vocals for them and then let them know you also mix. People are more likely to record with someone they don’t know yet than to have someone they don’t know mix or produce their stuff.

As a producer, I’d deny free offers from new mixer to mix what I’m working on unless I have heard their work and I like them. I’ve had people ask if I need mixing and offered through their relationship with the artists- it always came back fucked… at least so far. So try to get in with producers through offering other stuff like engineering in writing sessions. Comp and tune the demo vocals you got from the writing session, if you do a great job they’ll more likely to give it a go with you. Don’t ask too early, make sure you build a good rapport with them first. Vocal tuning can fuck things up just as bad as mixing, so try to find things where you can just do it (e.g. you just recorded vocals for someone) over asking people if they need their vocals tuned.

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content:
Also mixing good songs is probably just as important as mixing well in terms of building a portfolio. Even if you killed the mix, a shitty song is gonna mess with people’s first impression on your work. 

If you are also supplying the songs for your portfolio, it may take longer to build it song by song- but it will give you more control over what goes on your portfolio

question:
My advice is to have in person interactions as much as possible. When it comes to making records at a super high level (intense, stressful, high standards, egos, deadlines, freakouts, etc), you need to build a level of trust that for me is impossible without spending time with a person.

It doesn't mean you can't build a career remotely, but it's harder. Not only is it harder to build trust, but the remote option is available to anyone with an internet connection. So you're competing with a much larger pool of people too.

Does that mean move to LA or London or Miami or wherever? Not necessarily. But finding a way to get in person with the kinds of people you want to work with is extremely important

question: so are metal strings usually more sought after?

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: Generally speaking, steel string guitars are more common in pop music. They've got that jangly, biting, tone. Possibly because that tone can cut through a dense arrangement easier or be more aggressive. Nylon strings are associated more with classical performance or something like flamenco, but nylon strings can certainly find their way into pop music too. 2000s RnB/Hip Hop was all about that.

question: About to go record a band playing a pre recorded gig tomorrow. First time recording a fully live thing. Set up is acoustic guitar, e bass, epiano, 2 bg vocals and a singer. I think I'm set, but tbh I also feel kinda clueless. Just thought I'd come in here and see if anyone has any tips or suggestions? feel free to fire them at me please 😅

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Hoo boy... live recording is such an anxiety hole for me. My only takeaway would be focus on isolation and flexibility and less on vibe. You can add that in later, but you can't isolate in post. I'm dealing with a live record at the moment and I can get the instrumentals to sound amazing, but the vocal mics are just bleed central and completely destroy the mix. Try super tight patterns on everything, Beta 58s on vocals if you can, & don't compress anything going into the computer.

question: How does everyone get their mid range nice and pretty , 7/10 times I always end up with quite harsh first pass on a mix 😩

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content: That’s so interesting that y’all have to tame the midrange. I have the opposite issue: I usually need to bring up the midrange. I’m generally a subtractive mixer and am cutting out a lot of resonances and whistle-tones in the sounds that I have. It has the effect of bringing down the midrange as a whole which makes me need to turn up those instruments. I end up having to force myself to be more aggressive with the mids.

question:
2 Questions:

1. Does anyone have a reason to *not* use 32 Bit Float as opposed to 24 bit depth? I've stuck with 24 out of habit, but 32 seems to have 0 downfalls, besides space usage.

2. I am having trouble monitoring hardware inserts without the obvious latency, even when I figure out the time delay in Pro Tools. Is there something I'm missing? I imagine there has to be a way to monitor hardware inserts in real time and have it be in sync (Delaying all the tracks to be in sync).

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content: Oddly enough it plays in time when I turn it off, when I have a hardware insert on a track. Haven’t tried multiple yet. Either way, feel like it should be opposite - will keep messing with it. Thanks!

community_answers.author: absflores
community_answers.content: Delay compensation should be off when tracking and on for mixing

community_answers.author: absflores
community_answers.content: Bounce between the two and see what works

community_answers.author: mixedbywong_my
community_answers.content:
I read this on reaper blog a while back when I was wondering this same question , 

This is what i found 
“To summarize:

32-bit offers absolutely no benefit in terms of sound quality or headroom as a recording bit-depth. Use 24-bit for recording.

32-bit allows you to “unclip” and remove distortion of audio that was captured within the DAW. For rendering virtual instruments or freezing tracks that might go above 0dbFS use 32-bit.”

community_answers.author: absflores
community_answers.content: Interesting the other thing is try hardware insert delay

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content: Most DAW’s internal processing happen in 32 bit floating point. Meaning even 16bit recordings will be going through 32bit floating point math when plugins are processing the audio. So the only benefit I can think of is being able to unclip recorded signal.

community_answers.author: chadwahlbrink
community_answers.content: In regards to 32-bit, I try to stick with 32bit until Mastering. This is mainly out of an "abundance of caution," but basically, it's theoretically possible to have rounding errors/quantization distortion (granted at like -128dB) when bouncing between the 32-bit processing within the DAW and other processing like izotope RX or even just bouncing stems from one person to another. Note - there is also a settting in pro tools to "always use 32-bit for audiosuite processing" for this reason! Also, you can just use a 24bit dither when you go from 32 to 24bit at mastering stage as needed (if you are providing the master).

community_answers.author: chadwahlbrink
community_answers.content: I've also recently gotten into field recording and using the Sound Devices MixPre II 6 - it can do 32-bit recording. It's pretty gnarly. I just throw sounds into RX fully clipped at like +30dB and it comes out clean after gain-ing it down. so wild.

question: Hello beautiful people,I've remembered something from one of the LWMR episodes regarding vocals,can't really reacall which one exactly,but I recall Jon saying he clip gains into a limter and I was wondering in what way is it used ? Is it gaining up the overall "evened out" signal of the clip gained vocal  ?

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content: @sloth the reason is use clip gain is so you're not relying on the limiter or compressor to level out the sound. rather, you're using the limiter or compressor for the SOUND it creates. if you want that super compressed sound (or even that lightly compressed sound) of an actual compressor or limiter, you'll often get better results if the signal going into it is evened out a bit. this used to be solved mostly by great mic technique, where a singer would lean back on big notes and whatnot. but these days by using clip gain to even out the sound before it hits your dynamic processing, you can actually more fully lean into the SOUND of the compressor or limiter that comes after it.

community_answers.author: samvalentine
community_answers.content:
My take away from that segment, if I'm remembering correctly, was that Jon doesn't use clip gain for 100% of his dynamic control. Instead, he carefully clip gains each transient/syllable/word/phrase into his dynamic processing (e.g., compressor, saturation, limiter), giving him precise control over how hard he hits the limiter.
I suppose another method to achieve similar results and that level of control would be to clip gain without processing, and then initiate a limiter (or your choice of dynamic processor) and automate the threshold and output to achieve the desired performance, but that seems like way more work to me.
I think Jon's method works well and I've been using it myself for a while. It would be interesting to hear of alternative workflows from the rest of the community though!

community_answers.author: sloth
community_answers.content: @samvalentine @oaklandmatt thank you so much for the insight < 3

question: Hello people,long question about mix approach & loudness;I'm sorry I typed this at 2 AM :https://docs.google.com/document/d/1BJvpR1AbYFzj2JUKz_kXT9SIEF05lgXtQJ1jAZzxCEQ/edit?usp=sharing

expert_answers.author: ALXCPH
expert_answers.content:
1) always, always, always if possible communicate with the client. Some peeps might want you to do it from the ground up, others might just want the sound of their demo “but better”. It really depends and has no standard. 

2) starting off loud gives you less work, trying to get a finished mix loud without Changing the Sound of it. (Lets you make more “informed” decisions when building a mix if a certain loudness or Sound is your end goal). 

Ps. Mixing for real clients in a real world is never perfect and how it is imagined. Demoitis, deadlines, budgets, ego’s and so on. It’s all just about finding the best way to consistently get results. Because that’s why people hire you.

community_answers.author: sloth
community_answers.content: Thank you for the response !

community_answers.author: alex_epton
community_answers.content: Do a quick balance first. With everything in. Don’t spend more than 15 mins on this. Check it on your aura tones too or whatever small alt speakers you use. Then put your two buss clipping/ limiting /any EQ you think you might need. Adjust this stuff til it sounds good and you’re hitting your target level. Get it as close as you can without touching your individual tracks. Then start dealing with little stuff on individual elements: Resonances. Masking. vocal sibilance. boomyness etc… needless to say you wanna sit down and tackle this with fresh ears. Your balance is probably the single most important thing you’re gonna do as a mixer. So do editing /cleaning clicks and vocal tuning on a different day

question:
Can someone here get technical as to why putting a chorus or Microshift on a delay or reverb where one side is phaseflipped. Makes it Sound less wide? 

My best guess is that its because its essentially making the phase relation ship more then 180 out of phase so it starts becoming more mono again? 

Again i have no clue. What love to talk if someone here knows!

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
I love (trying) to explain this because it always makes me think of new things to try.

You can stereoize a sound using lots of techniques, the main three being pitch, delay, and phase. Often times your favorite plugins will do combos of these, so flipping the phase on one side will sometimes kill some of your wideness.

It's worth doing a google, but something like a flanger is simply duplicating the signal and micro delaying one of them at a variable rate. So the duplicated signal might oscillate between 2-20 milliseconds, which makes that crazy flanger sound. If you take that duplicated signal and run it through an aggressive filter (which will introduce some phase shift) and that's what a phaser is. 

You can play with multiple duplicate signals, flipping phase on one side and getting wild effects. You can play with pitch on the delayed signal and start getting an effect we call "chorus." But of course, each of these types of effects are just combinations of fundamental ways to manipulate audio. Many combos are possible!

Hooray sound design!

Also, I would love @Slow Hand to correct and expand, since I know he (and many others on here) are REAL sound design nerds.

question:
Hey everyone! I’m just beginning to take mixing more seriously so I just went back and watched the LWMR about Gain Staging to begin mixing some demos I’m working on. After watching , I had a question I was hoping someone could help me answer! 

    1.    Throughout the live Matt & Jon talked about how it’s helpful to bring every track down to somewhere around -6db in order to give enough headroom when mixing. It sounds like the goal is to build back up perceived volume through exciters and saturation, but are the loudest tracks staying at -6db post-mixing? Or, is the goal to get the fundamental parts of the song (kick, vocal, snare, bass, etc..) closer to 0db after adding these different plugins (saturators, exciters) that affect the output?

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: It's really just to give you some headroom for processing. Say you have a kick drum thats showing up at 0dBFS (or super hot and limited, or whatever) then you have no room to boost low end without distorting. So turning everything down -6 (or -12 or -3, whatever you want) just gives your processing chain a chance to not fuck things up.

community_answers.content: Thank you, that’s really helpful!

question:
Ok, I have a question for Melodyne jedis:

Tunning metal vocals at the moment and I'm in constant need to change between Note Assignment Mode and Edit Mode.
What happens is that once I leave NAM and switch to EM, if I want to undo something on the NAM, I can't. Even if I don't make any changes on the EM.

Has anyone found this shituation? Do you know if there is any workaround for this?

expert_answers.author: hyanrarvey
expert_answers.content: Hold on let me ask my vocal editor dude

community_answers.author: lulu lemon
community_answers.content: There’s no way I know of where you can undo after you’ve switched back to edit mode because Melodyne does a new analyzation based on your edits every time you leave Note Assignment Mode. There’s nothing you can’t undo in Note Assignment Mode after exiting it, either, though. If you don’t want to have to deal with both at the same time, I would recommend going through the whole track in Note Assignment Mode first and figuring out any note detection discrepancies and then start tuning.

community_answers.author: Barbara
community_answers.content: Well, you live, you learn! Thank you for the explanation! 🙌

question:
How do you get lyrics on streaming platforms? Can you update lyrics on songs that are already out?

Also- can I also put translation? I’m working on a song that is a lot of spanish-english back and forth so I’d like to put translation on each of them… but I don’t know what would be the best way to do this

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
You'll probably want to decide this with the band depending on what's comfortable for them, but I generally work on this type of project in one of two ways:

1) Realtime over zoom/audiomovers - I'm sharing my screen and audio with the artist/band and coming up with sounds and parts in real time and getting their feedback in real time 

2) snail-mail style where I get some input and references on what they're looking for stylistically and I take a stab at it and send a version, rinse and repeat until everyone is happy

question: I appreciate it! "Am I going to have to rap again?" has definitely been the question haunting the back of my mind as I struggle to get releases out.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Reps, reps, reps. However you swing it. Just do it as much as you can for as many people as you can. That’s how we all started. In this industry, like any industry, there’s a direct line between success and how much time you’ve put into *doing the thing*.

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content:
Mixing and mastering can mess up carefully crafted arrangements/recordings. In order for someone to give it a go with you, it would take some level of trust that they won’t be getting back a fucked up mix. 

I’m a producer that occasionally mix for others, and I found it the easiest to get in on earning people’s trust by offering other things first. Record them, or tune vocals for them and then let them know you also mix. People are more likely to record with someone they don’t know yet than to have someone they don’t know mix or produce their stuff.

As a producer, I’d deny free offers from new mixer to mix what I’m working on unless I have heard their work and I like them. I’ve had people ask if I need mixing and offered through their relationship with the artists- it always came back fucked… at least so far. So try to get in with producers through offering other stuff like engineering in writing sessions. Comp and tune the demo vocals you got from the writing session, if you do a great job they’ll more likely to give it a go with you. Don’t ask too early, make sure you build a good rapport with them first. Vocal tuning can fuck things up just as bad as mixing, so try to find things where you can just do it (e.g. you just recorded vocals for someone) over asking people if they need their vocals tuned.

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content:
Also mixing good songs is probably just as important as mixing well in terms of building a portfolio. Even if you killed the mix, a shitty song is gonna mess with people’s first impression on your work. 

If you are also supplying the songs for your portfolio, it may take longer to build it song by song- but it will give you more control over what goes on your portfolio

community_answers.author: mario dones
community_answers.content: I hear you 100%. I came up rapping in a crew full of producers. We used the same mix engineer for everything and nobody’s free or cheaper mix was getting in the way of that. I started the year thinking I’d focused on mixing, and putting in those reps. I never saw myself writing, or producing. Like with recording, I just picked it up along the way. But to do more mixing, it seems like I need to do more of everything. Because the people I can attract right now need a lot. I guess I need to double down on being cool with that.

community_answers.author: mario dones
community_answers.content: Thanks Cian. I’m with it. I’m all the way in and I love helping the artists I’m working with. I guess I’m still feeling the shock of being asked to do more than mix. I was trying to focus the reps in one area, but I guess I need the full-body workout

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content: Try offering help to the producers and rappers from the crew! Since they already know you pretty well, I'm sure it will be a higher chance of yes than asking anyone else.

community_answers.author: mario dones
community_answers.content: I'm the only one still kicking! We're "old heads" now. I've definitely tried. One of the artists I'm working with now is a close friend from that era. Now the struggle is getting him to release music without the "old head" thinking. Which is why I'm here in this very thread lol.

community_answers.author: mario dones
community_answers.content: I really appreciate whatyou're getting at though. I've gotta to just keep mining work from where I can get it

question: Any recommendations on ear training exercises or helpful resources online for mixers? I'm just getting started mixing in the studio and would like to make sure my ears are installed correctly. Working my way through "Mixing with the Mind" by Stavrou and I've been playing with some familiar references and visual EQ, just curious if y'all have any favourite resources I should be aware of.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Silly and obvious answer, but it's the only one I think will really get you there: just do the reps. Mix your stuff, mix your friends stuff, mix anything you can get your hands on. Focus on getting a consistent sonic landscape, despite the source material. Figure out what about old or modern records you like; what you don't like. The world already has plenty of vanilla mixers that make things sound like everyone else, find a way to set yourself apart from the rest -- it's become a very crowded space and anything you can do to make your thing special will work in your favor.

community_answers.author: OMA
community_answers.content: https://www.soundgym.co/  https://v2.puremix.com/ear-training.html

community_answers.author: utilitron
community_answers.content: Awesome, thanks very much!! These look great!

community_answers.author: Calvin Lauber
community_answers.content: One of my fav ear excersizes is throwing a multiband compressor that will let you solo bands on your master/main output (compressor off, I like using gaffel, it lets you split the bands without imparting any actual processing), and listen to all of your favorite songs to see how the frequencies add up. What’s important below 80, below 120, below 300, etc. I have learned just how different so many of my favorite tracks are balanced, and also learned to identify those frequency areas by ear much faster

community_answers.author: utilitron
community_answers.content: Dang, Great idea. I'll definitely play with this with some references for a track I'm playing with.

community_answers.author: Edsel Holden
community_answers.content:
Very similar to Cal - but a long time ago someone told me to seek out full Rez waves of songs and use a HPF and LPF to see where they sat things in the frequency spectrum. 

Some songs the cymbals will go away when you filter below 10k, others you will need to filter to 5-6k.

Do the same on the lows filter and see what goes away. 

It’s very similar to what cal said but all you need is any EQ. And your listening for what goes away. I still do it sometimes. It’s a great practice.

community_answers.author: CameronKuwada
community_answers.content: This is an exercise I came up with when I first started ear training: Take a bright snap (one that has freqs up to 20k) and put it in a song/beat. Make three copies of the snap track and put one snap on each track, each spaced apart equally in space. In the first, put a lowpass up to 2.5k, in the 2nd, back up lowpass to 5k, in third, back up to 10k, and in the last, no low pass. as you play this track and cycle through snaps, you'll start to hear the differences in the various ranges from 2.5k - 10k and beyond (assuming good monitoring), and also how the equal loudness curve works.

community_answers.author: Deleted User
community_answers.content: I trained using EQs with horizontal interface. Use the same one for a long time, you'll be able to graphically know where it sits. I wouldn't recommend using analyzers to do this because they are deceiving. At some point the numbers will start pop up in your head on their own.

community_answers.author: utilitron
community_answers.content: Thanks for this. I have a mix in progress, a plan for it, and a bunch of other recordings sitting around. Part of me has always known there are no good shortcuts to anywhere worthwhile in life.

question: How do I find the LA travel sub thread thing?! Gonna be there next week and want to bug y’all with questions

What would you consider the best beginner online music education for contemporary music making and methods? If you had a child who wanted to get into making music via online classes, where would you send them and why?

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content:
Maybe this is a hot take, but I believe everyone is actually self-taught. We each have unique learning styles- some are better with visual examples, some auditory, some complete fucking animals read the manual, 
Some like no examples at all and just want to experiment. 

Modern music making is a playground, and doing things wrong often engenders creativity.   Technique is teachable, but artistry is only cultivated. 

Curiosity and tenacity are the only skills required. Everything else is a google search away.

question: Any luck @! Andy ! where you left off?  I passed out early last night.

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content:
One thing I noticed is that this video shows you are looking at the mix for Outputs 1+2 on your Evo- what you hear from your monitors I assume - make sure you check out your mix on outputs 3+4 by clicking that on the right hand side of the software mixer.  You probably got feedback because input channel 4 in the Evo software is turned up on output 3+4 mix.  If you only plan to use outputs 3+4 for hardware loops, make sure Mac 3 and Mac 4 are turned up to unity (0) and Mac 1+2 are turned all the way down, and I’d turn down all the mic inputs  so you don’t create any feedback loops.

If that’s all set up correctly I’m stumped for now!

question: I have no clue where to post this, but it's kind of an advanced newbie question in a way. I've been doing some editing for a friend who records nature full-time. She sells the recordings online, and the clientele is presumably people in gaming, film, and app dev. A lot of the recordings are double mid/side and we're trying to figure out what's standard or expected in those industries when it comes to deliverables for multichannel recordings. 3 channel for the client to decode? 4ch? 4 stems front, back, L, R? Mono front, mono back, stereo L/R? maybe a long shot but does anyone have experience in this world?

expert_answers.author: LAPhill
expert_answers.content: (From a sound designer who works in games)

community_answers.author: Josh Bowman
community_answers.content: Hmm if they’re nature ambiences I’ve only run into mostly stereo files in libraries… as well as some surround (ie 5.1)  formats before when mixing/ sound designing for tv. Will message a buddy who does game audio and see if they have any other intel for ya.

community_answers.author: popaganda.
community_answers.content: Awesome, that gives a little clarity.

community_answers.author: SoundsLikeJoe
community_answers.content:
Double M/S is by default a Quadraphonic matrix output. LRLsRs.  Quad files are an odd format, but you can scale them to a standard SMPTE surround file. L R C Lfe Ls Rs....   but use audio black in C and LFE imo. You could push LR to C and all to LFE but you might lose mono compatibility with folddown. 

Dispite what they say...   Don't over bloat your deliverable with everything and the kitchen sink. It's sort of unnecessary if you include the natural matrix output of the format. Preserving the Quad output in a standard SMPTE poly wav would be the cleanest thing.  Just make sure you're also using UCS metadata formats.  These days that's a big feature for sound designers.

question: Do you remember if you formatted the drive originally on Windows or on Mac?

expert_answers.author: Adam Thein
expert_answers.content: I think mine was formatted on Mac if I remember correctly, so I'll probably either reformat this to APFS (i don't swap between machines anymore) or try formatting to exFat on the PC

community_answers.author: river
community_answers.content: It may have been windows, but I am unsure

community_answers.author: river
community_answers.content: Yeah if I could use APFS I'd do it in a heartbeat

community_answers.author: popthetrunk
community_answers.content:
It seems like your exfat drive got a ‘dirty’ bit set after an unsafe unmount and MacOS is stopping you from writing to a drive it doesn’t know will retain your work. Windows is being less cautious. It’s likely nothing is wrong with your volume, but without installing some odd tooling on your Mac this is how I would reset with access to both os.

Run a CHKDSK on that drive in windows(this will take some time) and then run first aid in disk utility to see if any file permissions got messed up when unmounting.

community_answers.author: Iwan Morgan
community_answers.content: I don’t like EXFat and have been in the exact same situation as you in the past year. Windows does some strange things to drives and PC owners seem far more comfortable with some errors thrown up from time to time. Exfat also doesn’t work with Backblaze so i’m never going there again.

question: Let me preface by saying nothing tangible has got me feeling down or discouraged. In fact I think I'm in the best season of my life so far and it feels like everything is going right (aside: aren't you more likely to self sabotage when things are good than when they are bad?) to zoom out a little bit, i already know the answer. I'm doing too much at once, spreading myself thin beyond enjoyment. in the grit of a transition and it's clear where I'm going but I have no frame of reference for the timeline. A few years ago, I was mid-20s, in a band on a major, had roommates & cheap rent, and a chess app addiction. i was still a "professional" but things were extremely simple. in short, left the band, spent a few years mixing much more than producing, and now am swinging back that way. I'm about to turn 30, I have a mortgage, a (semi) dependent, my first real studio, an intern to set an example for, 5ish mixing clients at any moment, producing for 3 artists and co-prod/consulting on 2 other projects, playing occasionally in any of 4 different bands, and producing/recording some live performances (as well as starting a YT channel in this lane). In my experience at least, it really seems like something shifted at the top of this year, and I hate to say it but part of the fault is TikTok (is the rest of the fault mine?). Everything is urgent to everyone and nothing informs each other or oscillates together. It feels like a clock is constantly going "tick, tock, tick, tock" and the anxiety I once had over money is shifted completely towards my time management. Every time I look away from my phone I have 30 new texts. I think I'm crushing it in my professional demands but I don't know that I'm being the person I want to be for my friends, family and partner. I don't know that I'm setting a good example to this intern. I don't know that I'm there to take care of myself all the way.

expert_answers.author: bobby k
expert_answers.content: I went deep with MJM last year to eliminate most of the fluff clogging the pipes, but it all seeped back in with time and the reason is simple - I fucking love making music and will say yes to every single opportunity. But it feels like there are a few too many artists I'm trying to lift up at once and I can't tell if it's ego or love at play - love for what they're making, or the ego wanting to be involved and feel important.

community_answers.author: cy (sigh)
community_answers.content:
I definitely don't think I can chime in too much the soecifixs. while we're of similar age you have a lot more "concrete" experience in the music space than I do. my stressors, are vastly different from this rn. some are the usual financial + get more work problems but the main ones very heavy and have to do with where I'm from. can't really speak on them without touching bits of  politics. 

I do think that the way you're expressing yourself around the topic makes it pretty clear how  self aware you actually are. I think the tasks  for you are more about drawing bounderies and figuring out a practical method of finding that line for yourself, in a consistent manner that doesn't make you "feel bad" about letting certain opportunitiea go.

question: I'm curious: Does anyone here have any insight into the drum sound on Foo Fighters "My Hero?" It's a really wild drum sound. Whenever I'm driving and that song comes on the radio it always piques my interest... I've been sifting through a few different reference tracks recently, and I just listened to it on headphones for the first time. They do some really wild stereo stuff with the drums in the intro and the chorus - You can hear it really pronounced on headphones. It's actually a little disconcerting hearing the cymbals basically mirroring each other in the left and right like that - and the snare, too. The cymbals also have a very pronounced "BWEEESHHH..." sound. It's a very unique sound... I suspect there were a lot of room mics going on in that sound, but of course I have no idea. Anyway, would love to hear from anyone who might know.

expert_answers.author: Edward Rivera
expert_answers.content: Intro was recorded in the garage of Grandmaster Recorders

question: https://youtu.be/UN6-CBF41Sk?si=s3x3_fKvnKhRNyC_

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Just everything - The flamming (the two drum kits playing at the same time), the panning, the strong stereo sounds reflecting in L and R. It's just... a very wild and unconventional sound to me...

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM

Like, I NEVER heard of two drums until this morning when I watched the video breakdown of that song! Also... I think as a drummer I tend to listen to things a little less objectively - because I imagine the snare should always be dead center, kick should be dead center - 18 crash on the right 16 on the left and so on and so forth. This track definitely challenged my concept of what a recorded drum kit "should" sound like - and mostly where it should sit in the mix. Panning and everything...

question: So, just to clarify- You're setting up hotkeys so that you can nudge sections in ms increments, correct? Like, for example, you've got a 2ms hotkey or 6 ms hotkey or a 10 ms hotkey, and you're just nudging things along incrementally like this, correct? 1 ms seems like such an imperceptibly small amount, though...? How often do you go down that low with the nudges?

expert_answers.author: Edward Rivera
expert_answers.content:
I set mine at 10ms, easy to tell if I’ve gone too far with even one nudge. Then I’ll set it to 5ms, and go back

And yes since we are in the millisecond range try not to get too hung up on it. I break out this tool if there’s a late snare hit but I don’t go messing around with an entire groove unless it’s noticeable 

The longer you spend on this the less objective you can be come

question: Hey guys! Can someone give me a good way to do performance mixes for an artist? One of the artists i work with is going on tour and need to export some performance mixes for him. expert_answers.content: Big side benefit of this is you've just made a plugin-proof archive of the multitrack if someone comes back to you in 19 years for the 20 year remix deluxe version

community_answers.author: cy (sigh)
community_answers.content:
you mostly just mute the leads and any other vocal track they don't want in the playback. 

if they'll have a producer /engineer doing playback sending stems (groups) might be helpful. 

the mastering doesn't usually come into play here. some big label folk might ask to send those files to mastering too. would probably be considered alts (some mastering folk will charge extra for them, some wont if it's not too many files)

Bonus points if you have sub folders for everything and their instrument groups with good labeling!
