question: Thanks for your sharing! I'll consider investing my acoustic treatment before upgrading my audio interface. One more question if you don't mind: I'm using DT770 to mix, and i know that headphone isn't dependent on the treatment of the room. So if my mix still sound not right, that could only be attributed to my mixing skill right??

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Your results will almost always be attributed to your skills! In this case, while I'd focus my attention on getting some reps in on various mixing projects, there's certainly room to grow in your equipment stable. Headphones are a great starting point and will likely continue to be useful down the road, but mixing on speakers helps you make things translate better to the real world (car & home stereos, public spaces, etc). So a pair of decent entry level monitors would be my next purchase. It will also prove useful for collaborating with other folks down the road as you can all hear the same thing from the same source.

question: i've seen a few multiband plugins defaults split their crossovers at 100, 1000, and 10,000 - is there a scientific reason behind these numbers showing up that often?

question: Say more about approaching mixing from the perspective of an electronics designer. What does this mean in practical terms?

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
Phase shift on a single sound is rarely (if at all) noticeable. 

Phase shift on a sound becomes important when that sound interacts with a second sound. It’s about the relationship between them because it changes the constructive and destructive interference (phase cancellation) that occurs between the two sounds.

There may be a few instances where it matters in the context of a single sound, but I’ll let more qualfied people chime in on that.

community_answers.author: tinkerjef
community_answers.content: Hmm I’m still early in developing this, but I think it isn’t far off from anyone else tbh, I guess im just a little more invested in exactly how the gear achieves the sound it gets and using that knowledge to design my own gear that I record through

community_answers.author: tinkerjef
community_answers.content: As far as end result mixing approaches I don’t think there’s really any difference

question:
Phase coherence as it relates to speakers vs how an eq shifts phase within a single track in mixing are two entirely different worlds. Not worth considering how they relate. 

For what it’s worth, I almost never pay attention to how an eq effect phase except for when filtering out low end, as it actually does create a resonant peak just above the filter point. 

Otherwise the only question that really needs answering is “is this better for the track?”

expert_answers.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_answers.content: It might be worth unpacking a little more, like @Rollmottle was getting at, the idea of having a  “philosophy of mixing.” I’m gonna move that conversation over to #👩🍳mixing-talk tho

question: Any distinct advantages to mixing on open back vs closed back headphones? Anything I might be being short sighted about and possibly missing? Got some really nice open back cans the other day (akg k701). They sound absolutely SUPERB, but I'm not super into the whole open back experience if I'm honest.

expert_answers.author: cian riordan
expert_answers.content: Pros and cons, like anything else. Open back tend to have a more neutral response… almost closer to being on speakers. Less fatiguing. Downside is lack of isolation from outside world, lack of low/high end “hype”. Neither are a panacea and both will have their issues with translation to the outside world. I can mix in headphones because I’ve mixed in good sounding rooms as built up good practices - with good results - for 20 years. But it isn’t my ideal. I would almost always trust a decent sounding — even unideal room before solely relying on them.

question: Are you on a Kensington trackball?

expert_answers.author: BatMeckley
expert_answers.content:
So, for pro tools I assign the three extra buttons for each one of the tools, and then chording the top two buttons gives me multitool in the instances that’s useful.  

Then my left hand is on asdfg for fades and moving the boundaries of clips (WAY faster than multi tool to just click in the middle of a region or at the zero crossing of an audio file and hitting A)

After a few days it should become pretty intuitive and automatic. Like anything else, it’ll take a second to adjust, 2 steps back, 3 steps fwd style.

Another perk of using melodyne standalone is assigning the trackball buttons for the note tune, cut notes, note length, and the chords for vibrato and note length tools. Makes melo WAYYYY faster.

question: Hey, my first few projects that I've worked on are getting close to releasing. With that I have a few questions about how to best use Instagram for advertising myself. 1. Should I make an engineering specific account? 2. Does it make sense to make posts for every release or just stick to stories? 3. I would appreciate any best practices or things you wish you did when getting started with promoting yourself

expert_answers.author: Jonathan Jetter
expert_answers.content: I don't want to clog the channel, but very quickly (and this is quite an oversimplification): If you have a 10% chance of incurring a $10,000 loss, then your EV is -$1000 (-$10000 * 0.1). So you'll lose $1k on average, but in actual real life it's a binary outcome: either -$10k or -$0. Insurance mitigates that variance, but not for free. So you don't just pay $1000, it gets marked up, and  you might pay the insurance company $1200 to insure against that $10,000 risk. The numbers are very very simplified to make the point briefly.

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Thank you for going into that. Appreciate you!

community_answers.author: Josh Bowman
community_answers.content: If you’re proud of them, I’d do a post and story some people won’t see the story since it’s time limited. If you can make them both personal in some way that’s always better…. All of us who have a bunch of engineer friends on their insta get flooded with these on new music Friday etc. at least the posts and stories that have some thought or personal touch put into them are a little interesting and stand out. Just my 2 cents. Also I try to tag anyone I can who was involved in the hopes of re-shares as well as giving credit where it’s due.

community_answers.author: Josh Bowman
community_answers.content: Also I’ll add- you can always delete a post later or edit it if needed. So don’t stress too much.

community_answers.author: chris_donlin
community_answers.content: I think stories are sufficient. The only time i really do a full grid post is if i worked on an album or part of an album. Honestly when i go on someone's page and see a template formatted grid post for every single song they worked on, I'm a little turned off. I think that should be saved for a website. But all that said, there isn't really a right or wrong, though having zero online presence could be argued as a wrong

question: Have you done a vocal lesson with a great vocal coach? They will help you in person with this. You really need this for what you're talking about as the answers are vary widely person to person

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
Great. A great vocal coach will walk you through so much of the shit we're all describing to you. 

It's SO much more physical than any other instrument that having someone who knows their shit help you IN PERSON is essential imho

community_answers.author: Yu Justin K
community_answers.content: Choir classes in music school (UofO) that implemented warm-ups and exercises before singing is the extent of my vocal training. Haven't done anything 1-to-1 with a great coach yet, but will take lessons from one within the next couple of weeks.

community_answers.author: youngteam
community_answers.content: I’m an extremely mediocre vocalist but got some professional lessons a few years back. Asides from warm ups the thing that really stuck with me was to not try and correct to make it sound good to my ear, but to learn what it feels like to sing properly

community_answers.author: gatewoodsensei
community_answers.content:
When you sing, you want to be as relaxed as possible. The moment it starts to feel like it hurts STOP. Breathing correctly also helps. When you breathe in, push your stomach out. You’re effectively getting the air into your diaphragm which is where you want the power to come from. When you breathe in, kinda do it like you’re yawning. That opens up the back of your throat (pause). Ideally you want your throat to act as a channel that your voice comes out of. If you look in the mirror while you sing, there’s this little bulge in your throat (like an Adam’s apple) - that’s your larynx. You wanna keep that either centered or moving down. You’ll notice if you start singing and you’re straining, it’ll start moving up, closer to your chin. That’ll eventually hurt your voice.

Sorry if that’s a lot. I have more lol but I just wrote what I could off the top of my head.

Edit: oh yea! When you’re warming up, do lip trills or hum into a straw! Like a 5 note scale going up and down. Starting from the bottom of your range to the top (before I starts to hurt).  That gets the sound to what’s called the “mask” of your face. That also takes the stress off of your throat when you sing.

community_answers.author: Yu Justin K
community_answers.content: Just tried out humming into a straw earlier today and I like it so much more than lip trills! Seems to do the same thing as lip trills but without losing as much air.

community_answers.author: Yu Justin K
community_answers.content: Thanks again everyone. Just scheduled a meetup with a vocal coach who happens to be a great artist and been teaching for over a decade now 🗣️

community_answers.author: Chad Rodgers
community_answers.content:
Vocal coaching and the advice I got along the way worked wonders for me. It is very personal like @oaklandmatt and others say though so if you can, try out a couple. Think of it like a therapist but for your vocal cords and diaphragm, lol.

First coach I tried was quite prescriptive, traditional and rules-based and wasn’t the right fit for me, yet the second coach (who is coach and vocal producer to a bunch of top UK-based pop artists) was awesome. Made me feel super confident and didn’t try and change my voice, just helped me strengthen it.

question:
I'm frustrated at the level of my mixes and would appreciate some feedback. My band just released an EP that I mixed and mastered, since we don't have budget to hire someone else to do it. 

I've read up on normalization, have used streaming preview occasionally on RX, and most of the songs are coming in at an integrated -10 or -9lufs, which I thought would result in more information being preserved and transients not being cut as much, but I have to turn up the songs in my car much more than other songs when I compare. 

Is it as simple as turning them up to -8,-7? I thought doing so would result in losing more transient information once it hits the codec, but maybe that's wrong. Any insight appreciated.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
In addition to the advice here, you might want to jump on #🤝collab-talk talk and ask if there's anyone willing to give you mix feedback. I'm sure you'll get some takers and you can send stuff to folks in the DMs. 

As @masteredbyjack says, loudness is more of a perception that you achieve in the arrangement and mix than the LUFS number. Learning how to treat sounds to make them feel loud is a big part of loudness.

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: There’s a lot to this

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: It’s hugely arrangement depending how things translate

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: Also, comparing songs on an EP to ones off it is tricky since the whole EP is normalized based on the loudest track

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: Feel free to DM I can take a listen to the actual songs and see if any thoughts pop up

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: One way to start is adding a song or two off the EP onto a playlist you made with other songs, that way they are normalized based on each song

community_answers.author: masteredbyjack
community_answers.content: But shooting for a certain lufs number is a bad time (not saying you are). Arrangement, vocal level, overall eq all play a big role in perceived loudness.

question: Hey, gang. Hey, team. Um... what's everybody doing when they record hardcore guitars? I, um... I recorded guitars for my album, and I did a really good job, but on a few of the songs the intonation might be just the slightest bit off - Off enough for me to curse myself and maybe want to do something different with my monitoring. It just... if anybody wants to hear it, I'll send a link. Really feels like a mistake I shouldn't have made - especially since I'm such an intonation FREAK. Ugh... Thanks.

expert_answers.author: Slow Hand
expert_answers.content:
Do it better on the next record and keep moving. 99% of listeners don’t care about intonation. It is not going to break your record. 

If Lou Reed can sell a million records and get into the Rock n Roll Hall of Fame with that ear for pitch you’ll be just fine.

I did run tests) and maybe do something a bit different with the levels in my headphones, but yeah... hopefully what I did is enough.

community_answers.author: SawyerM

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM

community_answers.author: SawyerM

community_answers.author: SawyerM
community_answers.content: Yes, the only time I won't tune is if it's punching into short parts... if it's just fixing a couple bad notes I will do multiple takes in between tuning

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Understood. Thank you. Yeah, that's what I did - tuned between each take. Some of the songs are SLAMMING in tune - like crazy in tune such that I surprised myself, but some of the others are just... off a little bit - more than a little bit, imo. Surprised me when I sat down to really do the critical listening last night. I must've just... not been as diligent somewhere along the way. Maybe too much caffeine. Ha

question: So, if you do four takes with the idea of selecting two - one R and one L - are you tuning before each one?

expert_answers.author: Zack Hames
expert_answers.content:
I pan the first one hard and then double with the other panned opposite. I may turn up the current one a slight amount.

Also when I do the doubles I always have to turn both down a few dB to be able to hear everything else.

I’m also super used to doing it, so I don’t know how else I would do it. I just make micro adjustments to the levels as needed

community_answers.author: SawyerM
community_answers.content: Yes, the only time I won't tune is if it's punching into short parts... if it's just fixing a couple bad notes I will do multiple takes in between tuning

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: Understood. Thank you. Yeah, that's what I did - tuned between each take. Some of the songs are SLAMMING in tune - like crazy in tune such that I surprised myself, but some of the others are just... off a little bit - more than a little bit, imo. Surprised me when I sat down to really do the critical listening last night. I must've just... not been as diligent somewhere along the way. Maybe too much caffeine. Ha

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: I'm gonna try and keep in mind what @Slow Hand  said, though - about it not being a crazy big deal.

community_answers.author: SawyerM
community_answers.content: Yeah, while having really good tuning is sick, a really good performance should always be the #1 priority

community_answers.author: BoozleBAM
community_answers.content: That's so it. Yup. thank you for re-iterating that.

community_answers.author: spookydrums
community_answers.content: I also think that tuning to the actual key you're playing in is really important as guitars will inevitably have certain notes be more in tune than others on the neck. So if you're playing a song in E major, don't tune your open G string to a g, but fret it at the first fret and tune that to a G# instead. That will help a lot as well in my experience.

question:
Hi guys. I’m getting to a point where I feel like I could really benefit from some mentorship, but I’m not familiar with how those relationships tend to function in the space. 

I see some of you mentioning past mentors, how did that come to fruition?? Was it on paper internships at their studio? Or did you seek them out specifically and pay for their time?

Ideally I’d like to work under someone, but I’m not sure how to open that door.

expert_answers.author: oaklandmatt
expert_answers.content:
When successful music producers talk about "mentors," it's almost always working under someone. This usually starts out as an internship or assistant position of some sort. Some come through your network of music friends, some come from doing exceptional work and people further along in their career taking notice, and some come from applying to the various "looking for an assistant with xyz qualifications" posts you see here and on social media.

I made an album with a local band called the Matches up in Oakland. They started getting attention from record labels and big producers in LA. I moved to LA and met Eric Valentine who liked the album and met with the band. I asked if I could intern for him. He said he didn't have interns but I should stay in touch cause sometimes they hired extra help. I called him every two weeks for the next six months until an opportunity opened up. Then I assisted him for five years while making indie records on the side.

question:
Clipper question:

I was watching Jon castelli mix on just for the record and he put a clipper on a track and then followed it up with a transient designer adding attack. What is  the thought process behind that move? What’s the reason for clipping off the front end and then adding it right back?

expert_answers.author: Bryan DiMaio
expert_answers.content:
also a clipper isn't just an envelope shaper, it's essentially a form of distortion
so if you replace "clipper" with "saturation" in your question, the transient designer doesn't sound all that out of place because as kidcutler pointed out it's doing more than just doing -1 and then +1

community_answers.author: kidcutler
community_answers.content: I believe the theory is that it isn’t just clipping it’s spreading that energy out across a broad band, beefing it up then adding back the attack that was lost

community_answers.author: nick
community_answers.content: That’s a makes much more sense now . Thank you!!!
